column1: darśaḥ asi darśataḥ asi samagraḥ asi samantaḥ / samagraḥ samantaḥ bhūyāsam gobhiḥ aśvaiḥ prajayā paśubhiḥ gṛhaiḥ dhanena /
column2: Thou art the New Moon, fair to see, thou art complete in every part. May I be perfect, fully blest in every way in steeds and kine, in children, cattle, home, and wealth.

column1: yaḥ asmān dveṣṭi yam vayam dviṣmaḥ tasya tvam prāṇena ā pyāyasva / ā vayam pyāsiṣīmahi gobhiḥ aśvaiḥ prajayā paśubhiḥ gṛhaiḥ dhanena /
column2: Inflate thee with his vital breath who hathes us and whom we detest. May we grow rich in steeds and kine, in children, cattle, houses, wealth.

column1: yam devāḥ aṃśum āpyāyayanti yam akṣitam akṣitāḥ bhakṣayanti / tena asmān indraḥ varuṇaḥ bṛhaspatiḥ ā pyāyayantu bhuvanasya gopāḥ /
column2: With that unwasting stalk which Gods, unwasting Gods, in- crease and eat, May Varuna, Brihaspati, and Indra, the Lords and Guardians of the world, increase us.

column1: abhi arcata suṣṭutim gavyam ājim asmāsu bhadrā draviṇāni dhatta / imam yajñam nayata devatā naḥ ghṛtasya dhārāḥ madhumat pavantām /
column2: Sing with fair laud the combat for the cattle. Bestow upon us excellent possessions. Lead to the Gods the sacrifice we offer: let streams of oil flow pure and full of sweetness.

column1: mayi agre agnim gṛhṇāmi saha kṣatreṇa varcasā balena / mayi prajām mayi āyuḥ dadhāmi svāhā mayi agnim /
column2: Agni I first appropriate with power, with splendour, and with might. I give myself children and lengthened life, with Hail! take Agni to myself.

column1: iha eva agne adhi dhāraya rayim mā tvā ni kran pūrva cittāḥ nikāriṇaḥ / kṣatreṇa agne suyamam astu tubhyam upasattā vardhatām te a niṣṭṛtaḥ /
column2: Even here do thou, O Agni, stablish wealth: let not oppressors injure thee by thinking of thee first. Light be thy task of ruling, Agni, with, thy power: may he who worships thee wax strong, invincible.

column1: anu agniḥ uṣasām agram akhyat anu ahāni prathamaḥ jātavedāḥ / anu sūryaḥ uṣasaḥ anu raśmīn anu dyāvāpṛthivī ā viveśa / prati agniḥ uṣasām agram akhyat prati ahāni prathamaḥ jātavedāḥ / prati sūryasya purudhā ca raśmīn prati dyāvāpṛthivī ā tatāna /
column2: Agni hath looked upon the spring of Morning, looked on the days, the earliest Jātavedas. So, following the gleams of Morning, Sūrya hath entered heaven and earth as his possession. Agni hath looked upon the spring of Mornings, looked on the days, the earliest Jātavedas. So he in countless places hath extended, full against heaven and earth, the beams of Sūrya.

column1: ghṛtam te agne divye sadhasthe ghṛtena tvām manuḥ adyā sam indhe / ghṛtam te devīḥ naptyaḥ ā vahantu ghṛtam tubhyam duhratām gāvaḥ agne /
column2: Butter to thee in heaven thy home, O Agni! Manu this day hath kindled thee with butter. Let the Celestial Daughters bring thee butter: Let cows pour butter forth for thee, O Agni.

column1: apsu te rājan varuṇa gṛhaḥ hiraṇyayaḥ mitaḥ / tatas dhṛta vrataḥ rājā sarvā dhāmāni muñcatu //
column2: Stablished amid the waters is, King Varuna, thy golden home. Thence let the Sovran who maintains the statutes loose all bind- ing cords.

column1: dāmnaḥ udāmnaḥ rājan itas varuṇa muñca naḥ / yat āpaḥ aghnyāḥ iti varuṇa iti yat ūcima tatas varuṇa muñca naḥ /
column2: Hence free thou us, King Varuna, from each successive bond and tie. As we have cried, O Varuna! have said, The Waters, they are kine, thence set us free, O Varuna.

column1: ud uttamam varuṇa pāśam asmat ava adhamam vi madhyamam śrathāya / adha vayam āditya vrate tava anāgasaḥ aditaye syāma /
column2: Loosen the bonds, O Varuna, that hold us, loosen the bond. above, between, and under. So before Aditi may we be sinless under thy favouring auspices, Āditya!

column1: pra asmat pāśān varuṇa muñca sarvān ye uttamāḥ adhamāḥ vāruṇāḥ ye / duṣvapnyam duritam ni sva asmat atha gacchema su kṛtasya lokam /
column2: Varuna, free us from all snares that bind us, Varuna's bonds, the upper and the lower. Drive from us evil dream, drive off misfortune: then let us pass into the world of virtue.

column1: anādhṛṣyaḥ jātavedāḥ amartyaḥ virāj agne kṣatra bhṛt dīdihi iha / viśvāḥ amīvāḥ pramuñcan mānuṣībhiḥ śivābhiḥ adya pari pāhi naḥ gayam /
column2: Holder of sway, shine here refulgent, Agni! invincible immortal Jātavedas. With succours friendly to mankind, auspicious, driving away all maladies, guard our dwelling.

column1: indra kṣatram abhi vāmam ojaḥ ajāyathāḥ vṛṣabha carṣaṇīnām / apānudaḥ janam amitrayantam urum devebhyaḥ akṛṇoḥ u lokam /
column2: Thou, Indra, lord and leader of the people, wast born for lovely strength and high dominion. Thou dravest off the folk who were unfriendly, and madest for the Gods wide room and freedom.

column1: mṛgaḥ na bhīmaḥ kucaraḥ giriṣṭhāḥ parāvataḥ ā jagamyāt parasyāḥ / sṛkam saṃśāya pavim indra tigmam vi śatrūn tāḍhi vi mṛdhaḥ nudasva /
column2: Like a dread wild beast roaming on the mountain, may he. approach us from the farthest distance. Whetting thy bolt and thy sharp blade, O Indra, crush down our foes and scatter those who hate us.

column1: tyam u su vājinam deva jūtam sahovānam tarutāram rathānām / ariṣṭa nemim pṛtanājim āśum svastaye tārkṣyam iha ā huvema /
column2: This very mighty one whom Gods urge onward, the conqueror of cars, ever triumphant, Swift, fleet to battle, with uninjured fellies, even Tārkshya for our weal will we call hither.

column1: trātāram indram avitāram indram have ihave su havam śūram indram / huve nu śakram puruhūtam indram svasti naḥ indraḥ maghavā kṛṇotu //
column2: Indra the rescuer, Indra the helper, Indra the brave who hears each invocation, Sakra I call, Indra invoked of many. May Indra Maghavan pros- per and bless us.

column1: yaḥ agnau rudraḥ yaḥ apsu antar yaḥ oṣadhīḥ vīrudhaḥ āviveśa / yaḥ imā viśvā bhuvanāni ca ākḷpe tasmai rudrāya namaḥ astu agnaye /
column2: To Rudra in the fire, to him who dwells in floods, to Rudra who hath entered into herbs and plants, To him who formed and fashioned all these worlds, to him this Rudra, yea, to Agni, reverence be paid!

column1: apehi ariḥ asi ariḥ vai asi viṣe viṣam apṛkthāḥ viṣam id vai apṛkthāḥ / ahim eva abhyapehi tam jahi //
column2: Depart! thou art a foe, a foe. Poison with poison hast thou mixt, yea, verily poison hast thou mixt. Go to the serpent: strike him dead.

column1: apaḥ divyāḥ acāyiṣam rasena sam apṛkṣmahi / payasvān agne āgamam tam mā sam sṛja varcasā /
column2: The heavenly Waters have I ranged: we have been sated with their dew. Here, Agni, bearing milk, am I. Endow me with the gift of strength.

column1: sam mā agne varcasā sṛja sam prajayā sam āyuṣā / vidyuḥ me asya devāḥ indraḥ vidyāt saha ṛṣibhiḥ /
column2: Endow me with the gift of strength, with children, and a length- ened life. May the Gods mark this prayer of mine, may Indra with the Rishis mark.

column1: idam āpaḥ pra vahata avadyam ca malam ca yat / yat ca abhidudroha anṛtam yat ca śepe abhīruṇam //
column2: Ye Waters, wash away this stain and whatsoever taint be here, Each sinful wrong that I have done and every harmless curse of mine.

column1: edhaḥ asi edhiṣīya samidh asi sam edhiṣīya / tejaḥ asi tejaḥ mayi dhehi //
column2: Thou art the wood, may I succeed! fuel, may I be glorified! splendour, give splendour unto me.

column1: api vṛśca purāṇa vat vratateḥ iva guṣpitam / ojaḥ dāsasya dambhaya //
column2: Tear thou asunder, as of old, like tangles of a creeping plant. Demolish thou the Dāsa's might.

column1: vayam tat asya sambhṛtam vasu indrena vi bhajāmahai / mlāpayāmi bhrajaḥ śibhram varuṇasya vratena te /
column2: May we with Indra's help divide the gathered treasure of the foe. I, by the law of Varuna, bring down thy pride and wantonness.

column1: yathā śepaḥ apāyātai strīṣu ca asat anāvayāḥ / avasthasya knadīvataḥ śāṅkurasya nitodinaḥ / yat ātatam ava tat tanu yat uttatam ni tat tanu //
column2: Ut virga abeat et feminis innocua fiat, (virga) membri humidi, membri quod verberat penetratque, id quod tentum est laxa, id quod sursum tentum est deorsum tende.

column1: indraḥ sutrāmā svavām avobhiḥ su mṛḍīkaḥ bhavatu viśva vedāḥ / bādhatām dveṣaḥ abhayam naḥ kṛṇotu su vīryasya patayaḥ syāma / sa sutrāmā svavān indraḥ asmat ārāt cit dveṣaḥ sanutar yuyotu / tasya vayam sumatau yajñiyasya api bhadre saumanase syāma /
column2: May Indra with his help, Lord of all treasures, be unto us a careful protector. Drive off our foes and give us peace and safety. May we be lords of goodly store of heroes. May this rich Indra as our good protector keep even far away the men who hate us. May we enjoy his favour, his the holy: may we enjoy his blessed loving-kindness.

column1: indreṇa manyunā vayam abhi syāma pṛtanyataḥ / ghnantaḥ vṛtrāṇi aprati /
column2: With Indra's and with Manyu's aid may we subdue our enemies, resistlessly destroying foes.

column1: dhruvam dhruveṇa haviṣā ava somam nayāmasi / yathā naḥ indraḥ kevalīḥ viśaḥ saṃmanasaḥ karat /
column2: We laid the constant Soma on with constant sacrificial gift, That Indra may make all the tribes unanimous and only ours.

column1: ud asya śyāvau vithurau gṛdhrau dyām iva petatuḥ / ucchocana praśocanau asya ucchocanau hṛdaḥ / aham enau ud atiṣṭhipam gāvau śrānta sadau iva / kurkurau iva kūjantau udavantau vṛkau iva /
column2: To heaven, as 'twere, have soared this man's two vultures, staggering, dusky hued. The Parcher and the Drier-up, the pair who parch and dry his heart. I verily have stirred them up like oxen resting after toil. Like two loud-snarling curs, or like two wolves who watch to make their spring:

column1: ātodinau nitodinau atho saṃtodinau uta / api nahyāmi asya meḍhram yaḥ itas strī pumān jabhāra //
column2: Like two that thrust, like two that pierce, like two that strike with mutual blows. I bind the conduit of the man or dame who hence hath taken aught.

column1: asadan gāvaḥ sadane apaptat vasatim vayaḥ / āsthāne parvatāḥ asthuḥ sthāmni vṛkkau atiṣṭhipam /
column2: The kine are resting in the stall, home to her nest hath flown the bird, The hills are firmly rooted: I have fixed the kidneys in their place.

column1: yat adya tvā prayati yajñe asmin hotar cikitvan avṛṇīmahi iha / dhruvam ayaḥ dhruvam uta śaviṣṭhai pravidvān yajñam upa yāhi somam /
column2: As we have here elected thee, skilled Hotar! to-day as this our sacrifice proceedeth, Come to the firm place, mightiest! yea, come firmly. Knowing the sacrifice, approach the Soma.

column1: sam indra naḥ manasā neṣa gobhiḥ sam sūribhiḥ harivan sam svastyā / sam brahmaṇā deva hitam yat asti sam devānām sumatau yajñiyānām /
column2: With kine connect us, and with spirit, Indra! Lord of Bay Steeds, with princes and with favour, With the God-destined portion of the Brāhmans, and the good-will of Gods who merit worship.

column1: yān āvahaḥ uśataḥ deva devān tān preraya sve agne sadhasthe / jakṣivāṃsaḥ papivāṃsaḥ madhūni asmai dhatta vasavaḥ vasūni //
column2: The willing Gods whom, God, thou hast brought hither, send thou to their own dwelling-place, O Agni. When ye have eaten and have drunk sweet juices, endow this man with precious wealth, ye Vasus.

column1: sugā vaḥ devāḥ sadanāḥ akarma yaḥ ājagma savane mā juṣāṇāḥ / vahamānāḥ bharamāṇāḥ svā vasūni vasum gharmam divam ā rohata anu //
column2: Gods, we have made your seats of easy access, who, pleased with me, have come to my libation. Bearing and bringing hitherward your treasures, after the rich warm beverage mount to heaven.

column1: yajña yajñam gaccha yajñapatim gaccha / svām yonim gaccha svāhā /
column2: Go to the sacrifiee, go to its master, Sacrifice! To thy birth- place go with Svāhā.

column1: eṣa te yajñaḥ yajñapate sahasūktavākaḥ / su vīryaḥ svāhā /
column2: This is thy sacrifice with hole hymnal, Lord of the Rite, Svāhā! and fraught with vigour.

column1: vaṣaṭ dhutebhyaḥ vaṣaṭ a hutebhyaḥ / devāḥ gātu vidaḥ gātum vittvā gātum ita /
column2: Vashat to paid and yet unpaid oblations! Ye Gods who know the way, find and pursue it!

column1: manasaḥ pate imam naḥ divi deveṣu yajñam / svāhā divi svāhā pṛthivyām svāhā antarikṣe svāhā vāte dhām svāhā /
column2: Lord of the Mind, lay this our sacrifice in heaven among the Gods. Svāhā in heaven! Svāhā on earth! Svāhā in air! In wind have I paid offerings. Hail!

column1: sam barhiḥ aktam haviṣā ghṛtena sam indreṇa vasunā sam marudbhiḥ / sam devaiḥ viśva devebhiḥ aktam indram gacchatu haviḥ svāhā /
column2: Balmed is the Grass with butter and libation, with Indra. gracious Lord, and with the Maruts. Hail! let the sacrifice go forth anointed to Indra with the Gods and Visve Devas.

column1: pari stṛṇīhi pari dhehi vedim mā jāmim moṣīḥ amuyā śayānām / hotṛṣadanam haritam hiraṇyayam niṣkāḥ ete yajamānasya loke /
column2: Strew thou the Grass, and spread it on the Altar: rob not the sister who is lying yonder. The Hotar's seat is green and golden: these are gold necklets. in the plaee of him who worships.

column1: paryāvarte duṣvapnyāt pāpāt svapnyāt abhūtyāḥ / brahma aham antaram kṛṇve parā svapna mukhāḥ śucaḥ /
column2: I turn away from evil dream, from dream of sin, from indigence. I make the prayer mine inmost friend. Hence! torturing. dreamy phantasies!

column1: yat svapne annam aśnāmi na prātar adhigamyate / sarvam tat astu me śivam nahi tat dṛṣyate divā /
column2: The food that in a dream I eat is not perceived at early morn. May all that food be blest to me because it is not seen by day.

column1: namaskṛtya dyāvāpṛthivībhyām antarikṣāya mṛtyave / mekṣāmi ūrdhvaḥ tiṣṭhat mā mā hiṃsiṣuḥ īśvarāḥ /
column2: When I have worshipped Heaven and Earth, reverenced Firma- ment and Death, I will make water standing up. Let not the Sovrans injure me.

column1: kaḥ asyāḥ naḥ druhaḥ avadyavatyai ud neṣyati kṣatriyaḥ vasyaḥ ichan / kaḥ yajña kāmaḥ kaḥ u pūrti kāmaḥ kaḥ deveṣu vanute dīrgham āyuḥ /
column2: What princely warrior, seeking higher fortune, will free us from this shameful fiend of mischief? What friend of sacrifice? What guerdon-lover? Who winneth: 'mid the Gods a long existence?

column1: kaḥ pṛśnim dhenum varuṇena dattām atharvane su dughām nitya vatsām / bṛhaspatinā sakhyam juṣaṇaḥ yathāvaśam tanvaḥ kalpayāti //
column2: Who will prepare the dappled Cow, good milker, ne'er without calf, whom Varuna gave Atharvan, And, joying in Brihaspati's alliance, arrange according to his will her body?

column1: apakrāman pauruṣeyāt vṛṇānaḥ daivyam vacaḥ / praṇītīḥ abhyāvartasva viśvebhiḥ sakhibhiḥ saha /
column2: Leaving humanity behind, making the heavenly word thy choice, With all thy friends address thyself to furthering and guiding men.

column1: yat asmṛti cakṛma kim cit agne upārima caraṇe jātavedaḥ / tatas pāhi tvam naḥ pracetaḥ śubhe sakhibhyaḥ amṛta tvam astu naḥ /
column2: Each thoughtless ill that we have done, O Agni, all error in our conduct, Jātavedas! Therefrom do thou, O sapient God, preserve us. May we thy friends, for bliss, have life eternal.

column1: ava divaḥ tārayanti sapta sūryasya raśmayaḥ / āpaḥ samudriyāḥ dhārāḥ tāḥ śalyam asisrasan /
column2: The seven bright beams of Surya bring the waters downward from the sky, The streams of ocean: these have made the sting that pained thee drop away.

column1: yaḥ naḥ stāyat dipsati yaḥ naḥ āvis svaḥ vidvān araṇaḥ vā naḥ agne / pratīcī etu araṇī datvatī tān mā eṣām agne vā astu bhūt mā u apatyam /
column2: Whoso by stealth or openly would harm us, a friend who knows us, or a stranger, Agni! May the strange she-fiend armed with teeth attack them: O Agni, theirs be neither home nor children!

column1: yaḥ naḥ suptān jāgrataḥ vā abhidāsāt tiṣṭhataḥ vā carataḥ jātavedaḥ / vaiśvānareṇa sayujā sajoṣāḥ tān pratīcaḥ niḥ daha jātavedaḥ /
column2: Whoso oppresseth us O Jātavedas, asleep or waking, standing still or moving. Accordant with Vaisvānara thy comrade, O Jātavedas, meet them and consume them.

column1: idam ugrāya babhrave namaḥ yaḥ akṣeṣu tanū vaśī / ghṛtena kalim śikṣāmi sa naḥ mṛḍāti īdṛśe /
column2: My homage to the strong, the brown, the sovran lord among the dice! Butter on Kali I bestow: may he be kind to one like me.

column1: ghṛtam apsarābhyaḥ vaha tvam agne pāṃsūn akṣebhyaḥ sikatāḥ apaḥ ca / yathābhagam havya dātim juṣāṇāḥ madanti devāḥ ubhayāni havyā /
column2: Bear butter to the Apsarases, O Agni, and to the Dice bear dust and sand and water. The Gods delight in both oblations, joying in sacrificial gifts apportioned duly.

column1: apsarasaḥ sadhamādam madanti havirdhānam antarā sūryam ca / tāḥ me hastau sam sṛjantu ghṛtena sapatnam me kitavam randhayantu //
column2: The Apsarases take pleasure in the banquet between the Sun and. the libation-holder. With butter let them fill my hands, and give me, to be my prey, the man who plays against me.

column1: ādinavam pratidīvne ghṛtena asmām abhi kṣara / vṛkṣam iva aśanyā jahi yaḥ asmān pratidīvyati //
column2: Evil be mine opponent's luck! Sprinkle thou butter over us. Strike, as a tree with lightning flash, mine adversary in the game.

column1: yaḥ naḥ dyuve dhanam idam cakāra yaḥ akṣāṇām glahanam śeṣaṇam ca / sa naḥ devaḥ haviḥ idam juṣāṇaḥ gandharvebhiḥ sadhamādam madema /
column2: The God who found for us this wealth for gambling, to cast the dice and count the winning number, May he accept the sacrifice we offer, and with Gandharvas revel in the banquet.

column1: saṃvasavaḥ iti vaḥ nāmadheyam ugraṃpaśyāḥ rāṣṭrabhṛtaḥ hi akṣāḥ / tebhyaḥ vaḥ indavaḥ haviṣā vidhema vayam syāma patayaḥ rayīṇām /
column2: Fellow-inhabitants, such is your title, for Dice with looks of power support dominion. As such with offerings may we serve you, Indus! May we have riches in our own possession.

column1: devān yat nāthitaḥ huve brahmacaryam yat ūṣima / akṣān yat babhrūn ālabhe te naḥ mṛḍantu īdṛśe /
column2: As I invoke the Gods at need, as I have lived in chastity, May these, when I have grasped the Dice, the brown, be kind to one like me.

column1: agne indraḥ ca dāśuṣe hataḥ vṛtrāṇi aprati / ubhā hi vṛtra hantamā /
column2: Resistless, Agni, Indra, smite his foemen for the worshipper, For best foe-slayers are ye both.

column1: yābhyām ajayan svar agre eva yau ātasthatuḥ bhuvanāni viśvā / pra carṣaṇī vṛṣaṇā vajra bāhū agnim indram vṛtra haṇā huve aham /
column2: Agni I call, and Indra, foe-destroyers, swift moving, heroes, Gods who wield the thunder, Through whom they won the light in the beginning, these who have made all worlds their habitation.

column1: upa tvā devaḥ agramīt camasena bṛhaspatiḥ / indra gīrbhiḥ naḥ ā viśa yajamānāya sunvate /
column2: The God Brihaspati hath won thy friendly favour with the cup. With hymns, O Indra, enter us for the juice-pouring worshipper.

column1: indrasya kukṣiḥ asi soma dhānaḥ ātmā devānām uta mānuṣāṇām / iha prajāḥ janaya yāḥ te āsu yāḥ anyatra iha tāḥ te ramantām /
column2: Belly of Indra art thou, Soma-holder! the very soul of Gods and human beings. Here be the sire of offspring, thine here present! Here be they glad in thee who now are elsewhere.

column1: śumbhanī dyāvāpṛthivī antisumne mahivrate / āpaḥ sapta susruvuḥ devīḥ tāḥ naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Radiant with light are Heaven and Earth, whose grace is nigh, whose sway is vast. Seven Goddesses have flowed to us: may they deliver us from woe;

column1: muñcantu mā śapathyāt atha u varuṇyāt uta / atha u yamasya paḍvīśāt viśvasmāt deva kilbiṣāt /
column2: Release me from the curse's bond and plague that comes from Varuna; Free me from Yama's fetter and from every sin against the Gods.

column1: tṛṣṭike tṛṣṭa vandanaḥ ud amūm chindhi tṛṣṭike / yathā kṛta dviṣṭāsaḥ amuṣmai śepyāvate / tṛṣṭā asi tṛṣṭikā viṣā viṣātakī asi / parivṛktā yathā asasi ṛṣabhasya vaśā iva /
column2: Rough Plant, thou rough rude parasite, cut thou that man, O Rough and Rude, That thou mayst hinder from his act that man in all his manly strength. Thou, rugged Plant, art rude and rough, Vishā, Vishātaki art thou. That thou mayest be cast off by him, as by a bull a barren cow.

column1: ā te dade vakṣaṇābhyaḥ ā te aham hṛdayāt dade / ā te mukhasya saṅkāśāt sarvam te varcaḥ ā dade /
column2: I have extracted from thy sides, I have extracted from thy heart, I have extracted from thy face the strength and splendour that were thine.

column1: pra itas yantu vyādhyaḥ pra anudhyāḥ pra u aśastayaḥ / agniḥ rakṣasvinīḥ hantu somaḥ hantu durasyatīḥ /
column2: Let pain and suffering pass away, let cares and curses vanish. hence. Let Agni slay the fiendish hags, Soma kill bags who trouble us.

column1: pra pata itas pāpi lakṣmi naśyetaḥ pra amutas pata / ayasmayena aṅkena dviṣate tvā sajāmasi //
column2: Hence. Evil Fortune! fly away, vanish from this place and from that. We fix thee with an iron hook unto the man who hateth us.

column1: yā mā lakṣmīḥ patayālūḥ ajuṣṭā abhicaskanda vandanā iva vṛkṣam / anyatra asmat savitar tām itas dhāḥ hiraṇya hastaḥ vasu naḥ rarāṇaḥ /
column2: Granting us riches, Savitar! golden-banded, send thou away from us to other regions That Fortune who, flying, abominable, hath, as a creeper climbs• a tree, assailed me.

column1: eka śatam lakṣmyaḥ martyasya sākam tanvā januṣaḥ adhi jātāḥ / tāsām pāpiṣṭhāḥ niḥ itas pra hiṇmaḥ śivāḥ asmabhyam jātavedaḥ niyaccha /
column2: One and a hundred Fortunes all together are at his birth born with a mortal's body. Of these we send away the most unlucky: keep lucky ones for us, O Jātavedas.

column1: etāḥ enāḥ vyākaram khile gāḥ viṣṭhitāḥ iva / ramantām puṇyā lakṣmīḥ yāḥ pāpīḥ tāḥ anīnaśam //
column2: I have disparted these and those like cows who stray on common land. Here let auspicious Fortunes stay: hence have I banished evil ones.

column1: namaḥ rūrāya cyavanāya nodanāya dhṛṣṇave / namaḥ śītāya pūrva kāma kṛtvane /
column2: Homage to him the burning one, shaker, exciter, violent! Homage to him the cold who acts according to his ancient will!

column1: yaḥ anyedyus ubhayadyus abhyeti imam maṇḍūkam / abhi etu avrataḥ /
column2: May he, the lawless one, who comes alternate or two following days, pass over and possess the frog.

column1: ā mandraiḥ indra haribhiḥ yāhi mayūra romabhiḥ / mā tvā ke cit vi yaman vim na pāśinaḥ ati dhanva iva tām ihi //
column2: Come hither, Indra, with bay steeds, joyous, with tails like pea- cock plumes. Let none impede thy way as fowlers stay the bird: pass o'er them as o'er desert lands.

column1: antakāya mṛtyave namaḥ prānāḥ apānāḥ iha te ramantām / iha ayam astu puruṣaḥ saha asunā sūryasya bhāge amṛtasya loke /
column2: Homage to Death the Ender! May thy breathings, inward and outward, still remain within thee. Here stay this man united with his spirit in the Sun's realm, the world of life eternal!

column1: ud enam bhagaḥ agrabhīt ud enam somaḥ aṃśumān / ud enam marutaḥ devāḥ ud indra agnī svastaye /
column2: Bhaga hath lifted up this man, and Soma with his filaments, Indra and Agni, and the Gods the Maruts, raised him up to health.

column1: iha te asuḥ iha prāṇaḥ iha āyuḥ iha te manaḥ / ud tvā nirṛtyāḥ pāśebhyaḥ daivyā vacā bharāmasi //
column2: Here is thy spirit, here thy breath, here is thy life, here is thy soul: By a celestial utterance we raise thee from Destruction's bonds.

column1: ud krāma atas puruṣa mā ava patthāḥ mṛtyoḥ paḍvīṣam avamuñcamānaḥ / mā chitthāḥ asmāt lokāt agneḥ sūryasya saṃdṛśaḥ /
column2: Up from this place, O man, rise! sink not downward, casting away the bonds of Death that hold thee. Be not thou parted from this world, from sight of Agni and the Sun.

column1: tubhyam vātaḥ pavatām mātariśvā tubhyam varṣantu amṛtāni āpaḥ / sūryaḥ te tanve śam tapāti tvām mṛtyuḥ dayatām mā pra meṣṭhāḥ //
column2: Purely for thee breathe Wind and Mātarisvan, and let the Waters rain on thee their nectar. The Sun shall shine with healing on thy body; Death shall have mercy on thee: do not leave us!

column1: udyānam te puruṣa na avayānam jīvātum te dakṣatātim kṛnomi / ā hi roha imam amṛtam sukham ratham atha jirviḥ vidatham ā vadāsi //
column2: Upward must be thy way, O man, not downward: with life and mental vigour I endow thee. Ascend this car eternal, lightly rolling; then full of years shalt thou address the meeting.

column1: mā te manaḥ tatra gāt mā tiras bhūt mā jīvebhyaḥ pra madaḥ mā anu gāḥ pitṝn / viśve devāḥ abhi rakṣantu tvā iha /
column2: Let not thy soul go thither, nor be lost to us: slight not the living, go not where the Fathers are. Let all the Gods retain thee here in safety.

column1: mā gatānām ā dīdhīthāḥ ye nayanti parāvatam / ā roha tamasaḥ jyotiḥ ehi ā te hastau rabhāmahe //
column2: Yearn not for the departed ones, for those who lead men far away. Rise up from darkness into light: come, both thy hands we clasp in ours.

column1: śyāmaḥ ca tvā mā śabalaḥ ca preṣitau yamasya yau pathirakṣī śvānau / arvāṅ ehi mā vi dīdhyaḥ mā atra tiṣṭhaḥ parāṅmanāḥ /
column2: Let not the black dog and the brindled seize thee, two warders of the way sent forth by Yama. Come hither; do not hesitate: with mind averted stay not there.

column1: # mā etam panthām anu gāḥ bhīmaḥ eṣa yena pūrvam neyatha tam bravīmi / tamaḥ etat puruṣa mā pra patthāḥ bhayam parastāt abhayam te arvāk // tamaḥ etat puruṣa mā pra patthāḥ bhayam parastāt abhayam te arvāk // te arvāk // tamaḥ etat puruṣa mā pra patthāḥ bhayam parastāt abhayam te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te arvāk // te ar
column2: Forbear to tread this path, for it is awful: that path I speak of which thou hast not travelled. Enter it not, O man; this way is darkness: forward is danger, hitherward is safety.

column1: rakṣantu tvā agnayaḥ ye apsu antā rakṣatu tvā manuṣyāḥ yam indhate / vaiśvānaraḥ rakṣatu jātavedāḥ divyaḥ tvā mā pra dhāk vidyutā saha /
column2: Thy guardians be the Fires within the Waters, thy guardian be the Fire which men enkindle. Thy guardian be Vaisvānara Jātavedas; let not celestial Fire with lightning burn thee.

column1: mā tvā kravyād abhi maṃstārāt saṃkasukāt cara rakṣatu tvā dyauḥ rakṣatu / pṛthivī sūryaḥ ca tvā rakṣatām candramāḥ ca / antarikṣam rakṣatu deva hetyāḥ //
column2: Let not the Flesh-Consumer plot against thee: depart thou far away from the Destroyer. Be Heaven and Earth and Sun and Moon thy keepers, and from the dart of Gods may Air protect thee.

column1: bodhaḥ ca tvā pratibodhaḥ ca rakṣatām asvapnaḥ ca tvā anavadrāṇaḥ ca rakṣatām / gopāyan ca tvā jāgṛviḥ ca rakṣatām / gopāyan ca tvā jāgṛviḥ ca rakṣatām / gopāyan ca tvā jāgṛviḥ ca rakṣatām /
column2: May Vigilance and Watchfulness protect thee, Sleepless and Slumberless keep guard above thee! Let Guardian and let Wakeful be thy warders.

column1: te tvā rakṣantu te tvā gopāyantu tebhyaḥ namaḥ tebhyaḥ svāhā //
column2: Let these be thy preservers, these thy keepers. All hail to these, to these be lowly worship!

column1: jīvebhyaḥ tvā samude vāyuḥ indraḥ dhātā dadhātu savitā trāyamāṇaḥ / mā tvā prāṇaḥ balam ha āsīt asum te anu hvayāmasi //
column2: May saving Savitar, Vāyu, Indra, Dhātar restore thee to com- munion with the living. Let not thy vigour or thy breath forsake thee: we recall thy life.

column1: mā tvā jambhaḥ saṃhanuḥ mā tamaḥ vidat mā jihvā barhiḥ pramayuḥ kathā syāḥ / ud tvā ādityāḥ vasavaḥ bharantu ud indra agnī svastaye /
column2: Let not the fiend with snapping jaws, nor darkness find thee: tongue, holy grass: how shouldst thou perish? May the Ādityas and the Vasus, Indra and Agni raise thee and to health restore thee.

column1: ud tvā dyauḥ ud pṛthivī ud prajāpatiḥ agrabhīt / ud tvā mṛtyoḥ oṣadhayaḥ soma rājñīḥ apīparan /
column2: The Sky hath raised thee, and the Earth, Prajāpati hath raised thee up. The Plants and Herbs with Soma as their King have rescued thee from Death.

column1: ayam devāḥ iha eva astu ayam mā amutra gāt itas / imam sahasra vīryeṇa mṛtyoḥ ud pārayāmasi //
column2: Here let this man, O Gods, remain: let him not go to yonder world. We rescue him from Mrityu with a charm that hath a thousand powers.

column1: ud tvā mṛtyoḥ apīparam sam dhamantu vayodhasaḥ / mā tvā vyasta keśyaḥ mā tvā agharudaḥ rudan /
column2: I have delivered thee from Death. Strength-givers smelt and fashion thee! Let not she-fiends with wild loose locks, or fearful howlers yell at thee.

column1: āhārṣam avidam tvā punar āgāḥ punarṇavaḥ / sarva aṅga sarvam te cakṣuḥ sarvam āyuḥ ca te avidam /
column2: I have attained and captured thee: thou hast returned restored to youth. Perfect in body: so have I found all thy sight and all thy life.

column1: vi avāt te jyotiḥ abhūt apa tvat tamaḥ akramīt / apa tvat mṛtyum nirṛtim apa yakṣmam ni dadhmasi // // {2}
column2: Life hath breathed on thee; light hath come: darkness hath past away from thee. Far from thee we have buried Death, buried Destruction and: Decline.

column1: ā rabhasva imām amṛtasya śnuṣṭim a chidyamānā jaradaṣṭiḥ astu te / asum te āyuḥ punar ā bharāmi rajaḥ tamaḥ mā upa gāḥ mā pra meṣṭhāḥ // jīvatām jyotiḥ abhyehi arvāṅ ā tvā harāmi śata śāradāya / avamuñcat mṛtyu pāśān aśastim drāghīyaḥ āyuḥ prataram te dadhāmi //
column2: Seize to thyself this trust of life for ever: thine be longevity which nothing shortens. Thy spirit and thy life again I bring thee: die not, nor vanish into mist and darkness. Come to the light of living men, come hither: I draw thee to a life of hundred autumns. Loosing the bonds of Death, the curse that holds thee, I give thee age of very long duration.

column1: vātāt te prānam avidam sūryāt cakṣuḥ aham tava / yat te manaḥ tvayi tat dhārayāmi sam vitsva aṅgaiḥ vada jihvayā ālapan /
column2: Thy breath have I recovered from the Wind, thy vision from the Sun. Thy mind I stablish and secure within thee: feel in thy members,. use thy tongue, conversing.

column1: prāṇena tvā dvipadām catuṣpadām agnim iva jātam abhi sam dhamāmi / namaḥ te mṛtyo cakṣuṣe namaḥ prāṇāya te akaram /
column2: I blow upon thee with the breath of bipeds and quadrupeds, as on a fire new-kindled. To thee, O Death, and to thy sight and breath have I paid reverence.

column1: ayam jīvatu mā mṛtaḥ imam sam īrayāmasi / kṛṇomi asmai bheṣajam mṛtyo mā puruṣam vadhīḥ //
column2: Let this man live, let him not die: we raise him, we recover him. I make for him a healing balm. O Death, forbear to slay this man.

column1: jīvalām naghāriṣām jīvantīm oṣadhīm aham / trāyamāṇām sahamānām sahasvatīm iha huve asmai ariṣṭatātaye //
column2: Here for sound health I invocate a living animating plant, Preserving, queller of disease, victorious, full of power and might.

column1: adhi brūhi mā rabhathāḥ sṛja imam tava eva san sarva hāyāḥ iha astu / bhava aśarvau mṛḍatam śarma yacchatam apasidhya duritam dhattam āyuḥ /
column2: Seize him not, but encourage and release him: here let him stay, though thine, in all his vigour. Bhava and Sarva, pity and protect him: give him full life and drive away misfortunes.

column1: asmai mṛtyo adhi brūhi imam dayasva ud itas ayam etu / ariṣṭaḥ sarva aṅgaḥ su śrut jarasā śata hāyanaḥ ātmanā bhujam aśnutām /
column2: Comfort him, Death, and pity him: let him arise and pass away, Unharmed, with all his members, hearing well, with old, may he through hundred years win profit with his soul.

column1: devānām hetiḥ pari tvā vṛṇaktu pārayāmi tvā rajasaḥ ud tvā mṛtyoḥ apīparam / ārāt agnim kravya adam nirūham jīvātave te paridhim dadhāmi //
column2: May the Gods' missile pass thee by. I bring thee safe from the mist: from death have I preserved thee. Far have I banished flesh-consuming Agni: I place a rampart for thy life's protection.
Saving him from that misty path of thine which cannot be defined. From that descent of thine, O Death, we make for him a shield of prayer.

column1: kṛṇomi te prāṇa apānau jarām mṛtyum dīrgham āyuḥ svasti / vaivasvatena prahitān yama dūtān carataḥ apa sedhāmi sarvān /
column2: I give thee both the acts of breath, health, lengthened life, and death by age. All Yama's messengers who roam around, sent by Vaivasvata, I chase away.

column1: ārāt arātim nirṛtim paras grāhim kravya adaḥ piśācān / rakṣaḥ yat sarvam durbhūtam tat tamaḥ iva apa hanmasi //
column2: Far off we drive Malignity, Destruction, Pisāchas banqueters on flesh, and Grāhi. And all the demon kind, the brood of sin, like darkness, we dispel.

column1: agneḥ ta prānam amṛtāt āyuṣmataḥ vanve jātavedasaḥ / yathā na riṣyāḥ amṛtaḥ sajūs asaḥ tat te kṛṇomi tat u te sam ṛdhyatām /
column2: I win thy life from Agni, from the living everlasting Jātavedas. This I procure for thee, that thou, undying, mayst not suffer harm, that thou mayst be content, that all be well with thee.

column1: śive te stām dyāvāpṛthivī asaṃtāpe abhiśriyau / śam te sūryaḥ ā tapatu śam vātaḥ vātu te hṛde / śivāḥ abhi kṣarantu tvāpaḥ divyāḥ payasvatīḥ /
column2: Gracious to thee be Heaven and Earth, bringing no grief, and drawing nigh! Pleasantly shine the Sun for thee, the Wind blow sweetly to thy heart! Let the celestial Waters full of milk flow happily for thee.

column1: śivāḥ te santu oṣadhayaḥ ud tvā ahārṣam adharasyāḥ uttarām pṛthivīm abhi / tatra tvā ādityau rakṣatām sūryācandramasau ubhā //
column2: Auspicious be the Plants to thee! I have upraised thee, borne thee from the lower to the upper earth: Let the two Sons of Aditi, the Sun and Moon, protect thee there.

column1: yat te vāsaḥ paridhānam yām nīvim kṛṇuṣe tvam / śivam te tanve tat kṛṇmaḥ saṃsparśe adrūkṣṇam astu te /
column2: Whatever robe to cover thee or zone thou makest for thyself, We make it pleasant to thy frame: may it be soft and smooth to touch.

column1: yat kṣureṇa marcayatā su tejasā vaptā vapasi keśa śmaśru / śubham mukham mā naḥ āyuḥ pra moṣīḥ /
column2: When, with a very keen and cleasing razor, our hair and beards thou shavest as a barber, Smoothing our face steal not our vital forces.

column1: śivau te stām vrīhi yavau abalāsau adomadhau / etau yakṣmam vi bādhete etau muñcataḥ aṃhasaḥ / yat aśnāsi yat pibasi dhānyam kṛṣyāḥ payaḥ / yat ādyam yat anādyam sarvam te annam aviṣam kṛṇomi //
column2: Auspicious unto thee be rice and barley, causing no painful sick- ness or consumption, these deliver from calamity. Thy food, thy drink, whate'er they be corn grown by cultivation, milk, Food eatable, uneatable, I make all poisonless for thee.

column1: ahne ca tvā rātraye ca ubhābhyām pari dadmasi / arāyebhyaḥ jighatsubhyaḥ imam me pari rakṣata // // {4}
column2: We give thee over as a charge to Day and Night, in trust to both. Keep him for me from stingy fiends, from those who fain would feed on him.

column1: śatam te ayutam hāyanān dve yuge trīṇi catvāri kṛṇmaḥ / indra agnī viśve devāḥ te anu manyantām a hṛṇīyamānāḥ /
column2: A hundred, yea, ten thousand years we give thee, ages two, three, four. May Indra, Agni, all the Gods, with willing favour look on thee.

column1: śarade tvā hemantāya vasantāya grīṣmāya pari dadmasi / varṣāṇi tubhyam syonāni yeṣu vardhante oṣadhīḥ /
column2: To Autumn we deliver thee, to Winter, Spring and Summer's care. We trust thee with auspicious years wherein the plants and herbs grow up.

column1: mṛtyuḥ īśe dvipadām mṛtyuḥ īśe catuṣpadām / tasmāt tvām mṛtyoḥ gopateḥ ud bharāmi sa mā bibheḥ //
column2: Death is the lord of bipeds, Death is sovran lord of quadrupeds. Away I bear thee from that: Death the ruler: be not thou afraid.

column1: saḥ ariṣṭa na mariṣyasi na mariṣyasi mā bibheḥ / na vai tatra mriyante naḥ yanti adhamam tamaḥ //
column2: Thou, still uninjured, shalt not die: be not afraid; thou shalt not die. Here where I am men do not die or go to lowest depths of gloom.

column1: sarvaḥ vai tatra jīvati gauḥ aśvaḥ puruṣaḥ paśuḥ / yatra idam brahma kriyate paridhiḥ jīvanāya kam / pari tvā pātu samānebhyaḥ abhicārāt sabandhubhyaḥ / amamriḥ bhava amṛtaḥ atijīvaḥ mā te hāsiṣuḥ asavaḥ śarīram /
column2: Here verily all creatures live, the cow, the horse, the man, the beast, Here where this holy prayer is used, a rampart that protecteth life. Let it preserve thee from thy peers, from incantation, from thy friends. Live very long, be healthy, be immortal: let not the vital breath forsake thy body.

column1: ye mṛtyavaḥ eka śatam yāḥ nāṣṭrāḥ atitāryāḥ / muñcantu tasmāt tvām devāḥ agneḥ vaiśvānarāt adhi /
column2: One and a hundred modes of death, dangers that may be over- come, May Gods deliver thee from this when Agni, dear to all men, bids.

column1: agneḥ śarīram asi pārayiṣṇu rakṣaḥ hā asi sapatna hā / atha u amīva cātanaḥ pūtudruḥ nāma bheṣajam // // {5}
column2: Body of Agni prompt to save, slayer of fiends and foes art thou, Yea, banisher of malady, the healing balm called Pūtudru.

column1: rakṣaḥ haṇam vājinam ā jigharmi mitram prathiṣṭham upa yāmi śarma / śiśānaḥ agniḥ kratubhiḥ samiddhaḥ sa naḥ divā sa riṣaḥ pātu naktam /
column2: I balm with oil the mighty demon-slayer, to the most famous friend I come for shelter. Enkindled, sharpened by our rites, may Agni protect us in the day and night from evil.

column1: ayaḥ daṃṣṭraḥ arciṣā yātudhānān upa spṛśa jātavedaḥ samiddhaḥ / ā jihvayā mūradevān rabhasva kravya adaḥ vṛṣṭvā api dhatsva āsan /
column2: O Jātavedas, armed with teeth of iron, enkindled with thy flame, attack the demons. Seize with thy tongue the foolish gods' adorers: rend, put with- in thy mouth the raw-flesh-eaters.

column1: ubhā ubhayāvin upa dhehi daṃṣṭrau hiṃsraḥ śiśānaḥ avaram param ca / uta antarikṣe pari yāhi agne jambhaiḥ sam dhehi abhi yātudhānān /
column2: Apply thy teeth, the upper and the lower, thou who hast both, enkindled and destroying. Roam also in the air, O King, around us, and with thy jaws assail the wicked spirits.

column1: agne tvacam yātudhānasya bhindhi hiṃsra aśaniḥ harasā hantu enam / pra parvāṇi jātavedaḥ śṛṇīhi kravyād kraviṣṇuḥ vi cinotu enam /
column2: Pierce through the Yātudhāna's skin, O Agni; let the destroying dart with fire consume him. Rend his joints, Jātavedas! let the eater of raw flesh, seeking flesh, tear and destroy him.

column1: yatra idānīm paśyasi jātavedaḥ tiṣṭhantam agne uta vā carantam / uta antarikṣe patantam yātudhānam tam astā vidhya śarvā śiśānaḥ /
column2: Where now thou seest, Agni Jātavedas! a Yātudhāna, standing still or roaming. Or one that flieth through the air's mid-region, kindled to fury as an archer pierce him.

column1: yajñaiḥ iṣūḥ saṃnamamānaḥ agne iva ācā śalyām aśanibhiḥ dihānaḥ / tābhiḥ vidhya hṛdaye yātudhānān pratīcaḥ bāhūn prati bhaṅgdhi eṣām /
column2: Bending thy shafts through sacrifices, Agni! dipping thine arrows in the hymn to point them, Pierce to the heart therewith the Yātudhānas, and break their arms uplifted to attack thee.

column1: uta ārabdhān spṛnuhi jātavedaḥ uta ārebhāṇām ṛṣṭibhiḥ yātudhānān / agne pūrvaḥ ni jahi śośucānaḥ āma adaḥ kṣviṅkāḥ tam adantu enīḥ /
column2: Rescue the captives also, Jātavedas! yea, those whom Yātudhā- nas' spears have captured. Strike down that fiend, blazing before him, Agni! Let spotted carrion-eating kites devour him.

column1: iha pra brūhi yatamaḥ saḥ agne yātudhānaḥ yaḥ idam kṛṇoti / tam ā rabhasva samidhā yaviṣṭha nṛ cakṣasaḥ cakṣuṣe randhaya enam /
column2: Here tell this forth, O Agni: whosoever is, he himself, or acteth as, a demon, Grasp him, O thou most youthful, with thy fuel: to the Man- Seer's eye give him as booty.

column1: tīkṣṇena agne cakṣuṣā rakṣa yajñam prāñcam vasubhyaḥ pra naya pracetaḥ / hiṃsram rakṣāṃsi abhi śośucānam mā tvā dabhan yātudhānāḥ nṛ cakṣaḥ /
column2: With keen glance guard the sacrifice, O Agni: thou Sage, con- duct it onward to the Vasus. Let not the fiends, O Man-Beholder, harm thee burning against the Rākshasas to slay them.

column1: nṛ cakṣāḥ rakṣaḥ pari paśya vikṣu tasya trīṇi prati śṛṇīhi agrā / tasya agne pṛṣṭīḥ harasā śṛṇīhi tredhā mūlam yātudhānasya vṛśca / tasya agne pṛṣṭīḥ harasā śṛṇīhi tredhā mūlam yātudhānasya vṛśca // tasya agne pṛṣṭīḥ harasā śṛṇīhi tredhā mūlam yātudhānasya vṛśca // tasya agne pṛṣṭīḥ harasā śṛṇīhi tredhā mūlam yātudhānasya vṛśca // tasya agne pṛṣṭīḥ harasā śṛṇīhi tredhā m
column2: Look on the fiend, 'mid men, as Man-Beholder: rend thou his three extremities in pieces. Demolish with thy flame his ribs, O Agni: the Yātudhāna's root destroy thou triply.

column1: tris yātudhānaḥ prasitim te etu ṛtam yaḥ agne anṛtena hanti / tam arciṣā sphūrjayan jātavedaḥ samakṣam enam gṛṇate ni yuṅgdhi //
column2: Thrice, Agni, let thy noose surround the demon who with his falsehood injures holy Order. Loud roaring with thy flame, Jātavedas, fetter him in the pre- sense of the singer.

column1: yat agne adya mithunā śapātaḥ yat vācaḥ tṛṣṭam janayanta rebhāḥ / manyoḥ manasaḥ śaravyā jāyate yā tayā vidhya hṛdaye yātudhānān /
column2: Agni, what curse the pair this day may utter, what rude rough word the worshippers have spoken, Each arrowy taunt sped from the angry spirit,—pierce to the heart therewith the Yātudhānas.

column1: parā śṛṇīhi tapasā yātudhānān parā agne rakṣaḥ harasā śṛṇīhi / parā arciṣā mūradevān śṛṇīhi parā asutṛpaḥ śośucataḥ śṛṇīhi //
column2: With fervent heat exterminate the demons: destroy the fiends with glow and flame, O Agni. Destroy with fire the foolish gods' adorers: destroy the insatiate fiercely-burning creatures.

column1: parā adya devāḥ vṛjinam śṛṇantu pratyak enam śapathāḥ yantu sṛṣṭāḥ / vācā stenam śaravaḥ ṛchantu marman viśvasya etu prasitim yātudhānaḥ /
column2: May Gods destroy to-day the evil-doer: may uttered curses turn again and strike him. Let arrows pierce the liar in his vitals, and Visva's net enclose the Yātudhāna.

column1: yaḥ pauruṣeyeṇa kraviṣā samaṅkte yaḥ aśvyena paśunā yātudhānaḥ / yaḥ aghnyāyāḥ bharati kṣīram agne teṣām śīrṣāṇi harasā api vṛśca /
column2: The fiend who smears himself with flesh of cattle, with flesh of horses and of human bodies, Who steals the milch-cow's milk away, O Agni,—tear off the heads of such with fiery fury.

column1: viṣam gavām yātudhānāḥ bharantām ā vṛścantām aditaye durevāḥ / para eṇān devaḥ savitā dadātu parā bhāgam oṣadhīnām jayantām /
column2: Let the fiends steal the poison of the cattle: may Aditi cast off the evil-doers. May the God Savitar give them up to ruin, and be their share of herbs and plants denied them.

column1: saṃvatsarīṇam payaḥ usriyāyāḥ tasya mā aśīt yātudhānaḥ nṛ cakṣaḥ / pīyūṣam agne yatamaḥ titṛpsāt tam pratyañcam arciṣā vidhya marmaṇi // sanāt agne mṛṇasi yātudhānān na tvā rakṣāṃsi pṛtanāsu jigyuḥ / sahamūrān anu daha kravya adaḥ mā te hetyāḥ mukṣata daivyāyāḥ // tvam naḥ agne adharāt udaktaḥ tvam paścāt uta rakṣā purastāt / prati tye te ajarāsaḥ tapiṣṭhāḥ agha śaṃsam śośucataḥ dahantu /
column2: The cow gives milk each year, O Man-Beholder: let not the Yātudhāna ever taste it. Agni, if one should glut him with the biestings, pierce with thy flame his vitals as he meets thee. Agni, from days of old thou slayest demons: never have Rākshasas in fight o'ercome thee. Burn up the foolish ones, the flesh-devourers: let none of them escape thy heavenly arrow.

column2: Guard us, O Agni, from above and under, protect us from be- hind and from before us; And may thy flames, most fierce and never wasting, glowing with fervent heat, consume the sinner. From rear, from front, from under, from above us, Agni, pro- tect us as a sage with wisdom. Guard to old age thy friend as friend eternal: O Agni, as im- mortal, guard us mortals.

column1: tat agne cakṣuḥ prati dhehi rebhe śaphārujaḥ yena paśyasi yātudhānān / atharvavat jyotiṣā daivyena satyam dhūrvantam acitam nyoṣa /
column2: Lend thou the worshipper that eye, O Agni, where with thou lookest on the hoof-armed demons. With light celestial in Atharvan's manner burn up the fool who ruins truth with falsehood.

column1: pari tvā agne puram vayam vipram sahasya dhīmahi / dhṛṣat varṇam divedive hantāram bhaṅgurāvataḥ /
column2: We set thee round us as a fort, victorious Agni! thee, a sage, In conquering colour day by day, destroyer of the treacherous foe.

column1: viṣeṇa bhaṅgurāvataḥ prati sma rakṣasaḥ jahi / agne tigmena śociṣā tapuḥ agrābhiḥ arcibhiḥ / vi jyotiṣā bṛhatā bhāti agniḥ āvis viśvāni kṛṇute mahitvā / pra adevīḥ māyāḥ sahate durevāḥ śiśīte śṛṅge rakṣobhyaḥ vinikṣe /
column2: With deadly poison strike thou back the treacherous brood of Rākshasas, O Agni, with thy sharpened glow, with rays that flash with points of flame. Agni shines far and wide with lofty splendour, and by his great- ness makes all things apparent. He conquers godless and malign enchantments, and sharpens both his horns to gore the ogres.

column1: ye te śṛṅge ajare jātavedaḥ tigma hetī brahma saṃśite / tābhyām durhārdam abhidāsantam kimīdinam / pratyañcam arciṣā jātavedaḥ vi nikṣva /
column2: Thy two unwasting horns, O Jātavedas, keen-pointed weapons, sharpened by devotion With these transfix the wicked-souled Kimidin, with fierce flame, Jātavedas! when he meets thee.

column1: indrāsomā tapatam rakṣaḥ ubjatam ni arpayatam vṛṣaṇā tamaḥ vṛdhaḥ / parā śṛṇītam acitaḥ ni oṣatam hatam nudethām ni śiśītam attriṇaḥ / indrāsomā sam agha śaṃsam abhi agham tapuḥ yayastu caruḥ agnimān iva / brahma dviṣe kravya ade ghora cakṣase dveṣaḥ dhattam an avāyam kimīdine /
column2: Bright, radiant, meet to be adored, immortal with refulgent glow, Agni drives Rākshasas away. Indra and Soma, burn, destroy the demon foe! Send downward, O ye Bulls, those who add gloom to gloom. Annihilate the fools, slay them and burn them up: chase them away from us, pierce the voracious fiends.

column1: indrāsomāḥ duṣkṛtaḥ vavre antar anārambhaṇe tamasi pra vidhyatam / yatas na eṣām punar ekaḥ cana udayat tat vām astu sahase manyumat śavaḥ /
column2: Indra and Soma, plunge the wicked in the depth, yea, cast them into darkness that hath no support, So that not one of them may ever thence return: so may your wrathful might prevail and conquer them.

column1: indrāsomā vartayatam divaḥ vadham sam pṛthivyāḥ agha śaṃsāya tarhaṇam / ud takṣatam svaryam parvatebhyaḥ yena rakṣaḥ vāvṛdhānam nijūrvathaḥ / indrāsomāḥ vartayatam divaḥ pari agni taptebhiḥ yuvam aśma hanmabhiḥ / tapuḥ vadhebhiḥ ajarebhiḥ attriṇaḥ ni parśāne vidhyatam yantu nisvaram /
column2: Indra and Soma, hurl your deadly crushing bolt down on the wicked fiend from heaven and from the earth. Yea, fashion from the big clouds your celestial dart wherewith ye burn to death the waxing demon race. Indra and Soma, cast ye downward from the sky your deadly bolts of stone burning with fiery flame, Eternal, scorching darts. Plunge the voracious fiends within the depth, and let them pass without a sound.

column1: indrāsomā pari vām bhūtu viśvatas iyam matiḥ kakṣyā aśvā iva vājinā / yām vām hotrām parihinomi medhayā imā brahmāṇi nṛpatī iva jinvatam /
column2: Indra and Soma, let this hymn control you both, even as the girth encompasses two vigorous steeds The song of praise which I with wisdom offer you. Do ye, as Lords of men, animate these my prayers.

column1: prati smarethām tujayadbhiḥ evaiḥ hatam druhaḥ rakṣasaḥ bhaṅgurāvataḥ / indrāsomāḥ duṣkṛte mā sugam bhūt yaḥ mā kadā cit abhidāsati druhuḥ /
column2: In your impetuous manner think ye both thereon: destroy those evil spirits, kill the treacherous fiends. Indra and Soma, let the wicked have no bliss whoso at any time- attacks and injures us.

column1: yaḥ mā pākena manasā carantam abhicaṣṭe anṛtebhiḥ vacobhiḥ / āpaḥ iva kāśinā samgṛbhītāḥ asan astu asataḥ indra vaktā /
column2: Whoso accuses me with words of falsehood when I pursue my way with guileless spirit, May he, the speaker of untruth, be, Indra! like water which the hollowed hand compresses.

column1: ye pāka śaṃsam viharante evaiḥ ye vā bhadram dūṣayanti svadhābhiḥ / ahaye vā tān pradadātu somaḥ ā vā dadhātu nirṛteḥ upaṣṭhe //
column2: Those who destroy, as is their wont, the simple, and with their evil natures harm the righteous, May Soma give them over to the serpent, or to the lap of Nirriti consign them.

column2: O Agni, whosoever seeks to injure the essence of our food, kine, steeds, or bodies, May he, the adversary, thief, and robber, sink to destruction,. both himself and offspring.

column1: paras saḥ astu tanvā tanā ca tisraḥ pṛthivīḥ adhas astu viśvāḥ / prati śuṣyatu yaśaḥ asya devāḥ yaḥ mā divā dipsati yaḥ ca naktam /
column2: May he be swept away, himself and children; may all the three earths press him down beneath them. May his fair glory, O ye Gods, be blighted, who in the day or night would fain destroy us.

column1: su vijñānam cikituṣe janāya sat ca asat ca vacasī paspṛdhāte / tasyoḥ yat satyam yatarat ṛjīyaḥ tat id somaḥ avati hanti asat /
column2: The prudent finds it easy to distinguish the true and false: their words oppose each other. Of these two that which is the true and honest Soma protects, and brings the false to nothing.

column1: na vai u somaḥ vṛjinam hinoti na kṣatriyam mithuyā dhārayantam / hanti rakṣaḥ hanti āsat vadantam ubhau indrasya prasitau śayāte /
column2: Never doth Soma aid and guide the wicked or him who falsely claims the Warrior's title. He slays the fiend and him who speaks untruly: both lie entan- gled in the noose of Indra.

column1: yadi vā aham anṛta devaḥ asmi mogham vā devām apyūhe agne / kim asmabhyam jātavedaḥ hṛṇīṣe drogha vācaḥ te nirṛtham sacantām /
column2: As if I worshipped deities of falsehood, or thought vain thoughts about the Gods, O Agni! Why art thou angry with us, Jātavedas? Destruction fall on those who lie against thee!

column1: adyā murīya yadi yātudhānaḥ asmi yadi vāyuḥ tatapa puruṣasya / adhā sa vīraiḥ daśabhiḥ vi yūyāḥ yaḥ mā mogham yātudhāna iti āha /
column2: So may I die this day if I have harassed any man's life, or if I be a demon. Yea, may he lose all his ten sons together who with false tongue hath called me Yātudhāna.

column1: yaḥ mā ayātum yātudhāna iti āha yaḥ vā rakṣāḥ śiciḥ asmi iti āha / indraḥ tam hantu mahatā vadhena viśvasya jantoḥ adhamaḥ padīṣṭa /
column2: May Indra slay him with a mighty weapon, and let the vilest of all creatures perish, The fiend who says that he is pure, who calls me a demon though devoid of demon nature.

column1: pra yā jigāti khargalā iva naktam apa druhuḥ tanvam gūhamānā / vavram anantam ava sā padīṣṭia grāvāṇaḥ ghnantu rakṣasaḥ upabdaiḥ /
column2: She too who wanders like an owl at night-time, hiding her body in her guile and malice, May she fall downward into endless caverns. May press-stones with loud ring destroy the demons.

column1: vi tiṣṭhadhvam marutaḥ vikṣu ichata gṛbhāyata rakṣasaḥ sam pinaṣṭan / vayaḥ ye bhūtvā patayanti naktabhiḥ ye vā ripaḥ dadhire deve adhvare /
column2: Spread out, ye Maruts, search among the people: seize ye and grind the Rākshasas to pieces, Who fly abroad, transformed to birds, at night-time, and sully and pollute our holy worship.

column2: Hurl down from heaven thy bolt of stone, O Indra: sharpen it, Maghavan, made keen by Soma. Forward, behind, and from above and under, smite down the demons with thy rocky weapon. They fly, the demon dogs, and, bent on mischief, fain would they harm indomitable Indra. Sakra makes sharp his weapon for the wicked: now let him cast his bolt at fiendish wizards.

column1: indraḥ yātūnām abhavat parāśaraḥ havirmathīnām abhi āvivāsatām / abhi id u śakraḥ paraśuḥ yathā vanam pātrā iva bhindan sataḥ etu rakṣasaḥ /
column2: Indra hath ever been the fiends' destroyer who spoil oblations of the Gods' invokers. Yea, Sakra, like an axe that splits the timber, assails and sma- shes them like earthen vessels.

column1: ulūka yātum śuśulūka yātum jahi śva yātum uta koka yātum / suparṇa yātum uta gṛdhra yātum dṛṣadā iva pra mṛṇa rakṣaḥ indra /
column2: Destroy the fiend shaped like an owl or owlet, destroy him in. the form of dog or cuckoo. Destroy him shaped as eagle or as vulture: as with a stone, O Indra, crush the demon.

column1: mā naḥ rakṣaḥ abhi naṭ yātumāvat apocchantu mithunāḥ ye kimīdinaḥ / pṛthivī naḥ pārthivāt pātu aṃhasaḥ antarikṣam divyāt pātu asmān /
column2: Let not the fiend of witchcraft-workers reach us: may Dawn. drive off the couples of Kimidins. Earth keep us safe from earthly woe and trouble! From grief that comes from heaven Mid-air preserve us!

column1: indra jahi pumāṃsam yātudhānam uta striyam māyayā śāśadānām / vigrīvāsaḥ mūradevāḥ ṛdantu mā te dṛśan sūryam uccarantam / # prati cakṣva vi cakṣva indraḥ ca soma jāgṛtam / rakṣobhyaḥ vadham asyatam aśanim yātumadbhyaḥ // // / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / / /
column2: Indra destroy the demon, male and female, joying and triumph- ing in arts of magic! Let the fools' gods with bent necks fall and perish, and see no. more the Sun when he arises. Look, each one, hither, look around. Indra and Soma, watch ye well. Cast forth your weapon at the fiends: against the sorcerers hurl your bolt.

column1: ayam pratisaraḥ maṇiḥ vīraḥ vīrāya badhyate / vīryavān sapatna hā śūra vīraḥ paripāṇaḥ su maṅgalaḥ / ayam maṇiḥ sapatna hā su vīraḥ sahasvān vājī sahamānaḥ ugraḥ / pratyak kṛtyā dūṣayan eti vīraḥ /
column2: Upon the strong is bound the strong, this magic cord, this Amu- let, Potent, foe-slayer, served by valiant heroes, happy and fortu- nate defence. This Charm, foe-slayer, served by many heroes, strong, power- ful, victorious, and mighty, goes bravely forth to meet and ruin witchcraft.

column1: anena indraḥ maṇinā vṛtram ahan anena asurān parābhāvayat manīṣī / anena ajayat dyāvāpṛthivī ubhe ime anena ajayat pradiśaḥ catasraḥ /
column2: With this same Amulet wise Indra routed the Asuras, with this he slaughtered Vritra, With this he won this pair, both Earth and Heaven, and made the sky's four regions his possession.

column1: ayam srāktyaḥ maṇiḥ pratīvartaḥ pratisaraḥ / ojasvān vimṛdhaḥ vaśī saḥ asmān pātu sarvatas /
column2: May this encircling magic cord, this Amulet of Srāktya wood, Mighty, subduing enemies, keep us secure on every side.

column1: tat agniḥ āha tat u somaḥ āha bṛhaspatiḥ savitā tat indraḥ / te me devāḥ purohitāḥ pratīcīḥ kṛtyāḥ pratisaraiḥ ajantu //
column2: This Agni hath declared, Soma declared it, Brihaspati, and Savitar, and Indra. So may these Gods whom I have set before me oppose with saving charms and banish witchcraft.

column1: antar dadhe dyāvāpṛthivī uta ahar uta sūryam / te me devāḥ purohitāḥ pratīcīḥ kṛtyāḥ pratisaraiḥ ajantu //
column2: I have obscured the heaven and earth, yea, and the daylight and the sun. So may these Gods whom I have set before me oppose with saving charms and banish witchcraft.

column1: ye srāktyam maṇim janāḥ varmāṇi kṛṇvate / sūryaḥ iva divam āruhya vi kṛtyā bādhate vaśī /
column2: Whoever for his armour takes an amulet of the Srāktya tree, Like the Sun risen up to heaven, quells witchcraft with superior might.

column1: srāktyena maṇinā ṛṣiṇā iva manīṣiṇā / ajaiṣam sarvāḥ pṛtanāḥ vi mṛdhaḥ hanmi rakṣasaḥ /
column2: With Amulet of Srāktya wood, as with a thoughtful Rishi's aid, In every fight have I prevailed; I smite the foes and Rākshasas.

column1: yāḥ kṛtyāḥ āṅgirasīḥ yāḥ kṛtyāḥ āsurīḥ yāḥ / kṛtyāḥ svayaṃkṛtāḥ yāḥ u ca anyebhiḥ ābhṛtāḥ / ubhayīḥ tāḥ parā yantu parāvataḥ navatim nāvyāḥ ati /
column2: All witchcraft of Angirases,"all witchcraft wrought by Asuras, All witchcraft self-originate, and all that others have prepared, May these depart to both remotest spaces, past ninety ample water-floods.

column1: asmai maṇim varma badhnantu devāḥ indraḥ viṣṇuḥ savitā rudraḥ agniḥ / prajāpatiḥ parameṣṭhī virāj vaiśvānaraḥ ṛṣayaḥ ca sarve / / / /
column2: May the Gods bind the Charm on him for armour, Indra, and Vishnu, Savitar Rudra, Agni, Prajāpati, sublimest Parameshlhin, Virāj, Vaisvānara, and all the Rishis.

column1: uttamaḥ asi oṣadhīnām anaḍvān jagatām iva vyāghraḥ śvapadām iva / yam aichāma avidāma tam pratispāśanam antitam /
column2: Thou art the chief of all the plants, even as a bull among the beasts. A tiger of the beasts of prey. Him whom we sought for have we found, him lying near in wait for us.

column1: saḥ id vyāghraḥ bhavati atha u siṃhaḥ atha u vṛṣā / atha u sapatna karśanaḥ yaḥ bibharti imam maṇim //
column2: A tiger verily is he, he is a lion, and a bull, Subduer of his foes is he, the man who wears this Amulet.

column1: na enam ghnanti apsarasaḥ na gandharvāḥ na martyāḥ / sarvāḥ diśaḥ vi rājati yaḥ bibharti imam maṇim //
column2: No mortal beings slay him, no Gāndharvas, no Apsarases; O'er all the regions he is king, the man who wears this Amulet.

column1: kaśyapaḥ tvām asṛjata kaśyapaḥ tvā sam airayat / abibhar tvā indraḥ mānuṣe bibhrat saṃśreṣiṇe ajayat / maṇim sahasra vīryam varma devāḥ akṛṇvata /
column2: Kasyapa formed and fashioned thee, Kasyapa raised and sent thee forth. Indra wore thee, and, wearing thee, won in the wrestling-match with man. The Amulet of boundless might the Gods have made a coat of mail.

column1: yaḥ tvā kṛtyābhiḥ yaḥ tvā dīkṣābhiḥ yajñaiḥ yaḥ tvā jighāṃsati / pratyak tvam indra tam jahi vajreṇa śata parvaṇā /
column2: Whoever would destroy thee with Dikshā-rites, sacrifices, spells, Meet him and smite him, Indra! with thy hundred-knotted thunderbolt.

column1: ayam id vai pratīvartaḥ ojasvān saṃjayaḥ maṇiḥ / prajām dhanam ca rakṣatu paripāṇaḥ su maṅgalaḥ /
column2: Verily let this Amulet, circular, potent, conquering, Happy and fortunate defence, preserve thy children and thy wealth.

column1: asapatnam naḥ adharāt asapatnam naḥ uttarāt / indra asapatnam naḥ paścāt jyotiḥ śūra puras kṛdhi //
column2: Brave Indra, set before us light, peace and security from below, Peace and security from above, peace and security from behind.

column1: varma me dyāvāpṛthivī varma ahar varma sūryaḥ / varma me indraḥ ca agniḥ ca varma dhātā dadhātu me /
column2: My coat of mail is Heaven and Earth, my coat of mail is Day and Sun: A coat of mail may Indra and Agni and Dhātar grant to me.

column1: aindrāgnam varma bahulam yat ugram viśve devāḥ na atividhyanti sarve / tat me tanvam trāyatām sarvatas bṛhat āyuṣmān jaradaṣṭiḥ yathā asāni //
column2: Not all the Gods may pierce, all leagued together, the vast strong shield which Indra gives, and Agni. May that great shield on all sides guard my body, that to full old my life may be extended.

column1: ā mārukṣat deva maṇiḥ mahyāḥ ariṣṭatātaye / imam methim abhisaṃviśadhvam tanūpānam tri varūtham ojase /

column2: All that man's sin whose food they do not eat remains unblot- ted out.

column1: sarvadā vai eṣa yukta grāvā ārdra pavitraḥ vitata adhvaraḥ āhṛta yajñakratuḥ yaḥ upaharati //
column2: The man who supplies food hath always pressing stones adjusted, a wet Soma filter, well prepared religious rites, and mental power to complete the arranged sacrifice.

column1: prājāpatyaḥ vai etasya yajñaḥ vitataḥ yaḥ upaharati //
column2: The arranged sacrifice of the man who offers food is a sacrifice to Prajāpati.

column1: prajāpateḥ vai eṣa vikramān anuvikramate yaḥ upaharati //
column2: The man who offers food follows the steps of Prajāpati.

column1: # saḥ āhavanīyaḥ yaḥ veśmani saḥ gārhapatyaḥ yasmin pacanti saḥ dakṣiṇāgniḥ // | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | iṣṭam ca vai eṣa pūrtam ca gṛhāṇām aśnāti yaḥ pūrvaḥ atitheḥ aśnāti //
column2: The fire of the guests is the Āhavaniya, the fire in the dwelling is the Gārhapatya, that whereon they cook food is the South- ern Sacrificial Fire. Now that man who eats before the guest eats up the sacrifice and the merit of the house.

column1: payaḥ ca vai eṣa rasam ca gṛhāṇām aśnāti yaḥ pūrvaḥ atitheḥ aśnāti //
column2: He devours the milk and the sap: And the vigour and prosperity.

column1: ūrjām ca vai eṣa sphātim ca gṛhāṇām aśnāti yaḥ pūrvaḥ atitheḥ aśnāti // prajām vai eṣa paśūn ca gṛhāṇām aśnāti yaḥ pūrvaḥ atitheḥ aśnāti //
column2: And the progeny and the cattle: And the fame and reputation. The man who eats before the guest eats up the glory and the understanding of the house.

column1: śriyam vai eṣa saṃvidam ca gṛhāṇām aśnāti yaḥ pūrvaḥ atitheḥ aśnāti // eṣa vai atithiḥ yat śrotriyaḥ tasmāt pūrvaḥ na aśnīyāt // aśitāvati atithau aśnīyāt yajñasya sātma tvāya yajñasya a vichedāya tat vratam //
column2: The man should not eat before the guest who is a Brāhman versed in holy lore. When the guest hath eaten he should eat. This is the rule for the animation of the sacrifice and the preservation of its continuity.

column1: etat vai u svādīyaḥ yat adhigavam kṣīram vā māṃsam vā tat eva na aśnīyāt // // _
column2: Now the sweetest portion, the produce of the cow, milk, or flesh, that verily he should not eat.

column1: sa yaḥ evam vidvān kṣīram upasicya upaharati / yāvat agniṣṭomena iṣṭvā su samṛddhena avarunddhe tāvat enena ava runddhe / sa yaḥ evam vidvān sarpiḥ upasicya upaharati / yāvat atirātreṇa iṣṭvā su samṛddhena avarunddhe tāvat enena ava runddhe / sa yaḥ evam vidvān madhūpasicya upaharati / yāvat sattra sadyena iṣṭvā su samṛddhena avarunddhe tāvat enena ava runddhe /
column2: The man who having this knowledge pours out milk and offers it wins for himself as much thereby as he gains by the perfor- mance of a very successful Agnishtoma sacrifice. The man who having this knowledge pours out clarified butter and offers it wins for himself thereby as much as he gains by the performance of a very successful Atirātra sacrifice. He who pours out mead and offers it wins for himself thereby as much as he gains by the performance of a very successful Sattrasadya sacrifice.

column1: sa yaḥ evam vidvān māṃsam upasicya upaharati / yāvat dvādaśa ahena iṣṭvā su samṛddhena avarunddhe tāvat enena ava runddhe /
column2: He who having this knowledge besprinkles flesh and offers it wins for himself thereby as much as he gains by the perfor- mance of a very successful Twelve-Day sacrifice.

column2: The man who having this knowledge pours out water and offers it obtains a resting-place for the procreation of living beings and becomes dear to living beings, even the man who having this knowledge pours out water and offers it.

column1: tasmai uṣāḥ hiṅ kṛṇoti savitā pra stauti / bṛhaspatiḥ ūrjayā ud gāyati tvaṣṭā puṣṭyā prati harati viśve devāḥ nidhanam / nidhanam bhūtyāḥ prajāyāḥ paśūnām bhavati yaḥ evam veda //
column2: For him Dawn murmurs, and Savitar sings the prelude; Brihas- pati chants with vigour, and Tvashtar joins in with increase; the Visve Devāh take up conclusion. He who hath this know- ledge is the abiding-place of welfare, of progeny, and of cattle.

column1: tasmai udyan sūryaḥ hiṅ kṛṇoti saṃgavaḥ pra stauti / madhyandinaḥ ud gāyati aparāhṇaḥ prati harati astaṃyat nidhanam / nidhanam bhūtyāḥ prajāyāḥ paśūnām bhavati yaḥ evam veda / tasmai abhraḥ bhavan hiṅ kṛṇoti stanayan pra stauti / vidyotamānaḥ prati harati varṣan ud gāyati udgṛhṇan nidhanam / nidhanam bhūtyāḥ prajāyāḥ paśūnām bhavati yaḥ evam veda / # atithīn prati paśyati hiṅ kṛṇoti abhi vadati pra stauti udakam yācati ud gāyati / upa harati prati harati ucchiṣṭam nidhanam / nidhanam bhūtyāḥ prajāyāḥ paśūnām bhavati yaḥ evam veda / / / / yaḥ evam veda / / / taḥ evam veda / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda / / / / taḥ evam veda / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda / / / | evam veda /
column2: For him the rising Sun murmurs, and Early Morning sings the prelude; Noon chants the psalm, Afternoon joins in; the setting Sun takes up the conclusion. He who hath this know- ledge is the abiding place of welfare, of progeny, and of cattle. For him the Rain-cloud murmurs when present, sings the pre- lude when thundering, joins in when lightening, chants the psalm when raining, and takes up the conclusion when it stays the downpour. He who hath this knowledge is the abiding- place of welfare, of progeny, and of cattle. He looks at the guests, he utters a gentle sound; he speaks, he signs the prelude; he calls for water, he chants the psalm; he offers the residue of the sacrifice, he takes up the conclusion.

column1: yat kṣattāram hvayati ā śrāvayati eva tat // yat pratiśṛṇoti pratyāśrāvayati eva tat //
column2: He (the door-keeper) pronounces the sacrificial formula in his answer to what he hears.

column1: yat pariveṣṭāraḥ pātra hastāḥ pūrve ca apare ca prapadyante camasa adhvaryavaḥ eva te //
column2: When the attendants with vessels in their hands, foremost and hindmost, come in, they are just the priests who manage the Soma cups.

column1: teṣām na kaḥ cana a hotā //
column2: Not one of them is incompetent to sacrifice.

column1: yat vai atithi patiḥ atithīn pariviṣya gṛhān upodaiti avabhṛtham eva tat upāvaiti // yat sabhāgayati dakṣiṇāḥ sabhāgayati yat anutiṣṭhate udavasyati eva tat //
column2: Or if the host, having offered food to his guest, goes up to the house, he virtually enters the bath of purification. When he distributes food he distributes priestly fees; what he performs he asks as favour.

column1: saḥ upahūtaḥ pṛthivyām bhakṣayati upahūtaḥ tasmin yat pṛthivyām viśva rūpam //
column2: He having been invited on earth, regales, invited in that, which wears all various forms on earth.

column1: saḥ upahūtaḥ antarikṣe bhakṣayati upahūtaḥ tasmin yat divi viśva rūpam // saḥ upahūtaḥ divi bhakṣayati upahūtaḥ tasmin yat divi viśva rūpam // saḥ upahūtaḥ deveṣu bhakṣayati upahūtaḥ tasmin yat divi viśva rūpam //
column2: He having been invited in the sky, regales, invited, in that which wears all various forms in the sky. He, having been invited among the gods, regales, invited in that which wears all various forms among the Gods.

column1: saḥ upahūtaḥ lokeṣu bhakṣayati upahūtaḥ tasmin yat divi viśva rūpam //
column2: He, having been invited in the worlds, regales, invited, in that which wears all various forms in the worlds.

column1: saḥ upahūtaḥ upahūtaḥ //
column2: He, having been invited hath been invited.

column1: āpnoti imam lokam āpnoti amum //
column2: He gains this world and the world yonder.
He who hath this knowledge wins the luminous spheres.

column1: prajāpatiḥ ca parameṣṭhī ca śṛṅge indraḥ śiraḥ agniḥ lalāṭam yamaḥ kṛkāṭam /
column2: Prajapati and Parameshthin are the two horns, Indra is the head, Agni the forehead, Yama the joint of the neck.

column1: somaḥ rājā mastiṣkaḥ dyauḥ uttarahanuḥ pṛthivī adharahanuḥ //
column2: King Soma is the brain, Sky is the upper jaw, Earth is the lower jaw.

column1: vidyut jihvā marutaḥ dantāḥ revatiḥ grīvāḥ kṛttikā skandhāḥ gharmaḥ vahaḥ //
column2: Lightning is the tongue, the Maruts are the teeth, Revati is the neck, the Krittikās are the shoulders, the Gharma s the shoulder-bar.

column1: viśvam vāyuḥ svargaḥ lokaḥ kṛṣṇadram vidharaṇī niveṣyaḥ //
column2: His universe is Vāyu, Svarga is his world, Krishpadram is the tendons and Vertebrae.

column1: śyenaḥ krotaḥ antarikṣam pājasyam bṛhaspatiḥ kakud bṛhatīḥ kīkasāḥ /
column2: The Syena ceremony is the breast, Air is the region of the belly,. Brihaspati is the hump, Brihatī the breast-bone and cartilages of the ribs.

column1: devānām patnīḥ pṛṣṭayaḥ upasadaḥ parśavaḥ //
column2: The consorts of the Gods are the ribs, the attendants are ribs.

column1: mitraḥ ca varuṇaḥ ca aṃsau tvaṣṭā ca aryamā ca doṣaṇī mahādevaḥ bāhū //
column2: Mitra and Varuna are the shoulder-blades. Tvashtar and Arya- man the fore-arms, Mahādeva is the arms.

column1: indrāṇī bhasat vāyuḥ pucham pavamānaḥ bālāḥ //
column2: Indrāni is the hinder parts, Vāyu the tail, Pavamāna the hair.

column1: brahma ca kṣatram ca śroṇī balam ūrū //
column2: Priestly rank and princely power are the hips, and strength is. the thigh.

column1: dhātā ca savitā ca aṣṭhīvantau jaṅghā gandharvāḥ apsarasaḥ kuṣṭhikāḥ aditiḥ śaphāḥ //
column2: Dhātar and Savitar are the two knee-bones, the Gandharvas are the legs the Apsarases are bits of the feet, Aditi is the hooves.

column1: cetaḥ hṛdayam yakṛt medhā vratam purītat //
column2: Thought is the heart, intelligence is the liver, law the pericar- dium.

column1: kṣudh kukṣiḥ irā vaniṣṭhuḥ parvatāḥ plāśayaḥ // krodhaḥ vṛkkau manyuḥ āṇḍau prajā śepaḥ //
column2: Hunger is the belly, refreshing drink is the rectum, mountains. are the inward parts. Wrath is the kidneys, anger the testes, offspring the generative organ.

column1: nadī sūtrī varṣasya patayaḥ stanā stanayitnuḥ ūdhar // viśva vyacāḥ carma oṣadhayaḥ lomāni nakṣatrāṇi rūpam //
column2: The river is the womb, the Lords of the Rain are the breasts,. the thunder is the udder. The All-embracing (Aditi) is the hide, the herbs are her hair,. and the Lunar Mansions her form.

column1: deva janāḥ gudāḥ manuṣyāḥ āntrāṇi atrāḥ udaram //
column2: The hosts of Gods are her entrails, man are her bowels, and demons her abdomen.

column1: rakṣāṃsi lohitam itarajanā ūbadhyam //
column2: Rākshasas are the blood, the Other Folk are the contents of the Stomach.

column1: abhram pībaḥ majjā nidhanam //
column2: The rain-cloud is her fat, her resting-place her marrow.

column1: agniḥ āsīnaḥ utthitaḥ aśvinā //
column2: Sitting he is Agni, when he hath stood up he is the Asvins.

column1: indraḥ prāṅ tiṣṭhan dakṣiṇā tiṣṭhan yamaḥ //
column2: Standing east-wards he is Indra, standing southwards, Yama.

column1: pratyaṅ tiṣṭhan dhātā udaṅ tiṣṭhan savitā //
column2: Standing westwards he is Dhātar, standing northwards Savitar.

column1: tṛṇāni prāptaḥ somaḥ rājā //
column2: When he hath got his grass he is King Soma.

column1: mitra īkṣamāṇaḥ āvṛttaḥ ānandaḥ //
column2: He is Mitra when he looks about him, and when he hath turned round he is joy.

column1: yujyamānaḥ vaiśvadevaḥ yuktaḥ prajāpatiḥ vimuktaḥ sarvam //
column2: When he is yoking he belongs to the All-Gods, when yoked he is Prajāpati, when unyoked he is All.

column1: etat vai viśva rūpam sarva rūpam go rūpam /
column2: This verily is omniform, wearing all forms, bovine-formed.

column1: # | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | śīrṣaktim śīrṣa āmayam karṇa śūlam vilohitam / sarvam śīrṣanyam te rogam bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe / karṇābhyām te kaṅkūṣebhyaḥ karṇa śūlam visalpakam / sarvam śīrṣanyam te rogam bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe /
column2: Each pain and ache that racks the head, earache, and erysipelas,. All malady that wrings thy brow we charm away with this our spell. From both thine ears, from parts thereof, thine earache, and the throbbing pain, All malady that wrings thy brow we charm away with this our spell. So that Consumption may depart forth from thine ears and from. thy mouth, All malady that wrings thy brow we charm away with this our spell.

column1: yasya hetoḥ pracyavate yakṣmaḥ karṇataḥ āsyataḥ / sarvam śīrṣanyam te rogam bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe / yaḥ kṛṇoti pramotam andham kṛṇoti pūruṣam / sarvam śīrṣanyam te rogam bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe / aṅgabhedam aṅgajvaram viśvāṅgyam visalpakam / sarvam śīrṣanyam te rogam bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe /
column2: The malady that makes one deaf, the malady that makes one blind, All malady that wrings thy brow we charm away with this our spell. The throbbing pain in all thy limbs that rends thy frame with fever-throes, All malady that wrings thy brow we charm away with this our spell.

column1: yasya bhīmaḥ pratīkāśaḥ udvepayati pūruṣam / takmānam viśva śāradam bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe //
column2: The malady whose awful look makes a man quiver with alarm, Fever whom every Autumn brings we charm away with this our spell.

column1: yaḥ ūrū anusarpati atha u eti gavīnike / yakṣmam te antar aṅgebhyaḥ bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe /
column2: Disease that creeps about the thighs and, after, reaches both the groins, Consumption from thine inward parts we charm away with this our spell.

column1: yadi kāmāt apakāmāt dhṛdayāt jāyate pari / hṛdaḥ balāsam aṅgebhyaḥ bahis niḥ mantrayāmahe /
column2: If the disease originates from love, from hatred, from the heart, Forth from the heart and from the limbs we charm the wasting malady.

column1: bahis bilam niḥ dravatu kāhā bāham tava udarāt / yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat / udarāt te klomnaḥ nābhyāḥ hṛdayāt adhi / yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat / yāḥ sīmānam virujanti mūrdhānam prati arṣanīḥ / a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam /
column2: The yellow Jaundice from thy limbs, and Colic from the parts within, And Phthisis from thine inward soul we charm away with this our spell. Let wasting malady turn to dust, become the water of disease. I have evoked the poison-taint of all Consumptions out of thee.

column1: yāḥ tiraścīḥ uparṣanti arṣaṇīḥ vakṣaṇāsu te / a hiṃsantīḥ anāmayāḥ niḥ dravantu bahis bilam /
column2: Forth from the hollow let it run, and rumbling sounds from thine inside. I have evoked the poison-taint of all Consumptions out of thee.

column1: ye aṅgāni madayanti yakṣmāsaḥ ropaṇāḥ tava / yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat / visalpasya vidradhasya vātīkārasya vālajeḥ / yakṣmāṇām sarveṣām viṣam niḥ avocam aham tvat / pādābhyām te jānubhyām śroṇibhyām pari bhaṃsasaḥ / anūkāt arṣaṇīḥ uṣṇihābhyaḥ śīrṣṇaḥ rogam anīnaśam /
column2: Forth from thy belly and thy lungs, forth from thy navel and thy heart. I have evoked the poison taint of all Consumptions out of thee. The penetrating stabs of pain which rend asunder crown and head, Let them depart and pass away, free from disease and harming not.

column1: tisraḥ matṝḥ trīn pitṝn bibhrat ekaḥ urdhvaḥ tasthau na īm ava glāpayanta / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva vidnām / / / mantrayante divaḥ amuṣya pṛṣṭhe viśva vidaḥ vācam aviśva
column2: The pangs that stab the heart and reach the breast-bone and connected parts, Let them depart and pass away, free from disease and harming not. The stabs that penetrate the sides and pierce their way along the ribs, Let them depart and pass away, free from disease and harming not. The penetrating pangs that pierce thy stomach as they shoot across, Let them depart and pass away, free from disease and harming not.

column1: pañca are cakre parivartamāne yasmin ātasthuḥ bhuvanāni viśvā / tasya na akṣaḥ tapyate bhūri bhāraḥ sanāt eva na chidyate sanābhiḥ //
column2: The pains that through the bowels creep, disordering the inward parts, Let them depart and pass away, free from disease and harming not.

column1: ye arvāñcaḥ tām u parācaḥ āhuḥ ye parāñcaḥ tām u arvācaḥ āhuḥ / indraḥ ca yā cakrathuḥ soma tāni dhurā na yuktāḥ rajasaḥ vahanti //
column2: The pains that suck the marrow out, and rend and tear the bones apart, May they speed forth and pass away, free from disease and harming not.

column1: yat gāyatre adhi gāyatram āhitam traiṣṭubham vā traiṣṭubhāt niratakṣata / yat vā jagat jagati āhitam padam ye id tat viduḥ te amṛta tvam ānuśuḥ // gāyatreṇa prati mimīte arkam arkeṇa sāma traiṣṭubhena vākam / vākena vākam dvipadā catuṣpadā akṣareṇa mimate sapta vāṇīḥ /
column2: Consumptions with their Colic pains which make thy limbs insensible I have evoked the poison-taint of all Consumptions out of thee. Of piercing pain, of abscesses, rheumatic ache, ophthalmia— I have evoked the poison-taint of all Consumptions out of thee.

column1: apaśyam gopām a nipadyamānam ā ca parā ca pathibhiḥ carantam / sa sadhrīcīḥ sa viṣūcīḥ vasānaḥ ā varīvarti bhuvaneṣu antar /
column2: I have dispelled the piercing pains from feet, knees, hips, and hinder parts, And spine, and from the neck and nape the malady that racked the head.

column1: kṛṣṇam niyānam harayaḥ suparṇāḥ apaḥ vasānāḥ divam ud patanti / tam āvavṛtran sadanāt ṛtasya āt id ghṛtena pṛthivīm vi ūduḥ / apād eti prathamā padvatīnām kaḥ tat vām mitrāvaruṇā ciketa / garbhaḥ bhāram bharati ā cit asyāḥ ṛtam piparti anṛtam ni pāti /
column2: Sound are the skull-bones of thy head and thy heart's beat is regular. Thou, Sun, arising with thy beams hast chased away the head's disease, hast stilled the pain that racked the limbs. Afar let her depart: away we drive her whom, made with hands, all-beautiful, Skilled men prepare and fashion like a bride amid her nuptial train.

column1: śīrṣaṇvatī nasvatī karṇiṇī kṛtyā kṛtā saṃbhṛtā viśva rūpā / sārāt etu apa nudāmaḥ enām /
column2: Complete, with head and nose and ears, all-beauteous, wrought with magic skill Afar let her depart: away we drive her.

column1: śūdra kṛtā rāja kṛtā strī kṛtā brahmabhiḥ kṛtā / jāyā patyā nuttā iva kartāram bandhu ṛchatu //
column2: Made by a Sidra or a Prince, by priests or women let her go. Back to her maker as her kin, like a dame banished by her lord.

column1: anayā aham oṣadhyā sarvāḥ kṛtyāḥ adūduṣam / yām kṣetre cakruḥ yām goṣu yām vā te puruṣeṣu /
column2: I with this salutary herb have ruined all their magic arts, The spell which they have cast upon thy field, thy cattle, or thy men.

column1: agham astu agha kṛte śapathaḥ śapathīyate / pratyak pratiprahiṇmaḥ yathā kṛtyā kṛtam hanat /
column2: Ill fall on him who doeth ill, on him who curseth fall the curse! We drive her back that she may slay the man who wrought the witchery.

column1: pratīcīnaḥ āṅgirasaḥ adhyakṣaḥ naḥ purohitaḥ / pratīcīḥ kṛtyāḥ ākṛtya amūn kṛtyākṛtaḥ jahi //
column2: Against her comes the Angirasa, the Priest whose eye is over us. Turn back all witcheries and slay those practisers of magic arts.
