column2: To this we give apportioned food, clarified butter, wine, and meath. May it provide each boon for us as doth a father for his sons. Again, again, from morn to morn, having approached the deities.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ maṇim phālam ghṛtaścutam ugram kadhiram ojase / tam agniḥ prati amuñcata saḥ asmai duhe ājyam bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ maṇim phālam ghṛtaścutam ugram kadhiram ojase / tam indraḥ prati amuñcata ojase vīryāya kam / saḥ asmai balam id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi //
column2: The Charm Brihaspati hath bound, the fatness-dropping citron- wood, the potent Khadira for strength, This Agni hath put on: it yields clarified butter for this man. Again, again, from morn to morn. With this subdue thine enemies. The Charm Brihaspati hath bound, the fatness-dropping citron- wood, the potent Khadira, for strength, This Charm hath Indra put on him for power and manly puissance. It yieldeth strength to strengthen him, again, again, from morn to morn, having approached the deities.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ maṇim phālam ghṛtaścutam ugram kadhiram ojase / tam somaḥ prati amuñcata mahe śrotrāya cakṣase / saḥ asmai varcaḥ id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ maṇim phālam ghṛtaścutam ugram khadiram ojase / tam sūryaḥ prati amuñcata tena imāḥ ajayat diśaḥ / saḥ asmai bhūtim id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi //
column2: The Charin Brihaspati, etc. This Charm hath Soma put on him for might, for hearing, and for sight. This yields him energy indeed, again, again, etc. The Charm Brihaspati, etc. This Sūrya put on him, with this conquered the regions of the sky. This yieldeth him ability, again, etc.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ maṇim phālam ghṛtaścutam ugram khadiram ojase / tam bibhrat candramāḥ maṇim asurāṇām puras ajayat dānavānām hiraṇyayīḥ / saḥ asmai śriyam id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // tvam
column2: The Charm Brihaspati, etc. This Charm did Chandra wear, with this conquered the forts of Asuras, the golden forts of Dānavas. This yields him glory and renown, again, etc. The Amulet Brihaspati bound on the swiftly-moving Wind. This yieldeth him a vigorous steed, again, etc. The Asvins with this Amulet protect this culture of our fields. This yields the two Physicians might, again, etc.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ vātāya maṇim āśave / tam bibhrat savitā maṇim tena idam ajayat svar / saḥ asmai sūnṛtām duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi //
column2: Savitar wore this Amulet: herewith he won this lucid heaven. This yields him glory and delight, again, etc.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ vātāya maṇim āśave / tam āpaḥ bibhratīḥ maṇim sadā dhāvanti akṣitāḥ / saḥ ābhyaḥ amṛtam id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi //
column2: Wearing this Charm the Waters flow eternally inviolate. This yieldeth them ambrosia, again etc.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ vātāya maṇim āśave / tam rājā varuṇaḥ maṇim prati amuñcata śaṃbhuvam / saḥ asmai satyam id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi //
column2: King Varuna assumed and wore this salutary Amulet. This yieldeth him his truthfulness, again, etc.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ vātāya maṇim āśave / tam devāḥ bibhrataḥ maṇim sarvān lokān yudhā ajayan / saḥ ebhyaḥ jitim id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ vātāya maṇim āśave / tam imam devatāḥ maṇim prati amuñcanta śambhuvam / saḥ ābhyaḥ viśvam id duhe bhūyas bhūyas śvas śvas tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi //
column2: Wearing this Amulet the Gods conquered in battle all the worlds. This yieldeth victory for them, again, etc. The Amulet Brihaspati formed for the swiftly-moving Wind, This salutary Amulet the Deities assumed and wore. This yieldeth them the universe, again, again, from morn to morn. With this subdue thine enemies.

column1: ṛtavaḥ tam abadhnata ārtavāḥ tam abadhnata / saṃvatsaraḥ tam baddhvā sarvam bhūtam vi rakṣati //
column2: The seasons formed that Amulet, the Groups of Seasons fashion- ed it. The Year having constructed it preserveth everything that is.

column1: antardeśāḥ abadhnata pradiśaḥ tam abadhnata / prajāpati sṛṣṭaḥ maṇiḥ dviṣataḥ me adharām akaḥ / atharvāṇaḥ abadhnata ātharvaṇāḥ abadhnata / taiḥ medinaḥ aṅgirasaḥ dasyūnām bibhiduḥ puras tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // // tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi // //
column2: The regions of the heaven, the points that lie between them fashioned it. Created by Prajāpati, may the Charm cast my foemen down. Atharvan made the Amulet, Atharvan's children fashioned it. With them the sage Angirases broke through the Dasyus' fortresses. With this subdue thine enemies.

column1: tam dhātā prati amuñcata sa bhūtam vi akalpayat / tena tvam dviṣataḥ jahi //
column2: Dhātar bound on this Amulet: he ranged and ordered all that is. With this do thou subdue thy foes.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ devebhyaḥ asura kṣitim / sa mā ayam maṇiḥ āgamat rasena saha varcasā / yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ devebhyaḥ asura kṣitim / sa mā ayam maṇiḥ āgamat saha gobhiḥ aja avibhiḥ annena prajayā saha / yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ devebhyaḥ asura kṣitim / sa mā ayam maṇiḥ āgamat saha vrīhi yavābhyām mahasā bhūtyā saha /
column2: The Amulet Brihaspati formed for the Gods, that slew the fiends. That Amulet here hath come to me combined with sap and energy. The Amulet, etc. That Amulet here hath come to me, hath come with cows, and goats, and sheep, hath come with food and progeny. The Amulet, etc. That Amulet here hath come to me with store of barley and of rice, with greatness and prosperity.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ devebhyaḥ asura kṣitim / sa mā ayam maṇiḥ āgamat madhoḥ ghṛtasya dhārayā kīlālena maṇiḥ saha / yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ devebhyaḥ asura kṣitim / sa mā ayam maṇiḥ āgamat ūrjayā payasā saha draviṇena śriyā saha / yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ devebhyaḥ asura kṣitim / sa mā ayam maṇiḥ āgamat tejasā tviṣyā saha yaśasā kīrtyā saha /
column2: The Amulet, etc. That Amulet here hath come to me with streams of butter and of mead, with sweet delicious beverage. The Amulet, etc. That Amulet here hath come to me with power and abundant strength, hath come with glory and with wealth. The Amulet, etc.. That Amulet here hath come to me with splendour and a blaze of light, with honour and illustrious fame.

column1: yam abadhnāt bṛhaspatiḥ devebhyaḥ asura kṣitim / sa mā ayam maṇiḥ āgamat sarvābhiḥ bhūtibhiḥ saha /
column2: The Amulet Brihaspati made for the Gods, that slew the fiends, That Amulet here hath come to me combined with all prosperities.

column1: tam imam devatāḥ maṇim mahyam dadatu puṣṭaye / abhibhum kṣatra vardhanam sapatna dambhanam maṇim //
column2: That Amulet may the Deities bestow on me to win success, The conquering, strength-increasing Charm, the damager of enemies.

column1: brahmaṇā tejasā saha prati muñcāmi me śivam / asapatnaḥ sapatna hā sapatnāt me adharām akaḥ // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // uttaram dviṣataḥ mām ayam maṇiḥ kṛṇotu deva jāḥ / yasya lokāḥ ime trayaḥ payaḥ dugdham upāsate / sa mā ayam adhi rohatu maṇiḥ śraiṣṭhyāya mūrdhataḥ /
column2: I bind on me my happy fate with holy prayer and energy. Foeless destroyer of the foe, it hath subdued mine enemies. May this Chaim, offspring of the Gods, make me superior to my foe. So may this charm whose milk expressed these three worlds longingly await, Be fastened on me here, that it may crown me with surpassing power.

column1: yam devāḥ pitaraḥ manuṣyāḥ upajīvanti sarvadā / sa mā ayam adhi rohatu maṇiḥ śraiṣṭhyāya mūrdhataḥ /
column2: The Charm to which men, Fathers, Gods look ever for their maintenance, May this be fastened on me here, to crown me with surpassing power

column1: yathā bījam urvarāyām kṛṣṭe phālena rohati / eva mayi prajā paśavaḥ annam annam vi rohatu //
column2: As, when the plough hath tilled the soil, the seed springs up in. fertile land, Let cattle, progeny, and food of every kind spring up with me.

column1: yasmai tvā yajñavardhana maṇe pratyamucam śivam / tam tvam śata dakṣiṇa maṇe śraiṣṭhyāya jinvatāt /
column2: Charm, forwarder of sacrifice, who hast a hundred priestly fees. Speed to preeminence him to whom I have attached thy happy fate.

column1: yat antarā dyāvāpṛthivī agniḥ ait pradahan viśvadāvyaḥ / yatra atiṣṭhan eka patnīḥ parastāt kva iva āsīt mātariśvā tadānīm / apsu āsīt mātariśvā praviṣṭaḥ praviṣṭāḥ devāḥ salilāni āsan // bṛhan ha tasthau rajasaḥ vimānaḥ pavamānaḥ haritaḥ ā viveśa /
column2: Love thou, O Agni, pleased with burnt oblations, this sacred fuel that is ranged in order. In him may we find grace and loving-kindness, happiness, progeny, and sight and cattle, in Jātavedas kindled with devotion.

column1: aghāyatām api nahyā mukhāni sapatneṣu vajram arpaya etam / indreṇa dattā prathamā śata odanā bhrātṛvya ghnī yajamānasya gātuḥ /
column2: Binding the mouths of those who threaten mischief, against my rivals cast this bolt of thunder, Indra first gave the Hundredfold Oblation, welfare of him who worships, foe-destroying.

column1: vediḥ te carma bhavatu barhiḥ lomāni yāni te / eṣā tvā raśanā agrabhīt grāvā tvā eṣaḥ adhi nṛtyatu //
column2: Thy skin shall be the Altar; let thine hair become the Sacred Grass. This cord hath held thee firmly: let this pressing-stone dance round on thee:

column1: bālāḥ te prokṣaṇīḥ santu jīhvā sam mārṣṭu aghnye / śuddhā tvam yajñiyā bhūtvā divam prehi śata odane /
column2: The holy water be thy hair: let thy tongue make thee clean, O Cow. Go, Hundredfold Oblation, made bright and adorable, to hea- ven.

column1: yaḥ śata odanām pacati kāmapreṇa sa kalpate / prītāḥ hi asya ṛtvijaḥ sarve yanti yathāyatham //
column2: He who prepares the Hundredfold Oblation gains each wish thereby: For all his ministering priests, contented, move as fitteth them.

column1: sa svargam ā rohati yatra adaḥ tridivam divaḥ / apūpa nābhim kṛtvā yaḥ dadāti śata odanām //
column2: He rises up to heaven, ascends to younder third celestial height. Whoever gives the Hundredfold Oblation with the central cake.

column1: sa tān lokān sam āpnoti ye divyāḥ ye ca pārthivāḥ / hiraṇyajyotiṣam kṛtvā yaḥ dadāti śata odanām //
column2: That man completely wins those worlds, both of the heavens and of the earth, Whoever pays the Hundredfold. Oblation with its golden light.

column1: ye te devi śamitāraḥ paktāraḥ ye ca te janāḥ / te tvā sarve gopsyanti mā ebhyaḥ bhaiṣīḥ śata odane /
column2: Thine Immolators, Goddess! and the men who dress thee for the feast, all these will guard thee, Hundredfold Oblation! Have no fear of them.

column1: vasavaḥ tvā dakṣiṇatas uttarāt marutaḥ tvā / ādityāḥ paścāt gopsyanti sā agniṣṭomam ati drava /
column2: The Vasus from the South will be thy guards, the Maruts from the North, Ādityas from the West; o'ertake and pass the Agnishtoma, thou!

column1: devāḥ pitaraḥ manuṣyāḥ gandharva apsarasaḥ ca ye / te tvā sarve gopsyanti sā atirātram ati drava /
column2: The Gods, the Fathers, mortal men, Gandharvas, and Apsara- ses, All these will be the guards: o'ertake and pass the Atirātra, thou!
The man who pays the Hundredfold Oblation winneth all the worlds, Air, heaven, and earth, Ādityas, and Maruts, and regions of the sky.

column1: ghṛtam prokṣantī subhagā devī devān gamiṣyati / paktāram aghnye mā hiṃsīḥ divam prehi śata odane /
column2: Sprinkling down fatness, to the Gods will the beneficent God- dess go. Harm not thy dresser, Cow! To heaven, O Hundredfold Obla- tion, speed!

column1: ye devāḥ diviṣadaḥ antarikṣa sadaḥ ca ye ye ca ime bhūmyām adhi / tebhyaḥ tvam dhukṣva sarvadā kṣīram sarpiḥ atha u madhu /
column2: From all the Gods enthroned in heaven, in air, from those who dwell on earth, Draw forth for evermore a stream of milk, of butter, and of mead.

column1: yat te śiraḥ yat te mukham yau karṇau ye ca te hanū / āmikṣām duhratām dātre kṣīram sarpiḥ atho madhu // yau te oṣṭhau ye nāsike ye śṛṅge ye ca te akṣiṇī / āmikṣām duhratām dātre kṣīram sarpiḥ atho madhu // yat te klomāḥ yat dhṛdayam purītat sahakaṇṭhikā / āmikṣām duhratām dātre kṣīram sarpiḥ atho madhu //
column2: Let thy head, let thy mouth, let both thine ears, and those two jaws of thine. Pour for the giver mingled curd, and flowing butter, milk, and mead. Let both thy lips, thy nostrils, both thy horns, and these two eyes of thine. Pour for the given, etc.

column1: yat te pucham ye te bālāḥ yat ūdhar ye ca te stanāḥ / āmikṣām duhratām dātre kṣīram sarpiḥ atho madhu // yāḥ te jaṅghāḥ yāḥ kuṣṭhikāḥ ṛcharāḥ ye ca te śaphāḥ / āmikṣām duhratām dātre kṣīram sarpiḥ atho madhu //
column2: Let heart and pericardium, let thy lungs with all the bronchial tubes, etc. Let liver, and let kidneys, let thine entrails, and the parts within, etc. Let rectum and omentum, let thy belly's hollows, and thy skin, etc.

column1: namaḥ te jāyamānāyai jātāyai uta te namaḥ / bālebhyaḥ śaphebhyaḥ rūpāya aghnye te namaḥ /
column2: Let all thy marrow, every bone, let all thy flesh, and all thy blood, etc.

column1: yayā dyauḥ yayā pṛthivī yayā apaḥ gupitāḥ imāḥ / vaśām sahasra dhārām brahmaṇā āchāvadāmasi //
column2: Let both thy shoulders and thy hump, thy forelegs, and their lower parts, etc.

column1: śatam kaṃsāḥ śatam dogdhāraḥ śatam goptāraḥ adhi pṛṣṭhe asyāḥ / ye devāḥ tasyām prāṇanti te vaśām viduḥ ekadhā /
column2: Let neck and nape and shoulder-joints, thy ribs and inter-costal parts, etc. So let thy thighs and thy knee-bones, thy hinder quarters, and thy hips, etc.

column1: apaḥ tvam dhukṣe prathamāḥ urvarāḥ aparāḥ vaśe / tṛtīyam rāṣṭram dhukṣe annam kṣīram vaśe tvam /
column2: So let thy tail and all the hairs thereof, thine udder, and thy teats, etc.

column1: sam hi somena āgata sam u sarveṇa padvatā / vaśā samudram adhi aṣṭhat gandharvaiḥ kalibhiḥ saha / sam hi vātena agata sam u sarvaiḥ patatribhiḥ / vaśā samudre prānṛtyat ṛcaḥ sāmāni bibhratī / sam hi sūryeṇa āgata sam u sarveṇa cakṣuṣā / vaśā samudram ati akhyat bhadrā jyotīṃṣi bibhratī /
column2: Let all thy legs, the refuse of thy feet, thy heelropes, and thy hooves. Pour for the giver mingled curd, and flowing butter milk, and mead. Let all thy skin, Sataudanā! let every hair thou hast, O Cow, Pour for the giver mingled curd, and flowing butter, milk, and mead.

column1: tredhā bhāgaḥ nihitaḥ yaḥ purā vaḥ devānām pitṝṇām martyānām / aṃśām jānīdhvam vi bhajāmi tān vaḥ yaḥ devānām saḥ imām pārayāti // agne sahasvān abhibhūḥ abhi id asi nīcaḥ ni ubja dviṣataḥ sapatnān / iyam mātrā mīyamānā mitā ca sajātān te bali hṛtaḥ kṛṇotu / sākam sajātaiḥ payasā saha edhi ud ubja enām mahate vīryāya / ūrdhvaḥ nākasya adhi roha viṣṭapam svargaḥ lokaḥ iti yam vadanti /
column2: Sprinkled with molten butter, let the two meal-cakes be sport for thee. Make them thy wings, O Goddess, and bear him who dresses thee to heaven. Each grain of rice in mortar or on pestle, all on the skin or in the winnowing-basket, Whatever purifying Mātarisvan, the Wind, hath sifted, let the Hotar Agni make of it an acceptable oblation.

column1: upaśvase druvaye sīdata yūyam vi vicyadhvam yajñiyāsaḥ tuṣaiḥ / śriyā samānān ati sarvān syāma adhaspadam dviṣataḥ pādayāmi // parehi nāri punar ehi kṣipram apām tvā goṣṭhaḥ adhi arukṣat bharāya / tāsām gṛhṇītāt yatamāḥ yajñiyāḥ asan vibhājya dhīrītarāḥ jahītāt /
column2: In the priest's hands I lay, in separate order, the sweet celestial Waters, dropping fatness. As here I sprinkle them may all my wishes be granted unto me in perfect fulness. May we have ample wealth in our posses- sion.

column1: bhava śarvau mṛḍatam mā abhi yātam bhūtapatī paśupatī namaḥ vām / pratihitām āyatām mā vi srāṣṭam mā naḥ hiṃsiṣṭam dvipadaḥ mā catuṣpadaḥ /
column2: Bhava and Sarva, spare us, be not hostile. Homage to you, twin Lords of beasts and spirits! Shoot not the arrow aimed and drawn against us: forbear to harm our quadrupeds and bipeds.

column1: śune kroṣṭre mā śarīrāṇi kartam ali klavebhyaḥ gṛdhrebhyaḥ ye ca kṛṣṇāḥ aviṣyavaḥ / makṣikāḥ te paśupate vayāṃsi te vighase mā vidanta /
column2: Cast not our bodies to the dog or jackal, nor, Lord of Beasts! to carrion-kites or vultures. Let not thy black voracious flies attack them; let not thy birds obtain them for their banquet.

column1: krandāya te prāṇāya yāḥ ca te bhava ropayaḥ / namaḥ te rudra kṛṇmaḥ sahasrākṣāya amartya /
column2: We offer homage to thy shout, Bhava! thy breath, thy racking pains: Homage, Immortal One! to thee, to Rudra of the thousand eyes.

column1: purastāt te namaḥ kṛṇmaḥ uttarāt adharāt uta / abhīvargāt divaḥ pari antarikṣāya te namaḥ /
column2: We offer reverence to thee from eastward, and from north and south, From all the compass of the sky, to thee and to the firmament.

column1: mukhāya te paśupate yāni cakṣūṃṣi te bhava / tvace rūpāya saṃdṛśe pratīcīnāya te namaḥ //
column2: Homage, O Bhava, Lord of Beasts, unto thy face and all thine eyes, To skin, and hue, and aspect, and to thee when looked at from behind!

column1: aṅgebhyaḥ te udarāya jihvāyāḥ āsyāya te / dadbhyaḥ gandhāya te namaḥ /
column2: We offer homage to thy limbs, thy belly, and thy tongue, and mouth we offer homage to thy smell.

column1: astrā nīla śikhaṇḍena sahasrākṣeṇa vājinā / rudreṇa ardhaka ghātinā tena mā sam arāmahi //
column2: Never may we contend with him, the mighty archer, thousand- eyed. Rudra who wears black tufts of hair, the slaughterer of Ardhaka.

column1: sa naḥ bhavaḥ pari vṛṇaktu viśvatas āpaḥ iva agniḥ pari vṛṇaktu naḥ bhavaḥ / mā naḥ abhi māṃsta namaḥ astu asmai //
column2: May he, may Bhava from all sides avoid us, avoid us even as fire avoids the waters. Let him not threaten us. To him be homage!

column1: catuḥ namaḥ aṣṭa kṛtvas bhavāya daśa kṛtvas paśupate namaḥ te / tava ime pañca paśavaḥ vibhaktāḥ gāvaḥ aśvāḥ puruṣāḥ aja avayaḥ /
column2: Four times, eight times be homage paid to Bhava, yea, Lord of Beasts, ten times be reverence paid thee! Thine are these animals, five several classes, oxen, and goats and sheep, and men, and horses

column1: tava catasraḥ pradiśaḥ tava dyauḥ tava pṛthivī tava idam ugrā uru antarikṣam / tava idam sarvam ātmanvat yat prāṇat pṛthivīm anu / tava idam sarvam ātmanvat yat prāṇat pṛthivīm anu / tava idam sarvam ātmanvat yat prāṇat pṛthivīm anu / tava idam sarvam ātmanvat yat prāṇat pṛthivīm anu / tava idam sarvam ātmanvat yat prāṇat pṛthivīm anu / tava idam sarvam ātmanvat yat prāṇat pṛthivīm anu / tava idam sarvam ātmanvat yat prāṇat pṛthivīm anu
column2: Thine the four regions, thine are earth and heaven, thine, Mighty One, this firmament between them; Thine everything with soul and breath here on the surface of the land.

column1: uruḥ kośaḥ vasu dhānaḥ tava ayam yasmin imā viśvā bhuvanāni antar / sa naḥ mṛḍa paśupate namaḥ te paras kroṣṭāraḥ abhibhāḥ śvānaḥ paras yantu agharudaḥ vikeśyaḥ /
column2: Thine is this ample wealth-containing storehouse that holds with- in it all these living creatures. Favour us, Lord of Beasts, to thee be homage! Far from us go ill-omens, dogs, and jackals, and wild-haired women with their horrid shrieking!

column1: dhanuḥ bibharṣi haritam hiraṇyayam sahasra ghnim śata vadham śikhaṇḍin / rudrasya iṣuḥ carati deva hetiḥ tasyai namaḥ yatamasyām diśi itas /
column2: A yellow bow of gold thou wieldest, slaying its hundred, tufted God! smiting its thousand. Weapon of Gods, far flies the shaft of Rudra: wherever it may be, we pay it homage.

column1: yaḥ abhiyātaḥ nilayate tvām rudra nicikīrṣati / paścāt anuprayuṅkṣe tam viddhasya padanīḥ iva /
column2: Thou, Rudra, followest close the foe who lies in wait to conquer thee. Even as a hunter who pursues the footsteps of the wounded game.

column1: bhava rudrau sayujā saṃvidānau ubhau ugrau carataḥ vīryāya / tābhyām namaḥ yatamasyām diśi itas /
column2: Accordant and allies, Bhava and Rudra, with mighty strength ye go to deeds of valour. Wherever they may be, we pay them homage.

column1: namaḥ te astu āyate namaḥ astu parāyate / namaḥ te rudra tiṣṭhate āsīnāya uta te namaḥ /
column2: Be homage, Rudra, unto thee approaching and departing hence! Homage to thee when standing still, to thee when seated and at rest!

column1: namaḥ sāyam namaḥ prātar namaḥ rātryāḥ namaḥ divā / bhavāya ca śarvāya ca ubhābhyām akaram namaḥ /
column2: Homage at evening and at morn, homage at night, homage by day . To Bhava and to Sarva, both, have I paid lowly reverence,

column1: sahasrākṣam atipaśyam purastāt rudram asyantam bahudhā vipaścitam / mā upārāma jihvayā īyamānam /
column2: Let us not outrage with our tongue far-seeing Rudra, thousand- eyed, Inspired with varied lore, who shoots his arrows forward, far away.

column1: śyāva aśvam kṛṣṇam asitam mṛṇantam bhīmam ratham keśinaḥ pādayantam / pūrve pratīmaḥ namaḥ astu asmai /
column2: Foremost we go to meet his car, the chariot of the long-haired God, Drawn by brown horses, dusky, black, o'erthrowing, slaying, terrible. Let reverence be paid to him.

column1: mā naḥ abhi srāḥ matyam deva hetim mā naḥ krudhaḥ paśupate namaḥ te / anyatra asmat divyām śākhām vi dhūnu // mā naḥ hiṃsīḥ adhi naḥ brūhi pari naḥ vṛṅdhi mā krudhaḥ / mā tvayā sam arāmahi // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // mā naḥ goṣu puruṣeṣu mā gṛdhaḥ naḥ aja aviṣu / anyatra ugra vi vartaya piyārūṇām prajām jahi //
column2: Cast not thy club at us, thy heavenly weapon. Lord of Beasts, be not wroth with us. Let reverence be paid to thee. Shake thy celestial branch above some others elsewhere, not o'er us. Do us no harm, but comfort us: avoid thou us, and be not wroth. Never let us contend with thee. Covet not thou our kine or men, covet not thou our goats or sheep. Elsewhither, strong One! turn thine aim: destroy the mockers' family.

column1: yasya takmā kāsikā hetiḥ ekam aśvasya iva vṛṣaṇaḥ krandaḥ eti / abhipūrvam nirṇayate namaḥ astu asmai /
column2: Homage to him whose weapon, Cough or Fever, assails one like the neighing of a stallion; to him who draws one forth and then another!

column1: yaḥ antarikṣe tiṣṭhati viṣṭabhitaḥ a yajvanaḥ pramṛṇan deva pīyūn / tasmai namaḥ daśabhiḥ śakvarībhiḥ /
column2: Homage be paid him with ten Sakvari verses who stands established in the air's mid-region, slaying non-sacrificing God-despisers!

column1: tubhyam āraṇyāḥ paśavaḥ mṛgāḥ vane hitāḥ haṃsāḥ suparṇāḥ śakunāḥ vayāṃsi / tava yakṣam paśupate apsu antar tubhyam kṣaranti divyāḥ āpaḥ vṛdhe /
column2: For thee were forest beasts and sylvan creatures placed in the wood, and small birds, swans, and eagles. Floods, Lord of Beasts! contain thy living beings: to swell thy strength flow the celestial Waters.

column1: śiṃśumārāḥ ajagarāḥ purīkayā jaṣāḥ matsyāḥ rajasā yebhyaḥ asyasi / na te dūram na pariṣṭhā asti te bhava sadyas sarvām pari paśyasi bhūmim pūrvasmāt dhaṃsi uttarasmin samudre /
column2: Porpoises, serpents, strange aquatic monsters, fishes, and things unclean at which thou shootest. Nothing is far for thee, naught checks thee, Bhava! The whole earth in a moment thou surveyest. From the east sea thou smitest in the northern.

column1: mā naḥ rudra takmanā mā viṣeṇa mā naḥ sam srāḥ divyena agninā / anyatra asmat vidyutam pātaya etām /
column2: O'erwhelm us not with Fever or with poison, nor, Rudra! with the fire that comes from heaven. Elsewhere, and not on us, cast down this lightning.

column1: bhavaḥ divaḥ bhavaḥ īśe pṛthivyāḥ bhavaḥ ā papre uru antarikṣam / tasyai namaḥ yatamasyām diśi itas /
column2: Ruler of heaven and Lord of earth is Bhava: Bhava hath filled the spacious air's mid-region. Where'er he be, to him be paid our homage!

column1: bhava rājan yajamānāya mṛḍa paśūnām hi paśupatiḥ babhūtha / yaḥ śraddadhāti santi devāḥ iti catuṣpade dvipade asya mṛḍa /
column2: King Bhava, favour him who offers worship, for thou art Pasupati, Lord of victims. Be gracious to the quadruped and biped of the believer in the Gods' existence.

column1: mā naḥ mahāntam uta mā naḥ arbhakam mā naḥ vahantam uta mā naḥ vakṣyataḥ / mā naḥ hiṃsīḥ pitaram mātaram ca svām tanvam rudra mā rīriṣaḥ naḥ /
column2: Harm thou among us neither great nor little, not one who bears us, not our future bearers. Injure no sire among us, harm no mother. Forbear to injure our own bodies, Rudra.

column1: āntrāṇi jatravaḥ gudāḥ varatrāḥ // iyam eva pṛthivī kumbhī bhavati rādhyamānasya odanasya dyauḥ apidhānam //
column2: This lowly reverence have I paid to Rudra's dogs with mighty mouths, Hounds terrible with bark and howl, who gorge unmasticated food.

column1: sītāḥ parśavaḥ sikatāḥ ūbadhyam // ṛtam hasta avanejanam kulyā upasecanam // ṛcā kumbhī adhihitā ārtvijyena preṣitā // brahmaṇā parigṛhītā sāmnā paryūḍhā // bṛhat āyavanam rathantaram darviḥ //
column2: Homage to thy loud-shouting hosts and thy long-haired followers! Homage to hosts that are adored, homage to armies that enjoy Homage to all thy troops, O God. Security and bliss be ours!

column1: tatas ca enam anyena śīrṣṇā prāśīḥ yena ca etam pūrve ṛṣayaḥ prāśnan / jyeṣṭhataḥ te prajā mariṣyati iti enam āha / tam vai aham na arvāñcam na parāñcam na pratyañcam / bṛhaspatinā śīrṣṇā / tena enam prāśiṣam tena enam ajīgamam / eṣa vai odanaḥ sarva aṅgaḥ sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ / sarva aṅgaḥ eva sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ sam bhavati yaḥ evam veda / yaḥ evam veda / yaḥ evam veda / tatas ca enam anyābhyām śrotrābhyām prāśīḥ yābhyām ca etam pūrve ṛṣayaḥ prāśnan / badhiraḥ bhaviṣyasi iti enam āha / tam vai aham na arvāñcam na parāñcam na pratyañcam / dyāvāpṛthivībhyām śrotrābhyām / tābhyām enam prāśiṣam tābhyām enam ajīgamam / eṣa vai odanaḥ sarva aṅgaḥ sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ / sarva aṅgaḥ eva sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ sam bhavati yaḥ evam veda / yaḥ evam veda / tatas ca enam anyābhyām akṣībhyām prāśīḥ yābhyām ca etam pūrve ṛṣayaḥ prāśnan / andhaḥ bhaviṣyasi iti enam āha / tam vai aham na arvāñcam na parāñcam na pratyañcam / sūryācandramasābhyām akṣībhyām / tābhyām enam prāśiṣam tābhyām enam ajīgamam / eṣa vai odanaḥ sarva aṅgaḥ sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ / sarva aṅgaḥ eva sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ sam bhavati yaḥ evam veda / tatas ca enam anyena mukhena prāśīḥ yena ca etam pūrve ṛṣayaḥ prāśnan / mukhataḥ te prajā mariṣyati iti enam āha / tam vai aham na arvāñcam na parāñcam na pratyañcam / brahmaṇā mukhena / tena enam prāśiṣam tena enam ajīgamam / eṣa vai odanaḥ sarva aṅgaḥ sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ / sarva aṅgaḥ eva sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ sam bhavati yaḥ evam veda / yaḥ evam veda / tatas ca enam anyayā jihvayā prāśīḥ yayā ca etam pūrve ṛṣayaḥ prāśnan / jihvā te mariṣyati iti enam āha / tam vai aham na arvāñcam na parāñcam na pratyañcam / agneḥ jihvayā / tayā enam prāśiṣam tayā enam ajīgamam / eṣa vai odanaḥ sarva aṅgaḥ sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ / sarva aṅgaḥ eva sarva paruḥ sarva tanūḥ sam bhavati yaḥ evam veda / / | eṣa vai odanaḥ sarva aṅgaḥ sarva tanūḥ sam bhavati yaḥ evam veda / | eṣa vai odanaḥ
column2: 32. And thence he said to this one, Thou hast eaten this with a different head from that with which the ancient Rishis ate: thy offspring, reckoning from the eldest, will die. I have eaten it neither turned downward, nor turned away, nor turned hitherward. With Brihaspati as head: with him I have eaten, with him have I come to it. Now this Odana is complete with all members, joints, and body. Complete, verily, with all his members, joints, and body is he who possess this knowledge. 33. And thence he said to him, Thou hast eaten this with other ears than those with which the ancient Rishis ate it. Thou wilt be deaf. I have eaten it neither, etc. (as in verse 32). With Heaven and Earth as ears, with these I have eaten it, with these I have come to it. Now this Odana, etc. (as in 32). 34. And thence he said to him. Thou hast eaten this with other eyes . . . thou wilt be blind. With Sun and Moon, etc. 35. And thence, etc. . . with other month. Thy offspring will die, reckoning from the head . . . With Brahma as mouth. 36. And thence, etc. . . . with other tongue . . . Thy tongue will die . . . With the tongue of Agni. 37. And thence, etc. . . With other teeth . . . Thy teeth will fall out . . . With the Seasons as teeth. 38. And thence, etc. . . . with other vital airs. . . . Thy vital airs will leave thee . . . With the Seven Rishis as the vital airs. 39. And thence, etc. . . . with other expanse . . . Consumption will destroy thee . . . With the firmament as expanse. 40 And thence, etc. . . . with other back. . . . Lightning will slay thee. . . With the heaven as back. 41. And thence, etc. . . . with other breast . . . Thou wilt fail in agriculture. . . . With the earth as breast. 42. And thence, etc. . . . with other belly . . . colic will destroy thee . . . With truth as belly. 43. And thence, etc. . . . with other abdomen . . . Thou wilt die in the water . . . With the sea as abdomen. 44. And thence, etc. . . . with other thighs . . . Thy thigh will perish . . . With Mitra-Varuna as thighs. 45. And thence, etc. . . . with other knees . . . Thou wilt become a sick man . . . With the knees of Tvashtar. 46. And thence, etc. . . . with other feet . . . Thou wilt become a wanderer . . . With the feet of the Asvins. 47. And thence, etc. . . with other fore-parts of the feet . . . A serpent will kill thee . . . With the fore-parts of Savitar's feet. 48. And thence, etc. . . . with other hands . . . The Brāhmana (divine power) will kill thee . . . With the hands of Right. 49. And thence, etc. . . . with other basis . . . Without standing-ground and resting-place thou wilt die . . . Having taken my stand on truth. With this I ate it, with this I came to it. Now this Odana is complete with all members, joints, and body. Complete, verily, with all his members, joints, and body is he who possesses this knowledge.

column1: prāṇāya namaḥ yasya sarvam idam vaśe / yaḥ bhūtaḥ sarvasya īśvaraḥ yasmin sarvam pratiṣṭhitam /
column2: Homage to Prāna, him who hath dominion o'er the universe, Who hath become the Sovran Lord of all, on whom the whole depends!

column1: namaḥ te prāṇa krandāya namaḥ te stanayitnave / namaḥ te prāṇa vidyute namaḥ te prāṇa varṣate /
column2: Homage, O Prāna, to thy roar, to thunder-peal and lightning flash! Homage, O Prāna, unto thee what time thou sendest down thy rain!

column1: yat prāṇaḥ stanayitnunā abhikrandati oṣadhīḥ / pra vīyante garbhān dadhate atha u bahvīḥ vi jāyante //
column2: When Prāna with a thunderous voice shouts his loud message to the plants, They straightway are impregnate, they conceive, and bear abundantly.

column1: yat prāṇe ṛtau āgate abhikrandati oṣadhīḥ / sarvam tadā pra modate yat kim ca bhūmyām adhi //
column2: When the due season hath arrived and Prāna shouteth to herbs, Then all is joyful, yea, each thing upon the surface of the earth.

column1: yadā prāṇaḥ abhyavarṣīt varṣeṇa pṛthivīm mahīm / paśavaḥ tat pra modante mahaḥ vai naḥ bhaviṣyati //
column2: When Prāna hath poured down his flood of rain upon the mighty land. Cattle and beasts rejoice thereat: Now great will he our strength, they cry.

column1: abhivṛṣṭāḥ oṣadhayaḥ prāṇena sam avādiran / āyuḥ vai naḥ prātītaraḥ sarvā naḥ surabhīḥ akaḥ /
column2: Watered by Prāna's rain the plants have raised their voices in accord: Thou hast prolonged our life, they say, and given fragrance to us all.

column1: namaḥ te astu āyate namaḥ astu parāyate / namaḥ te prāṇa tiṣṭhate āsīnāya uta te namaḥ /
column2: Homage to thee when coming nigh, homage to thee departing hence! Homage, O Prāna, be to thee when standing and when sitting still.

column1: namaḥ te prāṇa prāṇate namaḥ astu apānate / parācīnāya te namaḥ pratīcīnāya te namaḥ sarvasmai te idam namaḥ /
column2: Homage to thee at every breath thou drawest in and sendest forth! Homage to thee when turned away, homage to thee seen face to face! This reverence be to all of thee!

column1: yā te prāṇa priyā tanūḥ yā u te prāṇa preyasī / atha u yat bheṣajam tava tasya naḥ dhehi jīvase /
column2: Prāna, communicate to us thy dear, thy very dearest form. Whatever healing balm thou hast, give us thereof that we may live.

column1: prāṇaḥ prajāḥ anu vaste pitā putram iva priyam / prāṇaḥ ha sarvasya īśvaraḥ yat ca prāṇati yat ca na /
column2: Prāna robes living creatures as a father his beloved son. Prāna is sovran Lord of all, of all that breathes not, all that breathes

column1: prāṇaḥ mṛtyuḥ prāṇaḥ takmā prāṇam devāḥ upāsate / prāṇaḥ ha satya vādinam uttame loke ā dadhat /
column2: Prāna is Fever, he is Death. Prāna is worshipped by the Gods. Prāna sets in the loftiest sphere the man who speaks the words of truth.

column1: prāṇaḥ virāj prāṇaḥ deṣṭrī prāṇam sarve upāsate / prāṇaḥ ha sūryaḥ candramāḥ prāṇam āhuḥ prajāpatim /
column2: Prāna is Deshtri, and Virāj Prāna is reverenced by all. He is the Sun, he is the Moon. Prāna is called Prajāpati.

column1: prāṇa apānau vrīhi yavau anaḍvān prāṇaḥ ucyate / yave ha prāṇaḥ āhitaḥ apānaḥ vrīhiḥ ucyate /
column2: Both breaths are rice and barley, and Prāna is called the toiling ox: In barley is the inbreath laid, and rice is named the outward breath.

column1: apānati prāṇati puruṣaḥ garbhe antarā / yadā tvam prāṇa jinvasi atha sa jāyate punar /
column2: The human infant in the womb draws vital breath and sends it Lout: When thou, O Prāna, quickenest the babe it springs anew to life.

column1: prāṇam āhuḥ mātariśvānam vātaḥ ha prāṇaḥ ucyate / prāṇe ha bhūtam bhavyam ca prāṇe sarvam pratiṣṭhitam /
column2: The name of Prāna is bestowed on Mātarisvan and on Wind. On Prāna, past and future, yea, on Prāna everything depends.

column1: ātharvaṇīḥ āṅgirasīḥ daivīḥ manuṣya jāḥ uta / oṣadhayaḥ pra jāyante yadā tvam prāṇa jinvasi //
column2: All herbs and plants spring forth and grow when thou, O Prāna quickenest, Plants of Atharvan, Angiras, plants of the deities and men.

column1: yadā prāṇaḥ abhyavarṣīt varṣeṇa pṛthivīm mahīm / oṣadhayaḥ pra jāyante atha u yāḥ kāḥ ca vīrudhaḥ /
column2: When Prāna hath poured down his flood of rain upon the mighty earth, The plants are wakened into life, and every herd that grows on ground.

column1: yaḥ te prāṇa idam veda yasmin ca asi pratiṣṭhitaḥ / sarve tasmai balim harān amuṣmin loke uttame /
column2: The man who knows this truth of thee, O Prāna, and what bears thee up To him will all present their gift of tribute in that loftiest will all present their gift of tribute in that loftiest world.

column1: yathā prāṇa bali hṛtaḥ tubhyam sarvāḥ prajāḥ imāḥ / eva tasmai balim harān yaḥ tvā śṛṇavat suśravaḥ /
column2: As all these living creatures are thy tributaries, Prāna, so Shall they bring tribute unto him who hears thee with attentive ears.

column1: antar garbhaḥ carati devatāsu ābhūtaḥ bhūtaḥ saḥ u jāyate punar / sa bhūtaḥ bhavyam bhaviṣyat pitā putram pra viveśa śacībhiḥ // śacībhiḥ // // // _
column2: Filled with a babe, mid deities he wanders: grown; near at hand, he springs again to being. That Father, grown the present and the future, hath past into the son with mighty powers.

column1: ekam pādam na ud khidati salilāt dhaṃsaḥ uccaran / yat aṅga sa tam utkhidet na eva adya na śvas syāt / na rātrī na ahar syāt na vi uchet kadā cana /
column2: Hansa, what time he rises up, leaves in the flood one foot un- moved. If he withdrew it there would be no more tomorrow or to-day, Never would there be night, no more would daylight shine or morning flush.

column1: aṣṭācakram vartate eka nemi sahasra akṣaram pra puras ni paścā / ardhena viśvam bhuvanam jajāna yat asya ardham katamaḥ sa ketuḥ /
column2: It rolleth on, eight-wheeled and single-fellied, and with a thousand eyes, forward and backward. With one half it engendered all creation. What sign is there to tell us of the other?

column1: yaḥ asya viśva janmanaḥ īśe viśvasya ceṣṭataḥ / anyeṣu kṣipradhanvane tasmai prāṇa namaḥ astu te /
column2: Homage, O Prāna unto thee armed with swift bow among the rest, In whose dominion is this All of varied sort that stirs and works!

column1: ūrdhvaḥ supteṣu jāgāra nanu tiryak ni padyate / na suptam asya supteṣu anu śuśrāva kaḥ cana /
column2: Erect among the sleepers he wakes, and is never laid at length, No one hath ever heard that he hath been asleep while others slept.

column2: Thou, Prāna, never shalt be hid, never shalt be estranged from me. I bind thee on myself for life, O Prāna, like the Waters' germ.

column1: brahmacārīṣṇan carati rodasī ubhe tasmin devāḥ saṃmanasaḥ bhavanti / sa dādhāra pṛthivīm divam ca saḥ ācāryam tapasā piparti //
column2: Stirring both worlds the Brahmachāri moveth: in him the deities are all one-minded. He hath established firmly earth and heaven: he satisfies his Master with his Fervour.

column1: brahmacāriṇam pitaraḥ deva janāḥ pṛthak devāḥ anusaṃyanti sarve / gandharvāḥ enam anu āyan trayastriṃśat tri śatāḥ ṣaṣ sahasrāḥ sarvān sa devān tapasā piparti //
column2: After the Brahmachārī go the Fathers, the heavenly hosts, all Gods in separate order. After him too have the Gandharvas followed, thirty and three, three hundred, and six thousand. He satisfies all Gods with his devotion.

column1: ācāryaḥ upanayamānaḥ brahmacāriṇam kṛṇute garbham antar / tam rātrīḥ tisraḥ udare bibharti tam jātam draṣṭum abhisaṃyanti devāḥ /
column2: The Master, welcoming his new disciple, into his bowels takes the Brahmachāri. Three nights he holds and bears him in this belly. When he is born, the Gods convene to see him.

column1: iyam samidh pṛthivī dyauḥ dvitīyā uta antarikṣam samidhā pṛṇāti / brahmacārī samidhā mekhalayā śrameṇa lokān tapasā piparti //
column2: This log is earth, the second log is heaven: he fills the air's mid region with the fuel. With fuel, with his zone the Brahmachāri contents the worlds, with labour and with Fervour.

column1: pūrvaḥ jātaḥ brahmaṇaḥ brahmacārī gharmam vasānaḥ tapasā ud atiṣṭhat / tasmāt jātam brāhmaṇam brahma jyeṣṭham devāḥ ca sarve amṛtena sākam /
column2: The Brahmachāri, earlier born than Brahma, sprang up through Fervour, robed in hot libation. From him sprang heavenly lore, the highest Brahma, and all the Gods, with life that lasts for ever.

column1: brahmacārī eti samidhā samiddhaḥ kārṣṇam vasānaḥ dīkṣitaḥ dīrgha śmaśruḥ / sa sadyas eti pūrvasmāt uttaram samudram lokān saṃgṛbhya muhur ācarikrat /
column2: Lighted by fuel goes the Brahmachāri, clad in black-buck skin, consecrate, long-bearded. Swiftly he goes from east to northern ocean, grasping the worlds, oft bringing them anear him.

column1: brahmacārī janayan brahma apaḥ lokam prajāpatim parameṣṭhinam virājam / garbhaḥ bhūtvā amṛtasya yonau indraḥ ha bhūtvā asurān tatarha /
column2: The Brahmachāri, fathering Prayer, world, Waters, Virāj, Prajā- pati, and Parameshthin, Lay as a germ within the Immortal's bosom, then became Indra and destroyed the demons.

column1: ācāryaḥ tatakṣa nabhasī ubhe ime urvī gambhīre pṛthivīm divam ca / te rakṣati tapasā brahmacārī tasmin devāḥ saṃmanasaḥ bhavanti //
column2: The Master fashioned both these cloudy regions, profound and spacious pair, the earth and heaven. The Brahmachāri guards them with his Fervour. In him the deities are all one-minded.

column1: imām bhūmim pṛthivīm brahmacārī bhikṣām ā jabhāra prathamaḥ divam ca / te kṛtvā samidhau upāste tayoḥ ārpitā bhuvanāni viśvā /
column2: The Brahmachāri first of all brought hither this ample earth as alms, and heaven above it. He makes these twain two fuel-logs, and worships, On these sup- ported rest all living creatures.

column1: arvāk anyaḥ paras anyaḥ divaḥ pṛṣṭhāt guhā nidhī nihitau brāhmaṇasya / tau rakṣati tapasā brahmacārī tat kevalam kṛṇute brahma vidvān // tau rakṣati tapasā brahmacārī tat kevalam kṛṇute brahma vidvān // tau rakṣati tapasā brahmacārī tat kevalam kṛṇute brahma vidvān // tau rakṣati tapasā brahmacārī tat kevalam kṛṇute brahma vidvān // tau rakṣati tapasā brahmacārī tat kevalam kṛṇute brahma vidvān // tau rakṣati tapasā brahmacārī
column2: Both treasuries of sacred lore lie hidden, one hitherward, beyond heaven's ridge the other. The Brahmachārī with his Fervour guards them. He makes this all his own as knowing Brahma.

column1: arvāk anyaḥ itas anyaḥ pṛthivyāḥ agnī sametaḥ nabhasī antarā ime / tayoḥ śrayante raśmayaḥ adhi dṛḍhāḥ tān ā tiṣṭhati tapasā brahmacārī /
column2: Hitherward one, hence from the earth the other, two Agnis meet between these cloudy regions. Close to these two firm rays of light are clinging. The Brahma- chāri enters them through Fervour.

column1: abhikrandan stanayan aruṇaḥ śitiṅgaḥ bṛhat śepaḥ anu bhūmau jabhāra / brahmacārī siñcati sānau retaḥ pṛthivyām tena jīvanti pradiśaḥ catasraḥ /
column2: Thundering, shouting, ruddy-hued, and pallid, he bears along the earth great manly vigour. Down on the ridge of earth the Brahmachāri pours seed, and this gives life to heaven's four regions.

column1: agnau sūrye candramasi mātariśvan brahmacārī apsu samidham ā dadhāti / tāsām arcīṃṣi pṛthak abhre caranti tāsām ājyam puruṣaḥ varṣam āpaḥ /
column2: The Brahmachāri stores with fuel Waters, and Fire, and Sun, and Moon, and Mātarisvan. The Water's lights move separate in the rain-cloud, Man, rain, and water are their molten butter.

column1: ācāryaḥ mṛtyuḥ varuṇaḥ somaḥ oṣadhayaḥ payaḥ / jīmūtāḥ āsan satvānaḥ taiḥ idam svar ābhṛtam /
column2: The Master is Death, Varuna, Soma, the plants of earth, and milk. The thunder-clouds were men of war. By these this heavenly light was brought.

column1: amā ghṛtam kṛṇute kevalam ācāryaḥ bhūtvā varuṇaḥ / yat yat aichat prajāpatau tat brahmacārī prāyachat svāt mitraḥ adhi ātmanaḥ /
column2: Varuna, made a Master, takes at home the butter to himself. Whatever with Prajāpati he sought, the Brahmachāri gave like Mitra from his loftiest soul.

column1: ācāryaḥ brahmacārī brahmacārī prajāpatiḥ / prajāpatiḥ vi rājati virāj indraḥ abhavat vaśī //
column2: The pupil is the Master, yea, the pupil is Prajāpati. Prajāpati shines bright; the bright Virāj grew potent Indra's self.

column1: brahmacaryeṇa tapasā rājā rāṣṭram vi rakṣati / ācāryaḥ brahmacaryeṇa brahmacāriṇam ichate /
column2: By Fervour and by self-restraint the King protects the realm he rules. By self-restraint the Master seeks a Brahmachari to instruct.

column1: brahmacaryeṇa kanyā yuvānam vindate patim / anaḍvān brahmacaryeṇa aśvaḥ ghāsam jigīṣati //
column2: By self-restraint a maiden finds a youth to be her wedded lord. By self-restraint the ox and horse seek to win fodder for them- selves.

column1: brahmacaryeṇa tapasā devāḥ mṛtyum apāghnata / indraḥ ha brahmacaryeṇa devebhyaḥ svar ābharat //
column2: By Fervour and by self-restraint the Gods draye Death away from them, And Indra brought by self-restraint heaven's lustre to the deities.

column1: # saṃvatsaraḥ saha ṛtubhiḥ te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ // // saṃvatsaraḥ saha ṛtubhiḥ te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ // // saṃvatsaraḥ saha ṛtubhiḥ te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ // // saṃvatsaraḥ saha ṛtubhiḥ te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ // // saṃvatsaraḥ saha ṛtubhiḥ te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ // // saṃvatsaraḥ saha ṛtubhiḥ te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ // // saṃvatsaraḥ saha ṛtubhiḥ te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ // / pārthivāḥ divyāḥ paśavaḥ āraṇyāḥ grāmyāḥ ca ye / apakṣāḥ pakṣiṇaḥ ca ye te jātāḥ brahmacāriṇaḥ /
column2: The plants, what is and what shall be, day, night, the tall tree of the wood, The year with seasons of the year, all from the Brahmachāri sprang. All creatures of the earth and heaven, tame animals and sylvan beasts, Winged and wingless creatures, from the Brahmachāri sprang to life,

column1: pṛthak sarve prājāpatyāḥ prāṇān ātmasu bibhrati / tān sarvān brahma rakṣati brahmacāriṇī ābhṛtam /
column2: All children of Prajāpati have breath distinctly in themselves. The Brahma that is stored within the Brahmachāri guards them all.

column1: devānām etat pariṣūtam an abhyārūḍham carati rocamānam / tasmāt jātam brāhmaṇam brahma jyeṣṭham devāḥ ca sarve amṛtena sākam /
column2: Piled up on high, but never yet ascended, that power of deities is brightly shining. From that sprang heavenly lore, the loftiest Brahma, and all the Gods with, life that lasts for ever.

column1: brahmacārī brahma bhrājat bibharti tasmin devāḥ adhi viśve samotāḥ / prāṇa apānau janayan āt vyānam vācam manaḥ hṛdayam brahma medhām /
column2: The Brahmachāri wields the radiant Brahma wherein all Gods are woven close together; Creating breath, inhaling and exhaling, voice, mind, and heart, Brahma and holy wisdom.

column1: cakṣuḥ śrotram yaśaḥ asmāsu dhehi annam retaḥ lohitam udaram //
column2: Bestow on us the power of sight and hearing, glory and food and seed and blood and belly.

column1: tāni kalpan brahmacārī salilasya pṛṣṭhe tapaḥ atiṣṭhat tapyamānaḥ samudre / sa snātaḥ babhruḥ piṅgalaḥ pṛthivyām bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / bahu rocate / / / / bahu rocate / / / bahu rocate / / / bahu rocate /
column2: These, standing on the flood, the Brahmachāri formed practising in sea his hot devotion. When he hath bathed, brown, yellow-hued, he shines exceedingly on earth.

column1: agnim brūmaḥ vanaspatīn oṣadhīḥ uta vīrudhaḥ / indram bṛhaspatim sūryam te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: We call on Agni, on the trees lords of the forest, herbs and. plants, Indra, Sūrya, Brihaspati: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: brūmaḥ rājānam varuṇam mitram viṣṇum atha u bhagam / aṃśam vivasvantam brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: We call on Vishnu, Bhaga, on Mitra and Varuna the King, Ansa Vivasvān we address: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: brūmaḥ devam savitāram dhātāram uta pūṣaṇam / tvaṣṭāram agriyam brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: We call on Savitar the God, on Pūshan the establisher, Tvashtar the foremost we address: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: gandharva apsarasaḥ brūmaḥ aśvinā brahmaṇaspatim / aryamā nāma yaḥ devaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Gandharvas and Apsarases; the Asvins, Brāhmanaspati, Aryaman, God, by name we call: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: ahar rātre idam brūmaḥ sūryācandramasau ubhā / viśvān ādityān brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: This word of ours to Day and Night, and to the Sun and Moon we speak, All the Ādityas we address: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: vātam brūmaḥ parjanyam antarikṣam atha u diśaḥ / āśāḥ ca sarvāḥ brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Vāta, Parjanya we address, the Quarters, and the Firmament, And all the Regions of the sky: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: muñcantu mā śapathyāt ahar rātre atha u uṣāḥ / somaḥ mā devaḥ muñcatu yam āhuḥ candramāḥ iti /
column2: From all that brings a curse may Day and Night and Dawn deliver me, May Soma free me, God to whom they give the name of Chan- dramās.

column1: pārthivāḥ divyāḥ paśavaḥ āraṇyāḥ uta ye mṛgāḥ / śakuntān pakṣiṇaḥ brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: All creatures both of heaven and earth, wild beasts and sylvan animals, And winged birds of air we call: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: bhava śarvau idam brūmaḥ rudram paśupatiḥ ca yaḥ / iṣūḥ yāḥ eṣām saṃvidma tāḥ naḥ santu sadā śivāḥ /
column2: Bhava and Sarva we address, and Rudra who is Lord of Beasts, Their arrows which we feel and know: may they be ever kind to us.
We speak to Constellations, Heaven, to Earth, to Genii, and to Hills, To Seas, to Rivers, and to Lakes: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: sapta ṛṣīn vai idam brūmaḥ apaḥ devīḥ prajāpatim / pitṝn yama śreṣṭhān brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Or the Seven Rishis we address, Waters divine, Prajāpati, Fathers with Yama at their head: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: ye devāḥ diviṣadaḥ antarikṣa sadaḥ ca ye / pṛthivyām śakrāḥ ye śritāḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Gods whose abode is in the heaven and those who dwell in middle air, And Mighty ones who rest on earth: may they deliver us from. woe.

column1: ādityāḥ rudrāḥ vasavaḥ divi devāḥ atharvāṇaḥ / aṅgirasaḥ manīṣiṇaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Ādityas, Rudra, Vasus, Gods aloft in heaven, Atharvan's sons, The sages, sons of Angiras: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: yajñam brūmaḥ yajamānam ṛcaḥ sāmāni bheṣajā / yajūṃṣi hotrāḥ brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: To sacrifice, to worshipper, hymns, songs, and healing charms, we speak, To priestly acts and Yajus texts: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: pañca rājyāni vīrudhām soma śreṣṭhāni brūmaḥ / darbhaḥ bhaṅgaḥ yavaḥ sahaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: To the five kingdoms of the plants which Soma rules as Lord we speak. Darbha, hemp, barley, mighty power: may these deliver us from woe,

column1: arāyān brūmaḥ rakṣāṃsi sarpān puṇyajanān pitṝn / mṛtyūn eka śatam brūmaḥ te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ / ṛtūn brūmaḥ ṛtupatīn ārtavān uta hāyanān / samāḥ saṃvatsarān māsān te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: To demons and fierce fiends we speak, to Holy Genii, Fathers,. Snakes, And to the hundred deaths and one: may these deliver us from woe. We speak to Seasons, Season-Lords, to years and sections of the year, To Months, half-months, and years complete: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: eta devāḥ dakṣiṇatas paścāt prāñcaḥ udeta / purastāt uttarāt śakrāḥ viśve devāḥ sametya te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ / viśvān devān idam brūmaḥ satya sandhān ṛtāvṛdhaḥ / viśvābhiḥ patnībhiḥ saha te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Come hither from the south, ye Gods, rise and come forward from the west. Gathered together, all ye Gods, ye mighty Ones, from east and and north: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: sarvān devān idam brūmaḥ satya sandhān ṛtāvṛdhaḥ / sarvābhiḥ patnībhiḥ saha te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: This we address to all the Gods, faithful, maintainers of the Right, With all their Consorts by their side: may they deliver us from woe.

column1: bhūtam brūmaḥ bhūta patim bhūtānām uta yaḥ vaśī / bhūtāni sarvā saṃgatya te naḥ muñcantu aṃhasaḥ /
column2: The spirit, yea, the spirits' Lord, ruler of spirits, we address. Together let all spirits meet: may these deliver us from woe.

column1: yāḥ devīḥ pañca pradiśaḥ ye devāḥ dvādaśa ṛtavaḥ / saṃvatsarasya ye daṃṣṭrāḥ te naḥ santu sadā śivāḥ /
column2: The five Sky regions, Goddesses, and the twelve Seasons which are Gods. The teeth of the completed year, may these deliver us from woe.

column1: yat mātalī ratha krītam amṛtam veda bheṣajam / tat indraḥ apsu prāveśayat tat āpaḥ datta bheṣajam // tat indraḥ apsu prāveśayat tat āpaḥ datta bheṣajam // tat indraḥ apsu prāveśayat tat āpaḥ datta bheṣajam // tat indraḥ apsu prāveśayat tat āpaḥ datta bheṣajam // tat indraḥ apsu prāveśayat tat āpaḥ datta bheṣajam // tat indraḥ apsu prāveśayat tat āpaḥ datta bheṣajam // tat indraḥ apsu prāveśayat tat āpaḥ datta bheṣajam // tat indr
column2: The deathless balm that Mātalī knows, purchased at a chariot's price, Indra effused into the floods. Waters, give us that healing balm!

column1: ucchiṣṭe nāma rūpam ca ucchiṣṭe loke āhitaḥ / ucchiṣṭaḥ indraḥ ca agniḥ ca viśvam antar samāhitam /
column2: The Residue of Sacrifice containeth name, and from, and world: Indra and Agni and the whole universe are comprised therein.

column1: ucchiṣṭe dyāvāpṛthivī viśvam bhūtam samāhitam / āpaḥ samudraḥ ucchiṣṭe candramāḥ vātaḥ āhitaḥ /
column2: The Residue of Sacrifice holdeth Earth, Heaven, and all that is: The Residue of Sacrifice holdeth sea, waters, Moon, and Wind.

column1: san ucchiṣṭe asan ca ubhau mṛtyuḥ vājaḥ prajāpatiḥ / laukyāḥ ucchiṣṭe āyattāḥ vraḥ ca draḥ ca api śrīḥ mayi //
column2: Real, non-real, both are there, Prajāpati, and Death, and strength: Thereon depend the worldly ones: in me are glory Dra and Vra.

column1: dṛḍhaḥ dṛṃha sthiraḥ nyaḥ brahma viśvasṛjaḥ daśa / nābhim iva sarvatas cakram ucchiṣṭe devatāḥ śritāḥ /
column2: The firm, the fast, the strong, the hard, Brahma, the All-creating Ten. Gods, as a wheel about the nave, are fixed all round the Residue.

column1: ṛc sāma yajuḥ ucchiṣṭaḥ udgīthaḥ prastutam stutam / hiṅkāraḥ ucchiṣṭe svaraḥ sāmnaḥ meḍiḥ ca tat mayi /
column2: Verse, Song, and Sacrificial Text, chanting, the prelude, and the laud, The hum is in the Residue, the tone, the murmur of the psalm.

column1: aindrāgnam pāvamānam mahānāmnīḥ mahāvratam / ucchiṣṭe yajñasya aṅgāni antar garbhe iva mātari /
column2: Within the Residue, like babes unborn, the parts of sacrifice, Aindrāgne Pāvamāna lie. Mahānāmnī, Mahavrata.

column1: rājasūyam vājapeyam agniṣṭomaḥ tat adhvaraḥ / arka aśvamedhau ucchiṣṭe jīvabarhiḥ madintamaḥ /
column2: The Vājapeya, Royal Rite, the Agnishoma and its forms, Hymns, joyfullest with living grass the Asvamedha, are therein,

column1: agnyādheyam atha u dīkṣā kāmapraḥ chandasā saha / utsannāḥ yajñāḥ satrāṇi ucchiṣṭe adhi samāhitāḥ / agnihotram ca śraddhā ca vaṣaṭkāraḥ vratam tapaḥ / dakṣiṇeṣṭam pūrtam ca ucchiṣṭe adhi samāhitāḥ /
column2: Dikshā and Agnyādheya rite that sates the wish, with magic- hymn, Suspended rites, long sessions, are contained within the Residue. Faith fire-oblation, fervent zeal, service, and sacrificial cry, Guerdon, good works and their reward, are stored within the Residue.

column1: # eka rātraḥ dvi rātraḥ sadyaḥkrīḥ prakrīḥ ukthyaḥ / otam nihitam ucchiṣṭe yajñasya aṇūni vidyayā // // /| /| /| // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // // /| /
column2: Sacrifice of one night, or two, Sadya1 kri, Ukthya, and Prakri, Call, deep-toned summons are therein, fine parts, through lore, of sacrifice,

column1: catur rātraḥ pañca rātraḥ ṣaṣ rātraḥ ca ubhayaḥ saha / ṣoḍaśī sapta rātraḥ ca ucchiṣṭāt jajñire sarve ye yajñāḥ amṛte hitāḥ /
column2: Sacrifice of four nights, of five, of six nights, day and night conjoined, Shodai, seven-night sacrifice, all these sprang from the Residue, these which the Immortal One contains.

column1: pratīhāraḥ nidhanam viśvajit ca abhijit ca yaḥ / sāhnā atirātrau ucchiṣṭe dvādaśa ahaḥ api tat mayi /
column2: Pratihāra and Nidhanam, the Visvajit, the Abhijit, The two Sāhnātirātrās and Twelve-day rite are stored therein.

column1: sūnṛtā saṃnatiḥ kṣemaḥ svadhā ūrjā amṛtam sahaḥ / ucchiṣṭe sarve pratyañcaḥ kāmāḥ kāmena tātṛpuḥ /
column2: Pleasantness, reverence, peace, and power, strength, vigour, immortality All forward wishes are with love satisfied in the Residue.

column1: nava bhūmīḥ samudrāḥ ucchiṣṭe adhi śritāḥ divaḥ / ā sūryaḥ bhāti ucchiṣṭe ahar rātre api tat mayi //
column2: Nine several oceans, earths, and skies are set within, the Residue, Bright shines the Sun therein, in me, the Residue, are Day and Night.

column1: upahavyam viṣūvantam ye ca yajñāḥ guhā hitāḥ / bibharti bhartā viśvasya ucchiṣṭaḥ janituḥ pitā /
column2: The Residue the Father's sire, who bears this universe, supports Vishūvān, Upahavya, and all worship offered secretly.

column1: pitā janituḥ ucchiṣṭaḥ asoḥ pautraḥ pitāmahaḥ / sa kṣiyati viśvasya īśānaḥ vṛṣā bhūmyām atighnyaḥ //
column2: The Father's sire, the Residue, grandson of Spirit, primal Sire, Lord of the universe, the Bull, dwells on the earth victorious.

column1: ṛtam satyam tapaḥ rāṣṭram śramaḥ dharmaḥ ca karma ca / bhūtam bhaviṣyat ucchiṣṭe vīryam lakṣmīḥ balam bale /
column2: Right, truth, dominion, fervent zeal, toil, duty, action, future, past, Valour; prosperity, and strength dwell in the Residue in strength.

column1: samṛddhiḥ ojaḥ ākūtiḥ kṣatram rāṣṭram ṣaṭ urvyaḥ / saṃvatsaraḥ adhi ucchiṣṭaḥ iḍā praiṣāḥ grahāḥ haviḥ /
column2: Welfare, resolve and energy, the six expanses, kingship, sway, Prayer, and direction, and the year, oblation, planets, are there- in;

column2: Truth, high and potent Law, the Consecrating Rite, Fervour, Brahma, and Sacrifice uphold the Earth. May she, the Queen of all that is and is to be, may Prithivī make ample space and room for us.

column1: asaṃbādham madhyataḥ mānavānām yasyāḥ udvataḥ pravataḥ samam bahu / nānā vīryāḥ oṣadhīḥ yā bibharti pṛthivī naḥ prathatām rādhyatām naḥ /
column2: Not over awded by the crowd of Manu's sons, she who hath many heights and floods and level plains; She who bears plants endowed with many varied powers, may Prithivī for us spread wide and favour us.

column1: yasyām samudraḥ uta sindhuḥ āpaḥ yasyām annam kṛṣṭayaḥ saṃbabhūvuḥ / yasyām idam jinvati prāṇat ejat sā naḥ bhūmiḥ pūrvapeye dadhātu //
column2: In whom the sea, and Sindhu, and the waters, in whom our food and corn-lands had their being, In whom this all that breathes and moves is active, this Earth. assign us foremost rank and station!

column1: yasyāḥ catasraḥ pradiśaḥ pṛthivyāḥ yasyām annam kṛṣṭayaḥ saṃbabhūvuḥ / yā bibharti bahudhā prāṇat ejat sā naḥ bhūmiḥ goṣu api anne dadhātu //
column2: She who is Lady of the earth's four regions, in whom our food and corn-lands had their being, Nurse in each place of breathing, moving creatures, this Earth. vouchsafe us kine with milk that fails not!

column1: yasyām pūrve pūrva janāḥ vicakrire yasyām devāḥ asurān abhyavartayan / gavām aśvānām vayasaḥ ca viṣṭhā bhagam varcaḥ pṛthivī naḥ dadhātu //
column2: On whom the men of old before us battled, on whom the Gods attacked the hostile demons, The varied home of bird, and kine and horses, this Prithivī vouchsafe us luck and splendour!

column1: viśvaṃbharā vasu dhānī pratiṣṭhā hiraṇya vakṣāḥ jagataḥ niveśanī / vaiśvānaram bibhratī bhūmiḥ agnim indra ṛṣabhā draviṇe naḥ dadhātu /
column2: Firm standing-place, all-bearing, store of treasures, gold-breasted, harbourer of all that moveth. May Earth who bears Agni Vaisvānara, Consort of mighty Indra, give us great possessions

column1: yām rakṣanti asvapnāḥ viśvadānīm devāḥ bhūmim pṛthivīm apramādam / sā naḥ madhu priyam duhām atha u ukṣatu varcasā /
column2: May Earth, may Prithivī, always protected with ceaseless care by Gods who never slumber, May she pour out for us delicious nectar, may she bedew us with a flood of splendour.

column1: yā arṇave adhi salilam agre āsīt yām māyābhiḥ anvacarat manīṣiṇaḥ / yasyāḥ hṛdayam parame vyoman satyena āvṛtam amṛtam pṛthivyāḥ / sā naḥ bhūmiḥ tviṣim balam rāṣṭre dadhātu uttame /
column2: She who at first was water in the ocean, whom with their wond- rous powers the sages followed, May she whose heart is in the highest heaven, compassed about wit h truth, and everlasting, May she, this Earth, bestow upon us lustre, and grant us power in loftiest dominion.

column1: yasyām āpaḥ paricarāḥ samānīḥ ahar rātre apramādam kṣaranti / sā naḥ bhūmiḥ bhūri dhārā payaḥ duhām atha u ukṣatu varcasā /
column2: On whom the running universal waters flow day and night with never-ceasing motion, May she with many streams pour milk to feed us, may she bedew us with a flood of splendour.

column2: She whom the Asvins measured out, o'er whom the foot of Vishnu strode, Whom Indra, Lord of Power and Might, freed from all foemen for himself, May Earth pour out her milk for us, a mother unto me her son.

column1: girayaḥ te parvatāḥ himavantaḥ araṇyam te pṛthivi syonam astu / babhrum kṛṣṇām rohiṇīm viśva rūpām dhruvām bhūmim pṛthivīm indra guptām / a jītaḥ a hataḥ akṣataḥ adhi aṣṭhām pṛthivīm aham /
column2: O Prithivī, auspicious be thy woodlands, auspicious be thy hills and snow-clad mountains. Unslain, unwounded, unsubdued, I have set foot upon the Earth, On earth brown, black, ruddy and every-coloured, on the firm earth that Indra guards from danger.

column1: yat te madhyam pṛthivi yat ca nabhyam yāḥ te ūrjaḥ tanvaḥ saṃbabhūvuḥ / tāsu naḥ dhehi abhi naḥ pavasva mātā bhūmiḥ putraḥ aham pṛthivyāḥ parjanyaḥ pitā saḥ u naḥ pipartu //
column2: O Prithivī, thy centre and thy navel, all forces that have issued from thy body Set us amid those forces; breathe upon us. I am the son of Earth, Earth is my Mother. Parjanya is my Sire; may he promote me.

column1: yasyām vedim parigṛhṇanti bhūmyām yasyām yajñam tanvate viśvakarmāṇaḥ / yasyām mīyante svaravaḥ pṛthivyām ūrdhvāḥ śukrāḥ āhutyāḥ purastāt / sā naḥ bhūmiḥ vardhayat vardhamānā /
column2: Earth on whose surface they enclose the altar, and all-performers spin the thread of worship; In whom the stakes of sacrifice, resplendent, are fixed and raised on high before the oblation, may she, this Earth, prospering, make us prosper.

column1: yaḥ naḥ dveṣat pṛthivi yaḥ pṛtanyāt yaḥ abhidāsāt manasā yaḥ vadhena / tam naḥ bhūme randhaya pūrva kṛtvari /
column2: The man who hates us, Earth! who fights against us, who threaten us with thought or deadly weapon, make him our thrall as thou hast done aforetime.

column1: tvat jātāḥ tvayi caranti martyāḥ tvam bibharṣi dvipadaḥ tvam catuṣpadaḥ / tava ime pṛthivi pañca mānavāḥ yebhyaḥ jyotiḥ amṛtam martyebhyaḥ udyan sūryaḥ raśmibhiḥ ātanoti //
column2: Produced from thee, on thee move mortal creatures: thou bearest them, both quadruped and biped. Thine, Prithivī, are these Five human Races, for whom, though mortal, Sūrya as he rises spreads with his rays the light that is immortal.

column1: tāḥ naḥ prajāḥ sam duhratām samagrāḥ vācaḥ madhu pṛthivi dhehi mahyam //
column2: In concert may these creatures yield us blessings. With honey of discourse, O Earth, endow me.

column1: viśvasvam mātaram oṣadhīnām dhruvām bhūmim pṛthivīm dharmaṇā dhṛtām / śivām syonām anu carema viśvahā /
column2: Kind, ever gracious be the Earth we tread on, the firm Earth, Prithivī, borne up by Order, mother of plants and herbs, the all-producer.

column1: mahat sadhastham mahatī babhūvitha mahān vegaḥ ejathuḥ vepathuḥ te / mahān tvā indraḥ rakṣati apramādam / sā naḥ bhūme pra rocaya hiraṇyasya iva saṃdṛśi mā naḥ dvikṣata kaḥ cana /
column2: A vast abode hast thou become, the Mighty. Great stress is on thee, press and agitation, but with unceasing care great Indra guards thee. So make us shine, O Earth, us with the splendour of gold. Let no man look on us with hatred.

column1: agniḥ bhūmyām oṣadhīṣu agnim āpaḥ bibhrati agniḥ aśmasu / agniḥ antar puruṣeṣu goṣu aśveṣu agnayaḥ /
column2: Agni is in the earth, in plants; the waters hold Agni in them, in the stones is Agni. Agni abideth deep in men: Agnis abide in cows and steeds.

column2: Agni gives shine and heat in heaven: the spacious air is his, the God's Lover of fatness, bearer of oblation, men enkindle him.

column1: agni vāsāḥ pṛthivī asitajñūḥ tviṣīmantam saṃśitam mā kṛṇotu //
column2: Dark-kneed, invested with a fiery mantle, Prithivī sharpen me and give me splendour!

column1: bhūmyām devebhyaḥ dadati yajñam havyam araṃkṛtam / bhūmyām manuṣyāḥ jīvanti svadhayā annena martyāḥ / sā naḥ bhūmiḥ prāṇam āyuḥ dadhātu jaradaṣṭim mā pṛthivī kṛṇotu /
column2: On earth they offer sacrifice and dressed oblation to the Gods. Men, mortals, live upon the earth by food in their accustomed way. May that Earth grant us breath and vital power. Prithivī give me life of long duration!

column1: yaḥ te gandhaḥ pṛthivi saṃbabhūva yam bibhrati oṣadhayaḥ yam āpaḥ / yam gandharvāḥ apsarasaḥ ca bhejire tena mā surabhim kṛṇu mā naḥ dvikṣata kaḥ cana /
column2: Scent that hath risen from thee, O Earth, the fragrance which. growing herbs and plants and waters carry, Shared by Apsarases, shared by Gandharvas therewith make thou me sweet: let no man hate me.

column1: yaḥ te gandhaḥ puṣkaram āviveśa yam saṃjabhruḥ sūryāyāḥ vivāhe / amartyāḥ pṛthivi gandham agre tena mā surabhim kṛṇu mā naḥ dvikṣata kaḥ cana /
column2: Thy scent which entered and possessed the lotus, the scent which they prepared at Sūryā's bridal, Scent which Immortals Earth! of old collected, therewith make thou me sweet: let no man hate me.

column1: yaḥ te gandhaḥ puruṣeṣu strīṣu puṃsu bhagaḥ ruciḥ / yaḥ aśveṣu vīreṣu yaḥ mṛgeṣu uta hastiṣu / kanyāyām varcaḥ yat bhūme tena asmān api sam sṛja mā naḥ dvikṣata kaḥ cana /
column2: Thy scent in women and in men, the luck and light that is in. males, That is in heroes and in steeds in sylvan beasts and elephants, The splendid energy of maids, therewith do thou unite us,. Earth! Let no man look on us with hate.

column1: śilā bhūmiḥ aśmā pāṃsuḥ sā bhūmiḥ saṃdhṛtā dhṛtā / tasyai hiraṇya vakṣase pṛthivyāḥ akaram namaḥ /
column2: Rock earth, and stone, and dust, this Earth is held together,. firmly bound. To this gold-breasted Prithivī mine adoration have I paid.

column1: yasyām vṛkṣāḥ vānaspatyāḥ dhruvāḥ tiṣṭhanti viśvahā / pṛthivīm viśva dhāyasam dhṛtām achāvadāmasi //
column2: Hither we call the firmly held, the all-supporting Prithivī, On whom the trees, lords of the wood, stand evermore immov- able.

column1: udīrāṇāḥ uta āsīnāḥ tiṣṭhantaḥ prakrāmantaḥ / padbhyām dakṣiṇa savyābhyām mā vyathiṣmahi bhūmyām /
column2: Sitting at ease or rising up, standing or going on our way. With our right foot and with our left we will not reel upon the earth.

column1: vimṛgvarīm pṛthivīm ā vadāmi kṣamām bhūmim brahmaṇā vāvṛdhānām / ūrjam puṣṭam bibhratīm anna bhāgam ghṛtam tvā abhi ni sīdema bhūme / # pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛthivi mā ud punāmi // pavitreṇa pṛt
column2: I speak to Prithivī the purifier, to patient Earth who groweth strong through Brahma. O Earth, may we recline on thee who bearest strength, increase, portioned share of food, and fatness. Purified for our bodies flow the waters: we bring distress on him who would attack us. I cleanse myself, O Earth, with that which cleanseth. Earth, be thine eastern and thy northern regions, those lying southward and those lying westward. Propitious unto me in all my movements. Long as I tread the ground let me not stumble.

column1: mā naḥ paścāt mā purastāt nudiṣṭhāḥ mā uttarāt adharāt uta / svasti bhūme naḥ bhava mā vidan paripanthinaḥ varīyaḥ yāvaya vadham /
column2: Drive us not from the west or east, drive us not from the north or south, Be gracious unto us, O Earth: let not the robbers find us; keep the deadly weapon far away.

column1: yāvat te abhi vipaśyāmi bhūme sūryeṇa medinā / tāvat me cakṣuḥ mā mā iṣṭa uttarām uttarām samām /
column2: Long as, on thee, I look around, possessing Sūrya as a friend, So long, through each succeeding year, let not my power of vision fail.

column1: yat śayānaḥ paryāvarte dakṣiṇam sakhyam abhi bhūme pārśvam uttānāḥ tvā pratīcīm yat pṛṣṭībhiḥ adhiśemahe / mā hiṃsīḥ tatra naḥ bhūme sarvasya pratiśīvari //
column2: When, as I lie, O Earth, I turn upon my right side and my left, When stretched at all our length we lay our ribs on thee who meetest us. Do us no injury there, O Earth who furnishest a bed for all.

column1: yat te bhūme vikhanāmi kṣipram tat api rohatu / mā te marma vimṛgvari mā te hṛdayam arpipam /
column2: Let what I dig from thee, O Earth, rapidly spring and grow again. O Purifier, let me not pierce through thy vitals or thy heart.

column1: grīṣmaḥ te bhūme varṣāṇi śarad dhemantaḥ śiśiraḥ vasantaḥ / ṛtavaḥ te vihitāḥ hāyanīḥ ahar rātre pṛthivi naḥ duhātām //
column2: Earth, may thy summer, and thy rains, and autumn, thy winter, and thy dewy frosts, and spring-time. May thy years, Prithivī! and ordered seasons, and day and night pour out for us abundance.

column1: yā apa sarpam vijamānā vimṛgvarī yasyām āsan agnayaḥ ye apsu antar / parā dasyūn dadatī deva pīyūn indram vṛṇānā pṛthivī na vṛtram śakrāya dadhre vṛṣabhāya vṛṣṇe /
column2: The purifier, shrinking from the Serpent, she who held fires that lie within the waters, Who gives as prey the God-blaspheming Dasyus, Earth choosing Indra for her Lord, not Vritra, hath clung to Sakra, to the Strong and Mighty.

column1: yasyām sadaḥ havirdhāne yūpaḥ yasyām nimīyate / brahmāṇaḥ yasyām arcanti ṛgbhiḥ sāmnā yajuḥ vidaḥ yujyante yasyām ṛtvijaḥ somam indrāya pātave /
column2: Base of the seat and sheds, on whom the sacrificial stake is reared, On whom the Yajus-knowing priests recite their hymns and chant their psalms, And ministers are busied that Indra may drink the Soma juice;

column1: yasyām pūrve bhūta kṛtaḥ ṛṣayaḥ gāḥ udānṛcuḥ / sapta satreṇa vedhasaḥ yajñena tapasā saha /
column2: On whom the ancient Rishis, they who made the world, sang forth the cows, Seven worshippers, by session, with their fervent zeal and sacrifice;

column1: sā naḥ bhūmiḥ ā diśatu yat dhanam kāmayāmahe / bhagaḥ anuprayuṅktām indraḥ etu purogavaḥ // // //
column2: May she, the Earth, assign to us the opulence for which we yearn, May Bhaga share and aid the task and Indra come to lead the way.

column1: yasyām gāyanti nṛtyanti bhūmyām martyāḥ vyailabāḥ / yudhyante yasyām ākrandaḥ yasyām vadati dundubhiḥ / sā naḥ bhūmiḥ pra nudatām sapatnān asapatnam mā pṛthivī kṛṇotu //
column2: May she, the Earth, whereon men sing and dance with varied shout and noise, Whereon men meet in battle, and the war-cry and the drum resound, May she drive off our foemen, may Prithivī rid me of my foes.

column1: yasyām annam vrīhi yavau yasyāḥ imāḥ pañca kṛṣṭayaḥ / bhūmyai parjanya patnyai namaḥ astu varṣamedase /
column2: On whom is food, barley and rice, to whom these Races Five belong, Homage to her, P arjanya's wife, to her whose marrow is the rain!

column1: yasyāḥ puras deva kṛtāḥ kṣetre yasyāḥ vikurvate / prajāpatiḥ pṛthivīm viśva garbhām āśām āśām raṇyām naḥ kṛṇotu //
column2: Whose castles are the work of Gods, and men wage war upon her plain The Lord of Life make Prithivī, who beareth all things in her womb, pleasant to us on every side!

column1: nidhim bibhratī bahudhā guhā vasu maṇim hiraṇyam pṛthivī dadātu me / vasūni naḥ vasu dāḥ rāsamānā devī dadhātu sumanasyamānā /
column2: May Earth the Goddess, she who bears her treasure stored up in many a place, gold, gems, and riches, Giver of opulence, grant great possessions to us bestowing them with love and favour.

column1: janam bibhratī bahudhā vivācasam nānā dharmāṇam pṛthivī yathaukasam / sahasram dhārāḥ draviṇasya me duhām dhruvā iva dhenuḥ an apasphurantī /
column2: Earth, bearing folk of many a varied language with divers rites as suits their dwelling-places, Pour, like a constant cow that never faileth, a thousand streams of treasure to enrich me!

column1: yaḥ te sarpaḥ vṛścikaḥ tṛṣṭa daṃśmā hemanta jabdhaḥ bhṛmalaḥ guhā śaye / krimiḥ jinvat pṛthivi yat yat ejati prāvṛṣi tat naḥ sarpat mā upa sṛpat yat śivam tena naḥ mṛḍa /
column2: Thy snake, thy sharply stinging scorpion, lying concealed, be- wildered, chilled with cold of winter, The worm, O Prithivī, each thing that in the Rains revives and stirs, Creeping, forbear to creep on us! With all things gracious bless thou us.

column1: ye te panthānaḥ bahavaḥ janāyanāḥ rathasya vartmānasaḥ ca yātave / yaiḥ saṃcaranti ubhaye bhadra pāpāḥ tam panthānam jayema anamitram ataskaram yat śivam tena naḥ mṛḍa //
column2: Thy many ways on which the people travel, the road for car and wain to journey over, Thereon meet both the good and bad, that pathway may we attain without a foe or robber. With all things gracious bless thou us.

column1: malvam bibhratī guru bhṛt bhadra pāpasya nidhanam titikṣuḥ / varāheṇa pṛthivī saṃvidānā sūkarāya vi jihīte mṛgāya /
column2: Supporting both the foolish and the weighty she bears the death both of the good and evil. In friendly concord with the boar, Earth opens herself for the wild swine that roams the forest.

column1: ye te āraṇyāḥ paśavaḥ mṛgāḥ vane hitāḥ siṃhāḥ vyāghrāḥ puruṣādaḥ caranti / ulam vṛkam pṛthivi duchunām itas ṛkṣīkām rakṣaḥ apa bādhaya asmat /
column2: All sylvan beasts of thine that love the woodlands, man-eaters,. forest-haunting, lions, tigers, Hyena, wolf, Misfortune, evil spirit, drive from us, chase the demons to a distance.

column1: ye gandharvāḥ apsarasaḥ ye cārāyāḥ kimīdinaḥ / piśācān sarvā rakṣāṃsi tān asmat bhūme yāvaya // // //
column2: Gandharvas and Apsarases, Kimīdins, and malignant sprites, Pisāchas all, and Rākshasas, these keep thou, Earth! afar from us.

column1: yām dvipādaḥ pakṣiṇaḥ saṃpatanti haṃsāḥ suparṇāḥ śakunāḥ vayāṃsi / yasyām vātaḥ mātariśvā īyate rajāṃsi kṛṇvan cyāvayan ca vṛkṣān / vātasya pravām upavām anu vāti arciḥ /
column2: To whom the winged bipeds fly together, birds of each various kind, the swans, the eagles; On whom the Wind comes rushing, Mātarisvan, rousing the dust and causing trees to tremble, and flame pursues the blast. hither and thither;

column1: yasyām kṛṣṇam aruṇam ca saṃhite ahar rātre vihite bhūmyām adhi / varṣeṇa bhūmiḥ pṛthivī vṛtā āvṛtā sā naḥ dadhātu bhadrayā priye dhāmani dhāmani //
column2: Earth, upon whom are settled, joined together, the night and day, the dusky and the ruddy, Prithivī compassed by the rain about her, Happily may she stablish us in each delightful dwelling place.

column1: dyauḥ ca me idam pṛthivī ca antarikṣam ca me vyacaḥ / agniḥ sūryaḥ āpaḥ medhām viśve devāḥ ca sam daduḥ /
column2: Heaven, Earth, the realm of Middle Air have granted me this ample room, Agni, Sun, Waters, all the Gods have joined to give me mental power.

column1: aham asmi sahamānaḥ uttaraḥ nāma bhūmyām / abhīṣāh asmi viśvāṣāh āśām āśām viṣāsahiḥ //
column2: I am victorious, I am called the lord superior on earth, Triumphant, all-o'erpowering the conqueror on every side

column1: adaḥ yat devi prathamānā purastāt devaiḥ uktā vyasarpaḥ mahitvam / ā tvā subhūtam aviśat tadānīm akalpayathāḥ pradiśaḥ catasraḥ /
column2: There, when the Gods, O Goddess, named thee, spreading thy wide expanse as thou wast broadening eastward, Then into thee passed many a charm and glory: thou madest for thyself the world's four regions.

column1: ye grāmāḥ yat araṇyam yāḥ sabhāḥ adhi bhūmyām / ye saṃgrāmāḥ samitayaḥ teṣu cāru vadema te /
column2: In hamlets and in woodland, and in all assemblages on earth, In gatherings, meeting of the folk, we will speak glorious things of thee.

column1: aśvaḥ iva rajaḥ dudhuve vi tān janān yaḥ ākṣiyan pṛthivīm yāt ajāyata / mandrā agretvarī bhuvanasya gopāḥ vanaspatīnām gṛbhiḥ oṣadhīnām /
column2: As the horse scattereth the dust, the people who dwelt upon the land, at birth, she scattered, Leader and head of all the world, delightful, the trees' protectress and the plants' upholder.
