column1: yoge yoge tavastaram vājevāje havāmahe / sakhāyaḥ indram ūtaye /
column2: In every need, in every fray we call, as friends, to succour us, Indra the mightiest of all.

column1: hiraṇya varṇaḥ ajaraḥ su vīraḥ jarā mṛtyuḥ prajayā sam viśasva / tat agniḥ āha tat u somaḥ āha bṛhaspatiḥ savitā tat indraḥ /
column2: Gold-coloured, undecaying, blest with heroes, dwell, dying in old age, with children round thee. This is the spoken word of Agni, Soma, Brihaspati and Savitar, and Indra.

column1: a śrāntasya tvā manasā yunajmi prathamasya ca / utkūlam udvahaḥ bhava uduhya prati dhāvatāt /
column2: I yoke thee with the mind of one unwearied still and first of all. Be thou a bearer up the hill: run hither bearing up thy load.

column1: agneḥ prajātam pari yat hiraṇyam amṛtam dadhre adhi martyeṣu / yaḥ enat veda saḥ id enam arhati jarā mṛtyuḥ bhavati yaḥ bibharti //
column2: Gold that was born from Fire is immortal hath been deposited with mortal creatures. He who knows this deserves to own this jewel, and in extreme old age dies he who wears it.

column1: yat dhiraṇyam sūryeṇa suvarṇam prajāvantaḥ manavaḥ pūrve īṣire / tat tvā candram varcasā sam sṛjati āyuṣmān bhavati yaḥ bibharti //
column2: The men of ancient time with children round them longed for this Gold, bright with the Sun's own colour, This shall endow thee, as it shines, with splendour, and long shall be the life of him who wears it.

column1: āyuṣe tvā varcase tvā ojase ca balāya ca / yathā hiraṇya tejasā vibhāsāsi janān anu /
column2: Long life and splendour let it bring energy and strength to thee. That thou mayst shine among the folk with all the brightness of the Gold.

column1: yat veda rājā varuṇaḥ veda devaḥ bṛhaspatiḥ / indraḥ yat vṛtra hā veda tat te āyuṣyam bhuvat tat te varcasyam bhuvat /
column2: What Varuna the King knows well, and what the God Brihaspati, And Indra, Slayer of the Foe, may that bestow long life on thee, may that increase thy splendid strength.

column1: gobhiḥ tvā pātu ṛṣabhaḥ vṛṣā tvā pātu vājibhiḥ / vāyuḥ tvā brahmaṇā pātu indraḥ tvā pātu indriyaiḥ /
column2: Let the Bull guard thee with the kine, the Stallien with the fleet- foot steeds. Let Vāyu keep thee safe with prayer, and Indra with his mighty power.

column1: somaḥ tvā pātu oṣadhībhiḥ nakṣatraiḥ pātu sūryaḥ / mādbhyaḥ tvā candraḥ vṛtra hā vātaḥ prāṇena rakṣatu /
column2: Let Soma guard thee with the plants, Sūrya protect thee with the stars; With breath let Wind protect thee, and the Moon, foe-slayer, with the months.

column1: tisraḥ divaḥ tisraḥ pṛthivīḥ trīṇi antarikṣāṇi caturaḥ samudrān / trivṛtam stomam trivṛtaḥ āpaḥ āhuḥ tāḥ tvā rakṣantu trivṛtā trivṛdbhiḥ /
column2: Three are the earths, they say, and three the heavens, three are the atmospheres, and four the oceans. Threefold the hymn of praise, threefold the Waters. Let these with triple song and triplets guard thee.

column1: trīn nākān trīn samudrān trīn bradhnān trīn vaiṣṭapān / trīn mātariśvanaḥ trīn sūryān goptṝn kalpayāmi te /
column2: Three vaults of heaven, and three seas, three bright, three stationary ones, Three Mātarisvans, and three suns, protectors, I arrange for thee.

column1: ghṛtena tvā sam ukṣāmi agne ājyena vardhayan / agneḥ candrasya sūryasya mā prāṇam māyinaḥ dabhan //
column2: Increasing thee with butter I, Agni! with fatness sprinkle thee. Let not magicians harm the life of Agni or of Moon or Sun.

column1: mā vaḥ prāṇam mā vaḥ apānam mā haraḥ māyinaḥ dabhan / bhrājantaḥ viśva vedasaḥ devāḥ daivyena dhāvata /
column2: Let not magicians mar your heat, your vital or diffusive breath. Brilliant and all-possessing Gods, run ye your course with God- like power.

column1: prāṇena agnim sam sṛjati vātaḥ prāṇena saṃhitaḥ / prāṇena viśvatomukham sūryam devāḥ ajanayan //
column2: Fire they endow with vital breath, Wind is compact, with vital breath: With vital breath the Gods produced the Sun whose face turn every way.

column1: āyuṣā āyuḥ kṛtām jīva āyuṣmān jīva mā mṛthāḥ / prāṇena ātmanvatām jīva mā mṛtyoḥ ud agāḥ vaśam //
column2: Live with the Life-Creators' life. Die not, live on to lengthened age. Live with the breath of men with souls. Submit not to the power of Death.

column1: devānām nihitam nidhim yam indraḥ anvavindat pathibhiḥ deva yānaiḥ / āpaḥ hiraṇyam jugupuḥ trivṛdbhiḥ tāḥ tvā rakṣantu trivṛtā trivṛdbhiḥ //
column2: The secret treasure of the Gods which Indra, by pathways travelled by the Gods, discovered, That gold the Waters with the triplets guarded. May they keep thee with threebold hymn and triplets.

column1: trayastriṃśat devatāḥ trīṇi ca vīryāṇi priyāyamāṇāḥ jugupuḥ apsu antar / asmin candre adhi yat hiraṇyam tena ayam kṛṇavat vīryāṇi //
column2: With friendly thoughts the Deities, three-and thirty, and three great Powers preserved it in the Waters. He made heroic powers with the gold that lies upon this Moon.

column1: ye devāḥ divi ekādaśa stha te devāsaḥ haviḥ idam juṣadhvam // ye devāḥ antarikṣe ekādaśa stha te devāsaḥ haviḥ idam juṣadhvam //
column2: O ye eleven Gods who are in heaven, accept this sacrifice. O ye eleven Gods who are in air, accept this sacrifice.

column1: ye devā pṛthivyām ekādaśa stha te devāsaḥ haviḥ idam juṣadhvam //
column2: O ye eleven Gods who are on earth, accept this sacrifice.

column1: asapatnam purastāt paścāt naḥ abhayam kṛtam / savitā mā dakṣiṇatas uttarāt mā śacīpatiḥ /
column2: 15 repeated from XIX. 16. 1, 2.

column1: imam badhnāmi te maṇim dīrgha āyu tvāya tejase / darbham sapatna dambhanam dviṣataḥ tapanam hṛdaḥ /
column2: On thee I bind this Amulet for lengthened life and brilliancy. The rival-quelling Darbha grass that burns the spirit of a foe.

column1: dviṣataḥ tāpayan hṛdaḥ śatrūṇām tāpayan manaḥ / durhārdaḥ sarvān tvam darbha gharmaḥ iva abhīn saṃtāpayan /
column2: Burning the spirit of the foe, vexing the heart of enemies. Darbha, on every side, like heat, inflame all evil-hearted men.

column1: gharmaḥ iva abhitapan darbha dviṣataḥ nitapan maṇe / hṛdaḥ sapatnānām bhinddhi indraḥ iva virujam balam /
column2: O Darbha, burning round like heat, consuming foes, O Amulet,. Like Indra rending Vala cleave mine adversaries' hearts in twain.

column1: bhinddhi darbha sapatnānām hṛdayam dviṣatām maṇe / udyan tvacam iva bhūmyāḥ śiraḥ eṣām vi pātaya //
column2: Cleave through. O Darbha, Amulet, my foes', mine adversaries'. heart. Rise thou and batter down their heads like growth that coverethl the earth.

column1: bhinddhi darbha sapatnān me bhinddhi me pṛtanāyataḥ / bhinddhi me sarvān durhārdaḥ bhinddhi me dviṣataḥ maṇe / chinddhi darbha sapatnān me chinddhi me pṛtanāyataḥ / chinddhi me sarvān durhārdaḥ chinddhi me dviṣataḥ maṇe / vṛśca darbha sapatnān me vṛśca me pṛtanāyataḥ / vṛśca me sarvān durhārdaḥ vṛśca me dviṣataḥ maṇe /
column2: Cleave thou my rivals, Darbha, cleave the men who fain would, fight with me. Cleave all who wish me evil, cleave the men who hate me,. Amulet! Wound thou, my rivals, Darbha, etc. (as in 5, substituting. 'wound' for cleave.) Tear thou my rivals, Darbha, etc.

column1: kṛnta darbha sapatnān me kṛnta me pṛtanāyataḥ / kṛnta me sarvān durhārdaḥ kṛnta me dviṣataḥ maṇe / piṃśa darbha sapatnān me piṃśa me pṛtanāyataḥ / piṃśa me sarvān durhārdaḥ piṃśa me dviṣataḥ maṇe /
column2: How thou my rivals, Darbha, etc. Carve thou my rivals, Darbha, etc.

column1: runddhi darbha sapatnān me runddhi me pṛtanāyataḥ / runddhi me sarvān durhārdaḥ runddhi me dviṣataḥ maṇe / mṛṇa darbha sapatnān me mṛṇa me pṛtanāyataḥ / mṛṇa me sarvān durhārdaḥ mṛṇa me dviṣataḥ maṇe / mantha darbha sapatnān me mantha me pṛtanāyataḥ / mantha me sarvān durhārdaḥ mantha me dviṣataḥ maṇe /
column2: Pierce thou my rivals, Darbha, pierce the men who fain would fight with me. Pierce those who wish me evil, pierce the men who hate me, Amulet! Pierce thou my rivals, Darbha, pierce the men who fain would fight with me. Pierce all who wish me evil, pierce the men who hate me,. Amulet!

column1: piṇḍḍhi darbha sapatnān me piṇḍḍhi me pṛtanāyataḥ / piṇḍḍhi me sarvān durhārdaḥ piṇḍḍhi me dviṣataḥ maṇe /
column2: Split thou my rivals, Darbha, etc. (as in 1, with 'split' for 'pierce' throughout). Check thou, etc. Crush thou, etc.

column1: daha darbha sapatnān me daha me pṛtanāyataḥ / daha me sarvān durhārdaḥ daha me dviṣataḥ maṇe /
column2: Shake thou, etc. Bruise thou, etc. Burn thou, etc.

column1: jahi darbha sapatnān me jahi me pṛtanāyataḥ / jahi me sarvān durhārdaḥ jahi me dviṣataḥ maṇe /
column2: Slay thou my rivals. Darbha, slay the men who fain would fight with me. Slay all who wish me evil, slay the men who hate me, Amulet.

column1: yat te darbha jarā mṛtyu śatam varmasu varma te / tena imam varmiṇam kṛtvā sapatnām jahi vīryaiḥ //
column2: Darbha, with that good shield of thine, of hundred guards tilt death in eld, Arm thou this man, and with thy might strike thou his adver- saries down.

column1: śatam te darbha varmāṇi sahasram vīryāṇi te / tam asmai viśve tvām devāḥ jarase bhartavai aduḥ /
column2: Darbha, thou hast a hundred shields, thou hast a thousand. manly powers. All Gods have given thee to him to bear thee till extreme old age.

column1: tvām āhuḥ deva varma tvām darbha brahmaṇaḥ patim / tvām indrasya āhuḥ varma tvam rāṣṭrāṇi rakṣasi //
column2: They call thee, ‘Darbha, shield of Gods, they call the Brāhmanas- pati. They call thee shield of Indra: thou protectest kingdoms from attack.

column1: sapatna kṣayaṇam darbha dviṣataḥ tapanam hṛdaḥ / maṇim kṣatrasya vardhanam tanū pānam kṛṇomi te /
column2: Darbha, destroyer of the foe, vexing the hearts of enemies, An Amulet that strengthens rule I make thee, and the body's. guard.

column1: yat samudraḥ abhyakrandat parjanyaḥ vidyutā saha / tatas hiranyayaḥ binduḥ tatas darbhaḥ ajāyata //
column2: What time Parjanya roared to it with lightning flashes in the sea, Thence came the drop, the golden drop, thence Darbha into being sprang.

column1: audumbareṇa maṇinā puṣṭi kāmāya vedhasā / paśūṇām sarveṣām sphātim goṣṭhe me savitā karat /
column2: Savitar make all cattle grow and prosper in my stable with. Amulet of Udumbara, helper of him who longs for wealth!

column1: yaḥ naḥ agniḥ gārhapatyaḥ paśūnām adhipāḥ asat / audumbaraḥ vṛṣā maṇiḥ sam mā sṛjatu puṣṭyā /
column2: May he who was our Household Fire, the ruler of our cattle, strong. Amulet of Udumbara endow us with prosperity.

column1: karīṣiṇīm phalavatīm svadhām irām ca naḥ gṛhe / audumbarasya tejasā dhātā puṣṭim dadhātu me / yat dvipād ca catuṣpād ca yāni annāni ye rasāḥ / gṛhṇe aham tu eṣām bhūmānam bibhrat audumbaram maṇim //
column2: By power of the Udumbara Charm may Dhātar give me plenty, rich. In the kine's droppings and in fruit, and, in our dwelling, food, and drink. I win great plenty, while I wear the Amulet of Udumbara. Of quadrupeds and bipeds, of juices and food of every sort.

column1: puṣṭim paśūnām pari jagrabha aham catuṣpadām dvipadām yat ca dhānyam / payaḥ paśūnām rasam oṣadhīnām bṛhaspatiḥ savitā me ni yacchāt / aham paśūnām adhipāḥ asāni mayi puṣṭam puṣṭa patiḥ dadhātu / mahyam audumbaraḥ maṇiḥ draviṇāni ni yacchatu //
column2: I have obtained abundant wealth of cattle, bipeds and quad- rupeds, and corn in plenty. Savitar and Brihaspati vouchsafe me the milk of kine and herbs' refreshing juices! Fain would I be the lord of herds of cattle: may he who rules o'er riches send me riches! May the Udumbara Amulet vouchsafe possessions unto me.

column1: upa mā audumbaraḥ maṇiḥ prajayā ca dhanena ca / indreṇa jinvitaḥ maṇiḥ ā mā agan saha varcasā /
column2: To me with wealth and children come the Amulet of Udumbara. With splendour come the Amulet hastened by Indra on its way!

column1: devaḥ maṇiḥ sapatna hā dhana sāḥ dhana sātaye / paśoḥ annasya bhūmānam gavām sphātim ni yacchatu //
column2: Divine, foe-quelling Amulet, wealth-winner for the gain of wealth— May it give store of beasts and food and cause our kine to multiply.

column1: yathā agre tvam vanaspate puṣṭhyā saha jajñiṣe / eva dhanasya me sphātim ā dadhātu sarasvatī /
column2: As thou, O Forest Tree, wast born with increase when thy life began, So let Sarasvati bestow abundant growth of wealth on me.

column1: ā me dhanam sarasvatī paya sphātim ca dhānyam / sinīvālī upa ā vahāt ayam ca audumbaraḥ maṇiḥ /
column2: Sarasvati vouchsafe me wealth, household prosperity, and corn! Let Sinivāli bring them, and this Amulet of Udumbara.

column1: tvam maṇīṇām adhipāḥ vṛṣā asi tvayi puṣṭam puṣṭa patiḥ jajāna / tvayi ime vājāḥ draviṇāni sarva audumbaraḥ sa tvam asmat sahasva ārāt ārāt arātim amatim kṣudham ca /
column2: The Lord of amulets art thou, most mighty: in thee wealth's ruler hath engendered riches, These gains are lodged in thee, and all great treasures. Amulet, conquer thou: far from us banish malignity and indigence, and hunger.

column1: grāmaṇīḥ asi grāmaṇīḥ utthāya abhiṣiktaḥ abhi mā siñca varcasā / tejaḥ asi tejaḥ mayi dhāraya adhi rayiḥ asi rayim me dhehi //
column2: Vigour art thou, in me do thou plant vigour: riches art thou, so do thou grant me riches. Plenty art thou, so prosper me with plenty: House-holder, hear" a householder's petition.

column1: puṣṭiḥ asi puṣṭyāḥ mā sam aṅgdhi gṛhamedhī gṛhapatim mā kṛṇu / audumbaraḥ sa tvam asmāsu dhehi rayim ca naḥ sarva vīram ni yaccha rāyaḥ poṣāya prati muñce aham tvām / ayam audumbaraḥ maṇiḥ vīraḥ vīrāya badhyate / sa naḥ sanim madhumatīm kṛṇotu rayim ca naḥ sarva vīram ni yacchāt /
column2: Amulet of Udumbara, enrich us: vouchsafe us wealth with all good men about us. I bind thee on for increase of possessions. For hero is this hero bound, Amulet of Udumbara. So may he make our offering sweetly-savoured, and grant us wealth with all good men about us.

column1: śata kāṇḍaḥ duścyavanaḥ sahasra parṇaḥ uttiraḥ / darbhaḥ yaḥ ugraḥ oṣadhiḥ tam te badhnāmi āyuṣe /
column2: For lengthened life I bind on thee the Darbha grass, the mighty plant. Excellent, hard to overthrow, with hundred stems and thousand blades.

column1: na asya keśān pra vapanti na urasi tāḍam ā ghnate / yasmai a chinna parṇena darbhena śarma yacchati //
column2: They cut not off his hair, they strike blow upon the breast for' him. To whom one gives protection by Darbha that hath uninjured leaves.

column1: divi te tūlam oṣadhe pṛthivyām asi niṣṭhitaḥ / tvayā sahasra kāṇḍena āyuḥ pra vardhayāmahe //
column2: O Plant, thy root is in the sky, and thou art stationed on the earth: With thee who hast a thousand stalks we strengthen all the powers of life.

column1: tisraḥ divaḥ ati atṛṇat tisraḥ imāḥ pṛthivīḥ uta / tvayā aham durhārdaḥ jihvām ni tṛṇadmi vacāṃsi //
column2: Through all three skies the plant hath pierced, and the three regions of the earth; With thee I split in twain the tongue and words of the bad- hearted man.

column1: tvam asi sahamānaḥ aham asmi sahasvān / ubhau sahasvantau bhūtvā sapatnān sahiṣīvahi //
column2: Thou art victorious in thy might I am endowed with conquering strength: Possessed of overpowering force we two will quell our enemies.

column1: sahasva naḥ abhimātim sahasva pṛtanāyataḥ / sahasva sarvān durhārdaḥ suhārdaḥ me bahūn kṛdhi //
column2: Subdue our foeman, overcome the men who fain would fight: with us. Conquer all evil-hearted ones: make many well-disposed to me.

column1: darbheṇa deva jātena divi ṣṭambhena śaśvat id / tena aham śaśvataḥ janām asanam sanavāni ca /
column2: With Darbha that hath sprung from Gods, stationed in heaven, full many a time. With this have I won many men, have won and may I win them still.

column1: priyam mā darbha kṛṇu brahmarājanyābhyām śūdrāya ca āryāya ca / yasmai ca kāmayāmahe sarvasmai ca vipaśyate //
column2: Do thou, O Darbha, make me dear to Brāhman and Rājanya, dear to Sūdra, and to Arya dear, Yea, dear to every man we love, to every man with eyes to see.

column1: yaḥ jāyamānaḥ pṛthivīm adṛṃhat yaḥ astabhnāt antarikṣam divam ca / yam bibhratam nanu pāpmā viveda sa naḥ ayam darbhaḥ varuṇaḥ divā kaḥ /
column2: He who first born fixed earth in her position, he who established heaven and air's mid-region, Whom sinner ne'er hath known as his supporter,—this Darbha be our shelter and protection!

column1: sapatna hā śata kāṇḍaḥ sahasvān oṣadhīnām prathamaḥ sam babhūva / sa naḥ ayam darbhaḥ pari pātu viśvatas tena sākṣīya pṛtanāḥ pṛtanyataḥ /
column2: First of all plants it sprang into existence, victorious, hundred- stemmed, the foe-subduer, So may this Darbha from all sides protect us: with this may I subdue our foes in battle.

column1: sahasra arghaḥ śata kāṇḍaḥ payasvān apām agniḥ vīrudhām rājasūyam / sa naḥ ayam darbhaḥ pari pātu viśvatas devaḥ maṇiḥ āyuṣā sam sṛjāti naḥ /
column2: Hundred stemmed, succulent, and worth a thousand, the Royal Rite of plants, the Water's Agni, Let this same Darbha guard us from all quarters. This Godlike Amulet shall with life endow us.

column1: ghṛtāt ulluptaḥ madhumān payasvān bhūmi dṛṃhaḥ acyutaḥ cyāvayiṣṇuḥ / nudan sapatnān adharān ca kṛṇvan darbhāḥ roha mahatām indriyeṇa /
column2: Drawn forth from butter, juicy, sweetly-flavoured, firm as the earth, unshaken, overthrowing. Driving off foes and casting them beneath me, mount with the strength of mighty Ones, O Darbha.

column1: tvam bhūmim ati eṣi ojasā tvam vedyām sīdasi cāruḥ adhvare / tvām pavitram ṛṣayaḥ abharanta tvam punīhi duritāni asmat /
column2: Thou movest o'er the earth with vigour: lovely in sacrifice thou sittest on the altar. The Rishis bear thee as a purifier: cleanse thou us from all evil deeds' defilement.

column1: tīkṣṇaḥ rājā viṣāsahī rakṣaḥ hā viśvacarṣaṇiḥ / ojaḥ devānām balam ugram etat tam te badhnāmi jarase svastaye /
column2: A stern and all-victorious king, foe-queller, dear to every man— That energy of Gods and mighty power, I bind this on thee for long life and welfare.

column1: darbheṇa tvam kṛṇavat vīryāṇi darbham bibhrat ātmanā mā vyathiṣṭhāḥ / atiṣṭhāya varcasā adhānyān sūryaḥ iva ā bhāhi pradiśaḥ catasraḥ /
column2: Achieve heroic deeds with Darbha, wearing this Darbha never let thy soul be troubled. In splendour and precedence over others illumine like the Sun the heaven's four regions.

column1: jāṅgiḍaḥ asi jaṅgiḍaḥ rakṣitā asi jaṅgidaḥ / dvipād catuṣpād asmākam sarvam rakṣatu jaṅgidaḥ /
column2: Jangida, thou art Angiras: thou art a guardian, Jangida. Let Jangida, keep safely all our bipeds and our quadrupeds.

column1: yāḥ gṛtsyaḥ tri pañca āśīḥ śatam kṛtyā kṛtaḥ ca ye / sarvān vinaktu tejasaḥ arasām jaṅgidaḥ karat /
column2: Dice-witcheries, the fifty-threes, the hundred witchcraft-practi- sers, All these may Jangida make weak, bereft of their effectual force.

column1: arasam kṛtrimam nādam arasāḥ sapta visrasaḥ / apetaḥ jaṅgiḍāmatim iṣum astā iva śātaya //
column2: Baffle the loud factitious howl, make impotent the seven decays. As when an archer speeds the shaft, drive away want, O Jangida,

column1: kṛtyā dūṣaṇaḥ eva ayam atha u arāti dūṣaṇaḥ / atha u sahasvān jaṅgiḍaḥ pra naḥ āyumṣi tāriṣat /
column2: This counteracts the sorceress, this banishes malignity: Then may victorious Jangida's prolong the days we have to live.

column1: sa jaṅgiḍasya mahimā pari naḥ pātu viśvatas / viṣkandham yena sāsaha saṃskandham ojaḥ ojasā /
column2: Let Jangida's protecting might encompass us on every side. Wherewith he quells Vishkandha and Sanskandha, might by greater might.

column1: tris tvā devāḥ ajanayat niṣṭhitam bhūmyām adhi / tam u tvā aṅgirāḥ iti brāhmaṇāḥ pūrvyāḥ viduḥ /
column2: Three times the Gods engendered thee fixt on the surface of the earth; The Brāhmans of the olden time knew that thy name was Angiras;

column1: na tvā pūrvāḥ oṣadhayaḥ na tvā taranti yāḥ navāḥ / vibādhaḥ ugraḥ jaṅgiḍaḥ paripāṇaḥ su maṅgalaḥ /
column2: The ancient plants surpass thee not, nor any herbs of recent days. A potent charm is Jangida, a most felicitous defence.

column1: atha upadāna bhagavaḥ jāṅgiḍa amita vīrya / purā te ugrā grasataḥ upendraḥ vīryam dadau //
column2: Then when thou sprangest into life, Jangida of un-measured strength, Indra, O mighty One, bestowed great power upon thee from the first.

column1: ugraḥ id te vanaspate indraḥ ojmānam ā dadhau / amīvāḥ sarvāḥ cātayam jahi rakṣāṃsi oṣadhe //
column2: To thee in truth, O Forest Tree, Indra the mighty One gave strength. Driving away all maladies, strike thou the demons down, O Plant.

column1: āśarīkam viśarīkam balāsam pṛṣṭyāmayam / takmānam viśva śāradam arasām jaṅgiḍaḥ karat /
column2: Lumbago and rheumatic pain, consumptive cough, and pleurisy, And fever which each Autumn brings, may Jangida make- powerless.

column1: indrasya nāma gṛhṇantaḥ ṛsayaḥ jaṅgidam daduḥ / devāḥ yam cakruḥ bheṣajam agre viṣkandha dūṣaṇam /
column2: While their lips uttered Indra's name the Rishis gave us Jangida.. Which in the earliest time Gods made a remedy, Vishkandha's- cure.

column1: sa naḥ rakṣatu jaṅgiḍaḥ dhana pālaḥ dhanā iva / devāḥ yam cakruḥ brāhmaṇāḥ paripāṇam arāti ham /
column2: So may this Jangida guard us, even as a treasurer guards wealth,. Even this which Gods and Brāhmans made a malice-quelling sure defence.

column1: durhārdaḥ saṃghoram cakṣuḥ pāpa kṛtvānam āgamam / tān tvam sahasracakṣo pratībodhena nāśaya paripāṇaḥ asi jaṅgiḍaḥ /
column2: Hard-hearted men, the cruel eye, the sinner who hath come to- us, Destroy thou these with watchful care, O thou who hast a. thousand eyes. Thou, Jangida, art my defence.

column1: pari mā divaḥ pari mā pṛthivyāḥ pari antarikṣāt pari mā vīrudbhyaḥ / pari mā bhūtāt pari mā uta bhavyāt diśaḥ diśaḥ jaṅgiḍaḥ pātu asmān /
column2: Guard me from earth and guard me from the heavens, guard me from middle air, from plants protect me. Protect me from the present and the future. From every region Jangida preserve us!

column1: yaḥ ṛṣṇavaḥ deva kṛtāḥ yaḥ uta u vavṛte anyaḥ / sarvān stān viśva bheṣajaḥ arasām jaṅgiḍaḥ karat /
column2: All sorcerers made by the Gods, all that arise from mortal men,. These, one and all, let Jangida, healer of all, make impotent.

column1: śata vāraḥ anīnaśat yakṣmān rakṣāṃsi tejasā / ārohan varcasā saha maṇiḥ durṇāma cātanaḥ /
column2: The Hundred-haired hath banished hence fiends and Consump- tions by its might. With splendour hath the charm that scares demons of ill-name mounted up.

column1: śṛṅgābhyām rakṣaḥ nudate mūlena yātudhānyaḥ / madhyena yakṣmam bādhate na enam pāpmā ati tatrati //
column2: It drives off demons with its horns and sorceresses with its root, It stays Consumption with its waist: from this no wickedness escapes.

column1: ye yakṣmāsaḥ arbhakāḥ mahāntaḥ ye ca śabdinaḥ / sarvām durṇāmahāḥ maṇiḥ śata vāraḥ anīnaśat / śatam vīrān ajanayat śatam yakṣmān apāvapat / durṇāmnaḥ sarvān hatvā ava rakṣāṃsi dhūnute / hiraṇya śṛṅgaḥ ṛṣabhaḥ śāta vāraḥ ayam maṇiḥ / durṇāmnaḥ sarvān tṛdhvā ava rakṣāṃsi akramīt /
column2: Consumptions, light and serious, and those which sounds accompany, All these the Amulet, Hundred-haired, scarer of fiends, hath banished hence. A hundred men hath it produced, hundred Consumptions chased away, All fiends of evil-name it hath smitten, and shakes the Rākshasas.

column1: śatam aham durṇāmnīnām gandharva apsarasām śatam / śatam śaśvanvatīnām śata vāreṇa vāraye //
column2: Hundred she-fiends, a hundred of Gandharvas and Apsarasas, A hundred of dog-mated nymphs, I keep away with Hundred- Hair

column1: idam varcaḥ agninā dattam āgan bhargaḥ yaśaḥ sahaḥ ojaḥ vayaḥ balam / trayastriṃśat yāni ca vīryāṇi tāni agniḥ pra dadātu me /
column2: To me hath come this word given by Agni, fame, force and might, and strength, and life, and lustre. May Agni too bestow on me three-times a hundred manly powers.

column1: varcaḥ ā dhehi me tanvām sahaḥ ojaḥ vayaḥ balam / indriyāya tvā karmaṇe vīryāya prati gṛhṇāmi śata śāradāya //
column2: For mighty strength, for action, I receive thee, for manly power, to last a hundred autumns.

column1: ūrje tvā balāya tvā ojase sahase tvā / abhibhūyāya tvā rāṣṭra bhṛtyāya pari ūhāmi śata śāradāya // ṛtubhyaḥ tvā ārtavebhyaḥ mādbhyaḥ saṃvatsarebhyaḥ / dhātre vidhātre samṛdhe bhūtasya pataye yaje //
column2: For conquering strength and energy and vigour I fasten thee for chieftainship, for bearing royal dominion through a hundred autumns. With Seasons and with Season-groups, for vigour and extended life. With splendour of the perfect year we fasten thee about the neck.

column1: na tam yakṣmāḥ arundhate na enam śapathaḥ aśnute / yam bheṣajasya gulguloḥ surabhiḥ gandhaḥ aśnute /
column2: Never Consumption, never curse touches the man, Arundhatī! Whom the delicious odour of the healing Bdellium penetrates

column1: viṣvañcaḥ tasmāt yakṣmāḥ mṛgāḥ aśvāḥ iva īrate / yat gulgulu saindhavam yat vā api asi samudriyam / ubhayoḥ agrabham nāma asmai ariṣṭatātaye //
column2: Consumptions flee apart from it as from a wild beast fly the deer. If thou, O Bdellium, art produced from Sindhu or hast come from sea, The quality of both have I taken to keep this man unscathed.

column1: aitu devaḥ trāyamāṇaḥ kuṣṭhaḥ himavataḥ pari / takmānam sarvam nāśaya sarvāḥ ca yātudhānyaḥ /
column2: Let Kushtha from the Hill of Snow come, a divine deliverer. Banish thou all Consumption, drive all sorceresses far away.

column1: trīṇi te kuṣṭha nāmāni nadyamāraḥ nadyāḥ ariṣaḥ / nadyāḥ ayam puruṣaḥ riṣat / yasmai paribravīmi tvā sāyaṃprātar atho divā /
column2: Kushtha, three several names hast thou, Naghamāra, Naghārisha: let not mishap befall this man, For whom I make a charm of thee at eve, at morning, and by day.

column1: jīvalā nāma te mātā jīvantaḥ nāma te pitā / nadyāḥ ayam puruṣaḥ riṣat / yasmai paribravīmi tvā sāyam prātar atho divā /
column2: Jivalā is thy mother's name, thy father's name is Jivala; let not mishap, etc.

column1: uttamaḥ asi oṣadhīnām anaḍvān jagatām iva vyāghraḥ śvapadām iva / nadyāḥ ayam puruṣaḥ riṣat / yasmai paribravīmi tvā sāyam prātar atho divā /
column2: Thou art the best amid the plants, even as the ox is best of tame, the tiger of rapacious beasts: let not mishap, etc.

column1: tris śāmbubhyaḥ aṅgirebhyaḥ tris ādityebhyaḥ pari / tris jātaḥ viśva devebhyaḥ / sa kuṣṭhaḥ viśva bheṣajaḥ sākam somena tiṣṭhati / aśvatthaḥ deva sadanaḥ tṛtīyasyām itas divi / tatra amṛtasya cakṣaṇam tatas kuṣṭhaḥ ajāyata / sa kuṣṭhaḥ viśva bheṣajaḥ sākam somena tiṣṭhati / hiraṇyayī nauḥ acarat hiraṇya bandhanā divi / tatra amṛtasya cakṣaṇam tatas kuṣṭhaḥ ajāyata / sa kuṣṭhaḥ viśva bheṣajaḥ sāka
column2: Born thrice from the Ādityas, thrice from Bhrigus, thrice from Angiras' sons, born from the Visve Devas thrice, Healer of every malady, that Kushtha stands by Soma's side. Banish thou all Consumption, drive all sorceresses far away. In the third heaven above us stands the Asvattha tree, the seat of Gods: There is embodiment of life that dies not: thence was Kushtha born.

column1: śīrṣa śokam tṛtīyakam sa daṃdiḥ yaḥ ca hāyanaḥ / takmānam viśvadhā vīrya adharāñcam parā suva /
column2: O thou who hast all-reaching might drive away Fever, drive it down, Head racking Fever, tertian, continual, lasting for a year.

column1: yat me chidram manasaḥ yat ca vācaḥ sarasvatī manyumantam jagāma / viśvaiḥ tat devaiḥ saha saṃvidānaḥ sam dadhātu bṛhaspatiḥ /
column2: For each defect of mine in voice and spirit I have approached One vehement and ardent. With all the Deities, fully approving, Brihaspati supply the want!

column1: mā naḥ āpaḥ medhām mā brahma pra mathiṣṭana / suṣyadā yūyam syandadhvam upahūtaḥ aham sumedhāḥ varcasvī /
column2: Disturb ye not our intellect, O Waters, nor the power of prayer_ Glide on your way, strength-giving, invocated: may I be vigor- ous and wise.

column1: mā naḥ medhām mā naḥ dīkṣām mā naḥ hiṃsiṣṭam yat tapaḥ / śivāḥ naḥ śam santu āyuṣe śivāḥ bhavantu mātaraḥ /
column2: Mar not our consecrating rite, our intellect, or fervent zeal. Gracious to us for lengthened life, propitious let the Mothers be.

column1: yā naḥ pīparat aśvinā jyotiṣmatī tamaḥ tiras / tām asme rāsatām iṣam /
column2: Vouchsafe to us, ye Asvins twain, such strength as, with atten- dant light, May through the darkness carry us.

column1: bhadram ichantaḥ ṛṣayaḥ svar vidaḥ tapaḥ dīkṣām upaniṣeduḥ agre / tatas rāṣṭram balam ojaḥ ca jātam tat asmai devāḥ upasaṃnamantu //
column2: Desiring bliss, at first, light-finding Rishis began religious rite and holy fervour. Thence energy was born, and might, and kingship: so to this man let gathered Gods incline them.

column1: brahma hotā brahma yajñāḥ brahmaṇā svaravaḥ mitāḥ / adhvaryuḥ brahmaṇaḥ jātaḥ brahmaṇaḥ antarhitam haviḥ /
column2: Brahma is Hotar, sacrifice: with Brahma are the stakes set up. From Brahma was the Adhvaryu born, from Brahma hidden offering.

column1: brahma srucaḥ ghṛtavatīḥ brahmaṇā vediḥ uddhitā / brahma yajñasya tattvam ca ṛtvijaḥ ye haviṣkṛtaḥ / śamitāya svāhā /
column2: Brahma is fatness-dropping scoops: with Brahma was the altar reared. Brahma is worship, lengthened rite, the Rishis who pay sacrifice, the victim's Immolators. Hail!

column1: aṃhaḥ muce pra bhare manīṣām ā sutrāvṇe sumatim āvṛṇānaḥ / imam indra prati havyam gṛbhāya satyāḥ santu yajamānasya kāmāḥ / aṃhaḥ mucam vrṣabham yajñiyānām virājantam prathamam adhvarāṇam / apām napātam aśvinā huve dhiyaḥ indriyeṇa te indriyam dattam ojaḥ //
column2: To him who frees from woe mine hymn I offer, to the Good Guardian, as I seek his favour. Accept this offering of mine, O Indra. Fulfilled be all the sacri- ficer's wishes! With prayer I call on him who frees from trouble, Prince of Gods, Splendid, chief of sacrifices, I call the Waters' Child and both the Asvins, Vigour is mine, and strength bestowed by Indra.

column1: yatra brahma vidaḥ yānti dīkṣayā tapasā saha / agniḥ mā tatra nayatu agniḥ medhā dadhātu me / agnaye svāhā /
column2: Whither men versed in Brahma go, with fervour and the cleans- ing rite, Thither let Agni lead me, let Agni give me intelligence, All hail to Agni!

column1: yatra brahma vidaḥ yānti dīkṣayā tapasā saha / vāyuḥ mā tatra nayatu vāyuḥ praṇān dadhātu me vāyave svāhā /
column2: Whither etc. Thither let Vāyu lead me, let Vāyu vouchsafe me vital breath. All hail to Vāyu!

column1: yatra brahma vidaḥ yānti dīkṣayā tapasā saha / sūryaḥ mā tatra nayatu cakṣuḥ sūryaḥ dadhātu me / sūryāya svāhā / yatra brahma vidaḥ yānti dīkṣayā tapasā saha / candraḥ mā tatra nayatu manaḥ candraḥ dadhātu me / candrāya svāhā /
column2: Whither, etc. Thither let Sūrya lead me, let Sūrya vouchsafe me power of sight. All hail to Sürya Whither, etc. Thither let Chandra lead me, let Chandra vouchsafe me intellect. All hail to Chandra!

column1: yatra brahma vidaḥ yānti dīkṣayā tapasā saha / somaḥ mā tatra nayatu payaḥ somaḥ dadhātu me / somāya svāhā /
column2: Whither, etc. Thither let Soma lead me, let Soma vouchsafe me vital sap. All hail to Soma!

column1: yatra brahma vidaḥ yānti dīkṣayā tapasā saha / indraḥ mā tatra nayatu balam indraḥ dadhātu me / indrāya svāhā /
column2: Whither, etc. Thither let Indra lead me, let Indra bestow upon me power. All hail to Indra!

column1: yatra brahma vidaḥ yānti dīkṣayā tapasā saha / brahmā mā tatra nayatu brahmā brahma dadhātu me / brahmaṇe svāhā /
column2: Whither, etc. Thither let Brahma lead me, let Brahma give Brahma unto me. All hail to Brahma!

column1: āyuṣaḥ asi prataraṇam vipram bheṣajam ucyase / tat āñjana tvam śaṃtāte śam āpaḥ abhayam kṛtam /
column2: Thou art the lengthening of life, thy name is Universal Cure: Then, Ointment! send felicity; Waters, send happiness and peace.

column1: yaḥ harimā jāyānyaḥ aṅgabhedaḥ viṣalpakaḥ / sarvam te yakṣmam aṅgebhyaḥ bahis niḥ hantu āñjanam //
column2: The yellow hue, the feverish heat, the shooting pain that rends II the limbs, All the consumptive malady let the Ointment drive from out thy frame.

column1: āñjanam pṛthivyām jātam bhadram puruṣa jīvanam / kṛṇotu apramāyukam ratha jūtim anāgasam /
column2: Let the Salve born upon the earth, benignant, giving life to man. Make the swift rider on the car sinless, exempt from sudden death.

column1: prāṇa prāṇam trāyasva asave mṛḍa / nirṛte nirṛtyā naḥ pāśebhyaḥ muñca /
column2: Preserve our breath, O Vital Breath, have mercy on our life, O Life. From snares of Nirriti do thou, O Nirriti, deliver us.

column1: sindhoḥ garbhaḥ asi vidyutām puṣpam / vātaḥ prāṇaḥ sūryaḥ cakṣuḥ divaḥ payaḥ /
column2: Thou art the babe of Sindhu, thou art lightnings' flower, wind, breath, and Sun: thou art the eye and milk of heaven.

column1: devāñjana traikakuda pari mā pāhi viśvatas / na tvā taranti oṣadhayaḥ bāhyāḥ parvatīyāḥ uta /
column2: Gods' Ointment from the Three Peaked Hill, preserve thou me on every side. No plants of earth surpass thee, none from mountain or from cultured ground.

column1: vi idam madhyam avāsṛpat rakṣaḥ hā amīva cātanaḥ / amīvāḥ sarvāḥ cātayat nāśayat abhibhāḥ itas /
column2: Now hath it gently crept within, fiend-slaying, chasing malady. And driving all diseases hence, and evil omens, banished them.

column1: bahu idam rājan varuṇa anṛtam āha pūruṣaḥ / tasmāt sahasra vīrya muñca naḥ pari aṃhasaḥ /
column2: Full many a falsehood, O thou King Varuna, man hath uttered here: Do thou who hast a thousand powers preserve us from that misery.

column1: yat āpaḥ aghnyāḥ iti varuṇa iti yat ūcima / tasmāt sahasra vīrya muñca naḥ pari aṃhasaḥ /
column2: If we have cried, O Waters! Cows! if we have cried, O Varuna! For this endowed with thousand powers! deliver us from misery.

column1: mitraḥ ca tvā varuṇaḥ ca anupreyatuḥ āñjana / tau tvā anugatya dūram bhogāya punar ohatuḥ //
column2: Mitra and Varuna, O Salve have closely followed after thee May they, when they have followed thee afar, restore thee for our use.

column1: ṛṇāt ṛṇam iva sam naya kṛtyām kṛtyā kṛtaḥ gṛham / cakṣuḥ mantrasya durhārdaḥ pṛṣṭīḥ api śṛṇāñjana /
column2: As debt from debt repay and send sorcery to the sorcerer's house. Split, Salve! the cruel villain's ribs whose evil eye bewitches us.

column1: yat asmāsu duṣvapnyam yat goṣu yat ca naḥ gṛhe / anāmagaḥ tam ca durhārdaḥ priyaḥ prati muñcatām /
column2: Whatever evil dream we have, what'er befall our kine or home, Be this that is salubrity, the evil-hearted's foe applied.

column1: apām ūrjaḥ ojasaḥ vāvṛdhānam agneḥ jātam adhi jātavedasaḥ / catur vīram parvatīyam yat āñjanam diśaḥ pradiśaḥ karat id śivāḥ te /
column2: Increasing from the Waters' strength and vigour, sprung into life from Agni Jātavedas, Strong as four heroes, mountain born, this Ointment make for thee quarters and mind-points auspicious!

column1: catur vīram badhyate āñjanam te sarvāḥ diśaḥ abhayāḥ te bhavantu / dhruvaḥ tiṣṭhāsi savitā iva cāryaḥ imāḥ viśaḥ abhi harantu te balim /
column2: On thee is laid the Chaturvira Ointment: let all the regions give thee peace and safety. Secure like precious Savitar thou standest: to thee let all these regions bring their tribute.

column1: ākṣva ekam maṇim ekam krṇuṣva snāhi ekena piba ekam eṣām / catur vīram nairṛtebhyaḥ caturbhyaḥ grāhyā bandhebhyaḥ pari pātu asmān /
column2: Make one thy salve, thine amulet another, drink one, and with another bathe thy body. So let the Chaturvira keep us guarded from the four bonds of Nirriti and Grāhi.

column1: agniḥ mā agninā avatu prāṇāya apānāya āyuṣe varcase ojase / tejase svastaye subhūtaye svāhā /
column2: May Agni protect me with fire for inspiration and expiration, for strength, for energy, for vigour, for weal and prosperity. All Hail!

column1: indraḥ mā indriyeṇa avatu prāṇāya apānāya āyuṣe varcase ojase / tejase svastaye subhūtaye svāhā /
column2: May Indra protect me with his Indra-power for inspiration, etc.

column1: somaḥ mā saumyena avatu prāṇāya apānāya āyuṣe varcase ojase / tejase svastaye subhūtaye svāhā /
column2: May Soma protect me with Soma-power, etc.

column1: bhagaḥ ma bhagena avatu prāṇāya apānāya āyuṣe varcase ojase / tejase svastaye subhūtaye svāhā /
column2: May Bhaga with good fortune protect me, etc.

column1: marutaḥ mā gaṇaiḥ avantu prāṇāya apāna āyuṣe varcase ojase tejase / svastaye subhūtaye svāhā /
column2: May the Maruts protect me with their troops for inspiration and expiration, for strength, for energy, for vigour, for weal and prosperity. All Hail!

column1: prajāpatiḥ tvā badhnāt prathamam a stṛtam vīryāya kam / tat te badhnāmi āyuṣe varcase ojase ca balāya ca astṛtaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu //
column2: For manly strength Prajāpati bound thee on first, invincible. This for long life on thee I bind for splendour, strength, and energy. Invincible, let it guard thee well.

column1: ūrdhvaḥ tiṣṭhatu rakṣan apramādam astṛta imam mā tvā dabhan paṇayaḥ yātudhānāḥ / indraḥ iva dasyūn ava dhūnuṣva pṛtanyataḥ sarvām chatrūn vi sahasva astṛtaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
column2: Erect, invincible, be this man's watchful keeper: let not the Panis or the sorcerers harm thee. Shake off thy foes as Indra scattered Dasyus: quell all enemies. Invincible, let it guard thee well.

column1: śatam ca na praharantaḥ nighnantaḥ na tastire / tasmin indraḥ pari adatta cakṣuḥ prāṇam atho balam a stṛtaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
column2: Indra hath lent the power of sight, and vital breath and strength to this. Whom even a hundred combatants, striking, have failed to over- come. Invincible, let it guard thee well.

column1: indrasya tvā varmaṇā pari dhāpayāmaḥ yaḥ devānām adhirājaḥ babhūva / punar tvā devāḥ pra nayantu sarve a stṛtaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
column2: Around thy limbs I place the mail of Indra who hath become the Gods' imperial Sovran. Again let all the Deities bring thee hither. Invincible let it guard thee well.

column1: asmin maṇau eka śatam vīryāṇi sahasram prāṇāḥ asmin astṛte / vyāghraḥ śatrūn abhi tiṣṭha sarvān yaḥ tvā pṛtanyāt adharaḥ saḥ astu astṛtaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
column2: One and a hundred manly powers, a thousand lives hath this Amulet, unconquered ever. Go forth a tiger, strike down all thy foemen: let him who would oppose fall low beneath thee. Invincible, let it guard thee well.

column1: ghṛtāt ulluptaḥ madhumān payasvān sahasra prāṇaḥ śata yoniḥ vayodhāḥ / śambhūḥ ca mayobhūḥ ca ūrjasvān ca payasvān ca āstṛtaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
column2: Drawn forth from butter, rich in milk and sweetness, hundred- lived, thousand-homed, bestowing vigour, Kindly, delightsome, full of sap, and mighty, invincible let it guard thee well.

column1: yathā tvam uttaraḥ asaḥ asapatnaḥ sapatna hā / sajātānām asat vaśī tathā tvā savitā karat astṛtaḥ tvā abhi rakṣatu /
column2: That thou mayst be pre-eminent, slayer of rivals, rivalless, May Savitar cause thee to be chief and controller of thy kin. Invincible, let it guard thee well.

column1: ā rātri pārthivam rajaḥ pituḥ aprāyi dhāmabhiḥ / divaḥ sadāṃsi bṛhatī vi tiṣṭhase ā tveṣam vartate tamaḥ /
column2: Night! the terrestrial realm hath been filled with the Father's power and might. Thou spreadest forth on high unto the seats of Heaven: dark- ness that strikes with awe comes near.

column1: na yasyāḥ pāram dadṛśe na yoyuvat viśvam asyām ni viśate yat ejati / ariṣṭāsaḥ te urvi tamasvati rātri pāram aśīmahi bhadre pāram aśīmahi //
column2: Each moving thing finds rest in her whose yonder boundary is not seen, nor that which keeps her separate. O spacious, darksome Night, may we uninjured reach the end of thee, reach, O thou blessed One, thine end.

column1: ye te rātri nṛ cakṣasaḥ draṣṭāraḥ navatiḥ nava / aśītiḥ santi aṣṭa uta u te sapta saptatiḥ /
column2: Thy ninety-nine examiners, O Night, who look upon mankind, Eighty-and-eight in number, or seven-and-seventy are they.

column1: ṣaṣṭiḥ ca ṣaṭ ca revati pañcāśat pañca sumnayi / catvāraḥ catvāriṃśat ca trayaḥ triṃśat ca vājini //
column2: Sixty-and-six, O opulent, fifty-and-five, O happy One, Forty-and-four and thirty-three are they, O thou enriched with spoil.

column1: dvau ca te viṃśatiḥ ca te rātri ekādaśa avamāḥ / tebhiḥ naḥ adya pāyubhiḥ nu pāhi duhitar divaḥ /
column2: Twenty-and-two hast thou, O Night, eleven, yea, and fewer still. With these protectors guard us well. O Daughter of the Sky, to- day.

column1: rakṣā mākir naḥ agha śaṃsaḥ īśata mā naḥ duḥśaṃsaḥ īśata / mā naḥ adya gavām stenaḥ māvīnām vṛkaḥ īśata / mā aśvānām bhadre taskaraḥ mā nṛṇām yātudhānyaḥ / paramebhiḥ pathibhiḥ stenaḥ dhāvatu taskaraḥ / pareṇa datvatī rajjuḥ pareṇa aghāyuḥ arṣatu //
column2: Let not a fiends or spiteful man, let no ill-wisher master us. Let not the robber seize our cows, nor the wolf take our sheep today. Let not the thief, O Blessed, seize our horses, nor she-fiends our men. Let thief and robber run away on pathways most remote from us.

column1: adha rātri tṛṣṭa dhūmam a śīrṣāṇam ahim kṛṇu / hanū vṛkasya jambhayā stenam drupade jahi // tvayi rātri vasāmasi svapiṣyāmasi jāgṛhi / gobhyaḥ naḥ śarma yaccha aśvebhyaḥ puruṣebhyaḥ /
column2: Crush the wolf's jaws in pieces, strike the robber dead against a post. In thee, O Night, do we abide: we here will sleep. Be watchful thou. Give thou protection to our kine; and to our horses, and our men.

column1: atha u yāni ca yasmā ha yāni ca antar parīṇahi / tāni te pari dadmasi //
column2: Then all that we accumulate, all that the treasure-chest contains,. All this do we entrust to thee.

column1: rātri mātar uṣase naḥ pari dehi / uṣāḥ naḥ ahne pari dadātu ahar tubhyam vibhāvari //
column2: Entrust thou us to Dawn, O Mother Night. May Dawn entrust us to the Day, and Day to thee, O splendid. One.

column1: yat kim ca idam patayati yat kim ca idam sarīsṛpam / yat kim ca parvata ayāsa tvam tasmāt tvam rātri pāhi naḥ /
column2: Whatever flying thing be here, whatever thing that creeps and. crawls. Whatever fastens on a joint, therefrom do thou protect us, Night.

column1: sā paścāt pāhi sā puras sā uttarāt adharāt uta / gopāya naḥ vibhāvari stotāraḥ te iha smasi //
column2: So guard thou us from west and east, protect us from the north and south. O splendid One, preserve us: we, the singers of thy praise, are here.

column1: ye rātrim anutiṣṭhanti ye ca bhūteṣu jāgrati / paśūn ye sarvān rakṣanti te naḥ ātmasu jāgrati te naḥ paśuṣu jāgrati //
column2: They who are followers of Night, and they who watch o'er living things. They who protect all cattle, they keep watch and ward over our lives, over our herds keep watch and ward.

column1: veda vai rātri te nāma ghṛtācī nāma vai asi / tām tvām bharadvājaḥ veda sā naḥ vitte adhi jāgrati //
column2: Verily, Night, I know thy name, Dropper of Fatness art thou called. Thee Bharadvāja knew as such: as such be watchful o'er our wealth.

column1: iṣirā yoṣā yuvatiḥ damūnā rātrī devasya savituḥ bhagasya / aśva kṣabhā su havā saṃbhṛta śrīḥ ā paprau dyāvāpṛthivī mahitvā / ati viśvāni aruhat gambhiraḥ varṣiṣṭham aruhanta śraviṣṭhāḥ / uśatī rātri anu sā bhadrā abhi tiṣṭhate mitraḥ iva svadhābhiḥ //
column2: Friend of the home, the strong and youthful maiden, Night, dear to Savitar the God, and Bhaga, All-compassing, all-glorious, prompt to listen, hath with her greatness filled the earth and heaven. Over all depths hath she gone up, and mounted, most mighty One, the sky's exalted summit. Over me now the loving Night is spreading with her auspicious. Godlike ways like Mitra.

column1: varye vande subhage sujāte ājagan rātri sumanāḥ iha syām / asmān trāyasva naryāṇi jātāḥ atho yāni gavyāni puṣṭyā /
column2: Excellent, high-born, blissful, meet for worship, Night, thou hast come: stay here with friendly spirit. Guard us, the food for men that we have gotten, and all pro- sperity that comes of cattle.

column1: siṃhasya rātri uśatī pīṃṣasya vyāghrasya dvīpinaḥ varcaḥ ā dade / aśvasya bradhnam puruṣasya māyum puru rūpāṇi kṛṇuṣe vibhātī /
column2: With eager haste hath Night assumed the vigour of leopard,. tiger, or of tawny lion, The horse's neighing and the wild-man's bellow, Thou takest many a form when thou appearest.

column1: śivām rātrim anusūryam ca himasya mātā su havā naḥ astu / asya stomasya subhage ni bodha yena tvā vande viśvāsu dikṣu /
column2: Kind through the Night be absence of the sunshine: Mother of Frost, may she be swift to hear us. Take notice of the hymn, thou highly favoured, wherewith I worship thee in all the regions.

column1: stomasya naḥ vibhāvari rātri rājā iva joṣase / asāma sarva vīrāḥ bhavāma sarva vedasaḥ vyuchantīḥ anūṣasaḥ /
column2: Even as a King, O splendid Night, thou takest pleasure in our hymn. May we through Mornings as they flush have all our good men, round us, and become possessors of all wealth.

column1: śamyā ha nāma dadhiṣe mama dipsanti ye dhanā / rātrīhi tān asutapāḥ yaḥ stenaḥ na vidyate yat punar na vidyate /
column2: Yes, Rāmyā is the name thou hast assumed. The men who fain. would spoil. My wealth do thou annoy, O Night, that not one robber may appear, none may a second time appear.

column1: bhadrā asi rātri camasaḥ na viṣṭaḥ viṣvaṅ go rūpam yuvatiḥ bibharṣi / cakṣuṣmatī me uśatī vapūmṣi prati tvam divyā na kṣām amukthāḥ /
column2: Thou like a well-wrought cup, O Night, art lovely: thou, a. young maid, art formed in perfect beauty. Thou lovingly, for me with eyes to se: them, hast bound on thee heaven's stars as thine adornment.

column1: yaḥ adya stenaḥ āyati aghāyuḥ martyaḥ ripuḥ / rātrī tasya pratītya pra grīvāḥ pra śiraḥ hanat //
column2: Whatever robber comes to-day, mischievous mortal enemy. Let Night go forth, encounter him, and smite away his neck and head;

column1: pra pādau na yathāyati pra hastau na yathā āśiṣat / yaḥ malimluḥ upāyati sa saṃpiṣṭaḥ apāyati / apāyati su apāyati śuṣke sthāṇau apāyati // adha rātri tṛṣṭa dhūmam a śīrṣāṇam ahim kṛṇu / akṣau vṛkasya niḥ jahyāḥ tena tam drupade jahi //
column2: His feet that he may walk no more, his hands that he may do no harm. The robber who comes hitherward goes crushed and mutilated hence, Goes hence, goes far away from us, goes hence and bears no spoil away. Blind him and make him headless, Night! the serpent with the pungent breath. Strike from his head the wolf's two eyes, and dash the thief against a post.

column1: ye te rātri anaḍvāhaḥ tīkṣṇa śṛṅgāḥ su āśavaḥ / tebhiḥ naḥ adya pārayāti durgāṇi viśvahā / rātrim rātrim ariṣyantaḥ tarema tanvā vayam / gambhīram aplavāḥ iva na tareyuḥ arātayaḥ /
column2: Those oxen that are thine, O Night, with sharpened horns and rapid pace, With those transport us safe to-day o'er difficulties everywhere. Uninjured in our bodies may we pass through each succeeding night, And let malignities fail to pass, as men without a boat the depth.

column1: yathā śāmyākaḥ prapatan apavān na anuvidyate / eva rātri pra pātaya yaḥ asmām abhyaghāyati // apa stenam vāsayaḥ go ajam uta taskaram / atha u yaḥ arvataḥ śiraḥ abhidhāya ninīṣati // yat adya rātri subhage vibhajanti ayaḥ vasu / yat etat asmān bhojaya yathā id anyān upāyasi //
column2: As millet hurried through the air before us is beheld no more. So cause the man to vanish, Night, who plans to do us injury. The thief hast thou kept far away, the robber driver of our kine. Even him who having covered up the horse's head would lead him off.

column1: uṣase naḥ pari dehi sarvān rātri anāgasaḥ / uṣāḥ naḥ ahne ā bhajāt ahar tubhyam vibhāvari //
column2: Do thou entrust us to the Dawn, all of us free from sin, O Night. May Dawn deliver us to Day, and Day to thee, O glorious One.

column1: ayutaḥ aham ayutaḥ me ātmā ayutam me cakṣuḥ ayutam me śrotram / ayutaḥ me prāṇaḥ ayutaḥ me apānaḥ ayutaḥ me vyānaḥ ayutaḥ aham sarvaḥ /
column2: Undisturbed am I, undisturbed is my soul, undisturbed mine eye, undisturbed mine ear, undisturbed is mine in-breathing, undisturbed mine out-breathing, undisturbed my diffusive- breath, undisturbed the whole of me.

column1: devasya tvā savituḥ prasave aśvinoḥ bāhubhyām pūṣṇaḥ hastābhyām prasūtaḥ ā rabhe //
column2: Under the impulse of the God Savitar, sent forth from the arms- of the Asvins and both hands of Pūshan I have taken thee.

column1: kāmaḥ tat agre sam avartata manasaḥ retaḥ prathamam yat āsīt / sa kāma kāmena bṛhatā sayonī rāyaḥ poṣam yajamānāya dhehi //
column2: Thereafter rose Desire in the beginning, Desire the primal seed and germ of Spirit. O Kāma dwelling with the lofty Kāma, give growth of riches to the sacrificer.

column1: tvam kāma sahasā asi pratiṣṭhitaḥ vibhuḥ vibhāvā sakhaḥ ā sakhīyate / tvam ugraḥ pṛtanāsu sasahiḥ sahaḥ ojaḥ yajamānāya dhehi //
column2: Thou, Kāma, art victorious, famous, potent, splendid, a friend. to him who seeks thy friendship. Mighty and overpowering in battle, give strength and vigour to the sacrificer.

column1: dūrāt cakamānāya pratipāṇāya akṣaye / ā asmai aśṛṇvan āśāḥ kāmena ajanayan svar /
column2: They heard his prayers, and they begot, by Kāma, heavenly- light for him. Who from a distance longed for it, a dealer ready to exchange.

column1: yat kāma kāmayamānāḥ idam kṛṇmasi te haviḥ / tat naḥ sarvam sam ṛdhyatām atha etasya haviṣaḥ vīhi svāhā /
column2: O Kāma, with whatever wish we make this offering to thee, May it be all fulfilled to us. Then taste this sacrifice, All hail!

column1: kālaḥ aśvaḥ vahati sapta raśmiḥ sahasra akṣaḥ ajaraḥ bhūri retāḥ / tam ā rohanti kavayaḥ vipaścitaḥ tasya cakrā bhuvanāni viśvā /
column2: Prolific, thousand-eyed, and undecaying, a horse with seven reins Time bears us onward. Sages inspired with holy knowledge mount him: his chariot wheels are all the worlds of creatures.

column1: sapta cakrān vahati kālaḥ eṣa sapta asya nābhīḥ amṛtam nu akṣaḥ / saḥ imā viśvā bhuvanāni añjat kālaḥ saḥ īyate prathamaḥ nu devaḥ /
column2: This Time hath seven rolling wheels and seven naves immorality is the chariot's axle. This Time brings hitherward all worlds about us: as primal Deity is he entreated.

column1: pūrṇaḥ kumbhaḥ adhi kāle āhitaḥ tam vai paśyāmaḥ bahudhā nu santam / saḥ imā viśvā bhuvanāni pratyaṅ kālam tam āhuḥ parame vyoman /
column2: On Time is laid an overflowing beaker: this we behold in many a place appearing. He carries from us all these worlds of creatures. They call him Kāla in the loftiest heaven.

column1: saḥ eva sam bhuvanāni ābharat saḥ eva sam bhuvanāni pari ait / pitā san abhavat putraḥ eṣām tasmāt vai na anyat param asti tejaḥ /
column2: He only made the worlds of life, he only gathered the worlds of living things together. Their son did he become who was their Father: no other higher power than he existeth.

column1: kālaḥ amūm divam ajanayat kālaḥ imāḥ pṛthivīḥ uta / kāle ha bhūtam bhavyam ceṣitam ha vi tiṣṭhate // kālaḥ bhūtim asṛjata kāle tapati sūryaḥ / kāle ha viśvā bhūtāni kāle cakṣuḥ vi paśyati //
column2: Kāla created yonder heaven, and Kāla made these realms of earth. By Kāla, stirred to motion, both what is and what shall be expand. Kāla created land; the Sun in Kāla hath his light and heat. In Kāla rest all things that be: in Kāla doth the eye discern.

column1: kāle manaḥ kāle prāṇaḥ kāle nāma samāhitam / kālena sarvāḥ nandanti āgatena prajāḥ imāḥ /
column2: In Kāla mind, in Kāla breath, in Kāla name are fixt and joined. These living creatures, one and all, rejoice when Kāla hath approached.

column1: kāle tapaḥ kāle jyeṣṭham kāle brahma samāhitam / kālaḥ ha sarvasya īśvaraḥ yaḥ pitā āsīt prajāpateḥ /
column2: Kāla embraces Holy Fire, the Highest, Brahma in himself. Yea, Kāla, who was father of Prajāpati, is Lord of All.

column1: tena iṣitam tena jātam tat u tasmin pratiṣṭhitam / kālaḥ ha brahma bhūtvā bibharti parameṣṭhinam /
column2: He made, he stirred this universe to motion, and on him it rests. He, Kāla, having now become Brahma, holds Parameshthin up.

column1: kālaḥ prajāḥ asṛjata kālaḥ agre prajāpatim / svayaṃbhūḥ kaśyapaḥ kālāt tapaḥ kālāt ajāyata /
column2: Kāla created living things and, first of all, Prajāpati. From Kāla self-made Kasyapa, from Kāla Holy Fire was born.

column1: kālāt āpaḥ sam abhavan kālāt brahma tapaḥ diśaḥ / kālena ud eti sūryaḥ kāle ni viśate punar /
column2: From Kāla sprang the Waters, sprang the regions, Brahma, Holy Fire. The Sun ascends by Kāla, and in Kāla sinks again to rest.

column1: kālena vātaḥ pavate kālena pṛthivī mahī / dyauḥ mahī kāle āhitā /
column2: By Kāla freshly blows the wind, mighty through Kāla is the Earth: on Kāla rests the mighty Sky.

column1: kālaḥ ha bhūtam bhavyam ca putraḥ ajanayat purā / kālāt ṛcaḥ sam abhavan yajuḥ kālāt ajāyata /
column2: In Kāla erst the text produced what is and what is yet to be. From Kāla sprang the Richas, and from Kāla was the Yajus born.

column1: kālaḥ yajñam sam airayat devebhyaḥ bhāgam akṣitam / kāle gandharva apsarasaḥ kāle lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ /
column2: They formed in Kāla sacrifice, eternal portion for the Gods. In Kāla the Gandharvas and Apsarasas and worlds abide.

column1: kāle ayam aṅgirāḥ devaḥ atharvā ca adhi tiṣṭhataḥ / imam ca lokam paramam ca lokam puṇyān ca lokān vidhṛtīḥ ca puṇyāḥ / sarvān lokān abhijitya brahmaṇā kālaḥ saḥ īyate paramaḥ nu devaḥ /
column2: Atharvan and this Angiras in Kāla are supreme o'er heaven. Both this world and the world that is most lofty, the pure worlds and pure intermediate spaces,— Yea, having conquered all the worlds by Brahma, Kāla as God Supreme is supplicated.

column1: rātrim rātrim a prayātam bharantaḥ aśvāya iva tiṣṭhate ghāsam asmai / rāyaḥ poṣeṇa sam iṣā madantaḥ mā te agne prativeśāḥ riṣāma /
column2: Bringing, as 'twere, with care unceasing fodder night after night to feed this stabled Courser, Joying in food and in the growth of riches, may we thy neigh- bours, Agni, ne'er be injured.

column1: yā te vasoḥ vātaḥ iṣuḥ sā te eṣā tayā naḥ mṛḍa / rāyaḥ poṣeṇa sam iṣā madantaḥ mā te agne prativeśāḥ riṣāma /
column2: Here is thine own desire for wealth: through this be gracious unto us. Joying in food and in the growth of riches, may we thy neigh- bours, Agni, ne'er be injured.

column1: sāyam sāyam gṛhapatiḥ naḥ agniḥ prātar prātar saumanasasya dātā / vasoḥ vasoḥ vasu dānaḥ edhi vayam tvā indhānāḥ tanvam puṣema / prātar prātar gṛhapatiḥ naḥ agniḥ sāyaṃsāyam saumanasasya dātā / vasoḥ vasoḥ vasu dānaḥ edhi indhānāḥ tvā śataṃhimāḥ ṛdhema /
column2: Each eve that comes our household's Lord is Agni, showing his. loving-kindness every morning. Bestow upon us treasure after treasure: enkindling thee may we increase thy body. Each morn that comes our household's Lord is Agni, showing. his loving-kindness every evening. Vouchsafe us treasure after treasure: kindling thee may we prosper through a hundred winters.

column1: a paścā dagdha annasya bhūyāsam / anna ādāya annapataye rudrāya namaḥ agnaye / sabhyaḥ sabhām me pāhi ye ca sabhyāḥ sabhāsadaḥ /
column2: Never may I come short of food to feed me. Glory to Agni, Rudra, the consumer and the Lord of food!

column1: tvām indra puruhūta viśvam āyuḥ vi aśnavan / aharahar balim id te harantaḥ aśvāya iva tiṣṭhate ghāsam agne / yamasya lokāt adhi ā babhūvitha pramadāḥ martyān pra yunakṣi dhīraḥ / ekākinā sa ratham yāsi vidvān svapnam mimānaḥ asurasya yonau /
column2: Only to thee bringing our tribute, Agni, each day as fodder to a stabled courser, Joying in food and in the growth of riches, may we the neigh- bours, Agni ne'er be injured. Thou art come hither from the world of Yama: thou, resolute, affectest men with rapture. Thou, Sleep, created in the Asura's dwelling, goest, well-know- ing, with the solitary.

column1: bandhaḥ tvā agre viśva cayāḥ apaśyat purā rātryāḥ janitoḥ eke ahni / tatas svapna idam adhi ā babhūvitha bhiṣagbhyaḥ rūpam apagūhamānaḥ /
column2: At first the all-containing, depth beheld thee, ere Night was born, when only Day existed. Thence hast thou come, thence, Sleep, hast thou come hither, concealing, deep within, all form and figure.

column1: bṛhat gāvāsurebhyaḥ adhi devān upāvartata mahimānam ichan / tasmai svapnāya dadhuḥ ādhipatyam trayastriṃśāsaḥ svar ānaśānāḥ /
column2: Come from the Asuras in lofty, glory, he hath approached the Gods in search of greatness. Winners of heavenly light, the Three-and-Thirty endowed this Sleep with his supreme dominion.

column1: na etām viduḥ pitaraḥ na uta devāḥ yeṣām jalpiḥ carati antarā idam / trite svapnam adadhuḥ āptye naraḥ ādityāsaḥ varuṇena anuśiṣṭāḥ /
column2: Of him nor Fathers nor the Gods have knowledge, the Gods whose gentle talk is still about him. Urged by command of Varuna the Ādityas, Heroes, transported Sleep to Trita Āptya.

column1: yasya krūram abhajanta duṣkṛtaḥ asvapnena sukṛtaḥ puṇyam āyuḥ / svar madasi parameṇa bandhunā tapyamānasya manasaḥ adhi jajñiṣe /
column2: Thou whose severity hath reached ill-doers, and whose reward the good have gained in slumber, Delightest heaven with thy most lofty kinship, born from his spirit who was worn and weary.

column1: vidma te sarvāḥ parijāḥ purastāt vidma svapna yaḥ adhipāḥ iha te / yaśaśvinaḥ naḥ yaśasā iha pāhi ārāt dviṣebhiḥ apa yāhi dūram /
column2: Of old we know all places whence thou comest. O Sleep, we know him who is here thy ruler. Protect us here illustrious with glory. Go, from afar, with poisons, into distance.

column1: yathā kalām yathā śapham yathā ṛṇam samnayanti / eva duṣvapnyam sarvam apriye sam nayāmasi //
column2: As men discharge the utmost debt, collect the eighth and sixteenth part, So to the foeman we transfer together all the evil dream.

column1: sam rājānaḥ aguḥ sam ṛṇāmi aguḥ sam kuṣṭhāḥ aguḥ sam kalāḥ aguḥ / sam asmāsu yat duṣvapnyam niḥ dviṣate duṣvapnyam suvāma /
column2: Princes came together, debts came together, Kushthas came to- gether, Sixteenths came together. The whole evil dream that hath visited us we send away as a bad dream to the man who hates us.

column1: devānām patnīnām garbha yamasya kara yaḥ bhadraḥ svapna / sa mama yaḥ pāpaḥ tat dviṣate pra hiṇmaḥ / mā tṛṣṭānām asi kṛṣṇa śakuneḥ mukham / tam tvā svapna tathā sam vidma sa tvam svapna aśvaḥ iva kāyam aśvaḥ iva nīnāham / anā asmākam deva pīyum piyārum vapa yat asmāsu duṣvapnyam yat goṣu yat ca naḥ gṛhe /
column2: Child of Gods' Consorts, minister of Yama is the good Dream: that which is my trouble we drive away to the enemy. Thou whose name is Rough art the mouth of the Black Bird. As such we know thee, Dream, as such we know thee well. Like a horse art thou, O Dream. As they bind girth and surcingle on a horse, so bind the alien mischief-maker, the scorner of the Gods.

column1: anā asmākaḥ tat deva pīyuḥ piyāruḥ niṣkam iva prati muñcatām / nava aratnīn apamayāḥ asmākam tatas pari / duṣvapnyam sarvam dviṣate niḥ dayāmasi // ghṛtasya jūtiḥ samanā sa devā saṃvatsaram haviṣā vardhayantī / śrotram cakṣuḥ prāṇaḥ achinnaḥ naḥ astu achinnāḥ vayam āyuṣaḥ varcasaḥ /
column2: The evil dream that threatens us, threatens our cattle or our home. That let the scorner of the Gods, the alien mischief-maker bind as a gold jewel round his neck. Having measured off nine cubits' distance from us we give away the whole of the evil dream to the man who hates us.

column1: tvam agne vrata pāḥ asi devaḥ ā martyeṣu ā / tvam yajñeṣu īḍyaḥ /
column2: God among mortals, Agni, thou art guard of holy Law, thou art To be adored in sacred rites.

column1: yat vaḥ vayam pramināma vratāni viduṣām devāḥ aviduṣṭarāsaḥ / agniḥ tat viśvāt ā pṛṇātu vidvān somasya yaḥ brāhmaṇām āviveśa /
column2: When, ignorant, we violate the statutes of you, O Deities, with whom is knowledge, Wise Agni shall correct our faults and failings, and Soma who hath entered into Brāhmans.

column1: ā devānām api panthām aganma yat śaknavāma tat anupravoḍhum / agniḥ vidvān sa yajāt saḥ id hotā saḥ adhvarān saḥ ṛtūn kalpayāti //
column2: To the Gods' pathway have we come desiring to execute what work we may accomplish. Let Agni—for he knows—complete the worship. He is the Priest: let him fix rites and seasons.

column1: vāc me āsan nasoḥ prāṇaḥ cakṣuḥ akṣṇoḥ śrotram karṇayoḥ / a palitāḥ keśāḥ a śoṇāḥ dantāḥ bahu bāhvoḥ balam /
column2: May I have voice in my mouth, breath in my nostrils, sight in mine eyes, hearing in mine ears, hair that hath not turned gray, teeth free from yellowness, and much strength in mine arms.

column1: ūrvoḥ ojaḥ jaṅghayoḥ javaḥ pādayoḥ / pratiṣṭhā ariṣṭāni me sarvātmā anibhṛṣṭaḥ / tanūḥ tanvā me sahe dataḥ sarvam āyuḥ aśīya / syonam me sīda puruḥ pṛṇasva pavamānaḥ svarge /
column2: May I have power in my thighs, swiftness in my legs, stedfast- ness in my feet. May all my members be uninjured and my soul unimpaired. May my self remain in my body: may I enjoy the full time of life, Rest thee pleasantly: pour forth abundance, purifying thyself in Svarga.

column1: priyam mā kṛṇu deveṣu priyam rājasu mā kṛṇu / priyam sarvasya paśyataḥ uta śūdraḥ uta ārye /
column2: Make me beloved among the Gods, beloved among the Princes, make Me dear to everyone who sees, to Sūdra and to Aryan man.

column1: ud tiṣṭha brahmaṇas pate devān yajñena bodhaya / āyuḥ prāṇam prajām paśūn kīrtim yajamānam ca vardhaya //
column2: Rise up, O Brāhmanaspati; awake the Gods with sacrifice. Strengthen the Sacrificer: aid life, breath, and off-spring, cattle, fame.

column1: agne samidham āhārṣam bṛhate jātavedase / sa me śraddhām ca medhām ca jātavedāḥ pra yacchatu //
column2: For lofty Jātavedas I have brought the fuel hither first. May he who knoweth all bestow faith and intelligence on me.

column1: idhmena tvā jātavedaḥ samidhā vardhayāmasi / tathā tvam asmān vardhaya prajayā ca dhanena ca /
column2: With fuel and with flaming wood we, Jātavedas, strengthen thee; So do thou strengthen us in turn with children and with store of wealth.

column1: yat agne yāni kāni cit ā te dārūṇi dadhmasi / sarvam tat astu me śivam tat juṣasva yaviṣṭhya //
column2: Whatever even be the logs which, Agni, we lay down for thee, propitious be it all to me: accept it, O most youthful God.

column1: etāḥ te agne samidhaḥ tvam iddhaḥ samidh bhava / āyuḥ asmāsu dhehi amṛta tvam ācāryāya //
column2: Agni, these logs are thine: with these be, fain to burn! a flaming brand. Vouchsafe us length of life and give us hope of immortality.

column1: hariḥ suparṇaḥ divam āruhaḥ arciṣā ye tvā dipsanti divam utpatantam / ava tām jahi harasā jātavedaḥ a bibhyat ugraḥ arciṣā divam ā roha sūrya //
column2: A Golden Eagle thou hast soared with light to heaven. Those who would harm thee as thou fliest skyward. Beat down, O Jātavedas, with thy fury. The strong hath feared: to heaven mount up with light, O Sūrya.

column1: ayaḥ jālāḥ asurāḥ māyinaḥ ayasmayaiḥ pāśaiḥ aṅkinaḥ ye caranti / tān te randhayāmi harasā jātavedaḥ sahasra ṛṣṭiḥ sapatnān pramṛṇan pāhi vajraḥ /
column2: The Asuras with iron nets, magicians, who roam about with hooks and bonds of iron, With wrath I make thy thralls, O Jātavedas. Come as a bolt foe- quelling, thousand pointed.

column1: paśyema śaradaḥ śatam //
column2: A hundred autumns may we see.

column1: jīvema śaradaḥ śatam // budhyema śaradaḥ śatam //
column2: A hundred autumns may we live. A hundred autumns may we know.

column1: rohema śaradaḥ śatam // pūṣā ima śaradaḥ śatam //
column2: A hundred autumns may we grow. A hundred autumns may we thrive.

column1: bhavema śaradaḥ śatam // bhūṣema śaradaḥ śatam //
column2: A hundred autumns may we be. A hundred autumns may we bide.

column1: bhūyasīḥ śaradaḥ śatam //
column2: A hundred, yea, and even more.

column1: avyasaḥ ca vyacasaḥ ca bilam vi syāmi māyayā / tābhyām uddhṛtya vedam atha karmāṇi kṛṇmahe /
column2: Both of broad and narrow I with magic power unclose the mouth. With these when we have raised the bunch of grass we pay the holy rites.

column1: jīvā stha jīvyāsam sarvam āyuḥ jīvyāsam // upajīvā stha upa jīvyāsam sarvam āyuḥ jīvyāsam /
column2: Ye are alive. I fain would live. I fain would live my complete term of life.

column1: saṃjīvāḥ stha sam jīvyāsam sarvam āyuḥ jīvyāsam /
column2: Ye remain alive. I fain would remain alive. I fain would live my complete term of life.

column1: jīvalā stha jīvyāsam sarvam āyuḥ jīvyāsam // indra jīva sūrya jīva devāḥ jīvāḥ jīvyāsam aham / sarvam āyuḥ jīvyāsam /
column2: Live, Indra. Live Sūrya. Live, ye Gods. I fain would live. Fain would I live my complete term of life.

column1: stutā mayā vara dā veda mātā pra codayantām pāvamānī dvijānām / āyuḥ prāṇam prajām paśum kīrtim draviṇam brahmavarcasam / mahyam dattvā vrajata brahma lokam / yasmāt kośāt udabharāma vedam tasmin antar ava dadhmaḥ enam / kṛtam iṣṭam brahmaṇaḥ vīryeṇa tena mā devāḥ tapasā avata iha /
column2: Let my libations, giving boons, adoring, further the Twice-born's song that honours Soma. Go ye to Brahma's world having enriched me with life and breath, with children and with cattle, with fame and wealth, and with a Brāhman's lustre.

column1: indra tvā vṛṣabham vayam sute some havāmahe / sa pāhi madhvaḥ andhasaḥ /
column2: Thee, Indra, we invoke, the Bull, what time the Soma hath been pressed. Drink of the sweetly-flavoured juice.

column1: marutaḥ yasya hi kṣaye pāthāḥ divaḥ vimahasaḥ / sa sugopātamaḥ janaḥ /
column2: The best of guardian hath the man within whose dwelling-place ye drink, O Maruts, giants of the sky.

column1: ukṣa annāya vaśā annāya soma pṛṣṭhāya vedhase / stomaiḥ vidhema agnaye /
column2: Let us serve Agni with our hyms, Sage who consumeth ox and cow, Who beareth Soma on his back.

column1: marutaḥ potrāt suṣṭubhaḥ su arkāt ṛtunā somam pibantu //
column2: Let the Maruts drink Trishtups from the Potar's cup, according to the season Soma from heaven.

column1: agniḥ āgnīdhrāt suṣṭubhaḥ su arkāt ṛtunā somam pibatu //
column2: Let Agni from the Kindler's cup drink Trishtups, according to the season Soma from heaven.

column1: indraḥ brahmā brāhmaṇāt suṣṭubhaḥ su arkāt ṛtunā somam pibatu //
column2: Let Indra the Brāhman from the Brāhman's cup drink Trishtups, according to the season Soma from heaven.

column1: devaḥ draviṇaḥ dāḥ potrāt suṣṭubhaḥ su arkāt ṛtunā somam pibatu //
column2: Let the God, Granter of Wealth, from the Potar's cup drink Trishtups, according to the season Soma from heaven.

column1: ā yāhi suṣuma hi te indra somam pibā imam / ā idam barhiḥ sadaḥ mama /
column2: Come, we have pressed the juice for thee: O Indra, drink this Soma here. Seat thee on this my sacred grass.

column1: ā tvā brahma yujā harī vahatām indra keśinā / upa brahmāṇi naḥ śṛṇu //
column2: Let both thy bay steeds, yoked by prayer long-maned, O Indra, bring thee nigh.

column1: brahmāṇaḥ tvā vayam yujā soma pām indra sominaḥ / sutāvantaḥ havāmahe //
column2: We Soma-bearing Brāhmans call thee Soma-drinker with thy friend, We, Indra, who have pressed the juice.

column1: ā naḥ yāhi sutāvataḥ asmākam suṣṭutīḥ upa / pibā su śiprin andhasaḥ / ā te siñcāmi kukṣyoḥ anu gātrā vi dhāvatu / gṛbhāya jihvayā madhu //
column2: Come unto us who poured the juice, come hither to our eulogies. Drink of the juice, O fair of face. I pour it down within thee, so through all thy members let it run. Take with thy tongue the pleasant drink.

column1: svāduḥ te astu saṃsude madhumān tanve tava / somaḥ śam astu te hṛde /
column2: Sweet to thy body let it be, delicious be the savoury juice. Sweet be the Soma to thy heart.

column1: ayam u tvā vicarṣaṇe janīḥ iva abhi saṃvṛtaḥ / pra somaḥ indra sarpatu /
column2: Like women, let this Soma juice invested with its raiment, glide.. Most active Indra, close to thee.

column1: tuvi grīvaḥ vapodaraḥ su bāhuḥ andhasaḥ sade / indraḥ vṛtrāṇi jighnate /
column2: Mighty in bulk, strong-necked, stout-armed in the wild rapture. of the juice Doth Indra smite the foemen dead.

column1: indra prehi puras tvam viśvasya īśānaḥ ojasā / vṛtrāṇi vṛtraham jahi //
column2: Indra, advance, go forward thou who by thy might art Lord of all. Slay, Vritra-slayer slay thy foes.

column1: dīrghaḥ te astu aṅkuśaḥ yena vasu prayacchasi / yajamānāya sunvate /
column2: Long be thy grasping-hook wherewith thou givest treasure unto- him Who pours the juice and worships thee.

column1: ayam te indra somaḥ nipūtaḥ adhi barhiṣi / ehi īm asya drava piba /
column2: Here, Indra, is thy Soma draught, made pure upon the sacred. grass. Run hither, come and drink thereof.

column1: śāci go śāci pūjana ayam raṇāya te sutaḥ / ākhaṇḍala pra hūyase /
column2: Famed for thy radiance, worshipped well! this juice is shed for thy delight: Thou art invoked, Ākhandala!

column1: yaḥ te śṛṅga vṛṣaḥ napāt praṇapāt kuṇḍapāyyaḥ / ni asmin dadhre ā manaḥ / indra tvā vṛṣabham vayam sute some havāmahe / sa pāhi madhvaḥ andhasaḥ / indra kratu vidam sutam somam harya puruṣṭuta / pibā vṛṣasva tātṛpim /
column2: Thee, Indra, we invoke, the Bull, what time the Soma is ex- pressed. So drink thou of the savoury juice. Indra, whom many laud, accept the strength-confering Soma juice. Quaff, pour down drink that satisfies.

column1: indra pra naḥ dhitāvānam yajñam viśvebhiḥ devebhiḥ / tira stavāna viśpate /
column2: Indra, with all the Gods promote our wealth-bestowing sacrifice, Thou highly-lauded Lord of men.

column1: indra somāḥ sutāḥ ime tava pra yanti satpate / kṣayam candrāsaḥ indavaḥ / dadhiṣva jaṭhare sutam somam indra vareṇyam / tava dyukṣāsaḥ indavaḥ /
column2: Lord of the brave, to thee proceed these drops of Soma juice expressed, The bright drops to thy dwelling-place. Within thy belly, Indra take Soma the juice most excellent: The heavenly drops belong to thee.

column1: girvaṇaḥ pāhi naḥ sutam madhoḥ dhārābhiḥ ajyase / indra tvā adātam id yaśaḥ /

column2: Leading his band Indra encompassed Vritra; weak grew the wily leader enchanters. He who burns fierce in forests slaughtered Vyansa, and made the milch-kine of nights apparent.

column2: Indra, light-winner, days' creator, conquered, as guardian, hostile bands with those who loved him. For man the days' bright ensign he illumined, and found the light for his great joy and gladness. Forward to fiercely falling blows pressed Indra, hero-like doing many hero exploits. Those holy songs he taught the bard who praised him, and widely spread these Dawns' resplendent colour.

column2: They laud the mighty acts of him the mighty, the many glorious deeds performed by Indra. He in his strength, with all-surpassing prowess, through wond- rous arts crushed the malignant Dasyus.

column2: Lord of the brave, Indra who rules the people gave freedom to the Gods by might and battle. Wise singers glorify with chanted praises these his achievements in Vivasvān's dwelling. column2: A cry was raised which reached the Gods, O Indra, a cry to them to send us strength in combat. None among men knows his own life's duration: bear us in safety over these our troubles.

Lover of praise, none else but thou receives our laud: as Earth loves all her creatures, love thou this our hymn.

Thou, who hast thunder for thy weapon, with thy bolt hast shattered into pieces this broad massive cloud. Thou hast sent down obstructed floods that they may flow: thou hast, thine own for ever, all victorious might.

column2: The son of Angiras, meeting the cattle, as Bhaga, brought in Aryaman among us. As Friend of men he decks the wife and husband. As for the race, Brihaspati, nerve our coursers.

column2: As the Sun dews with meath the seat of Order, and casts a flam- ing meteor down from heaven, So from the rock Brihaspati forced the cattle, and cleft the earth's skin as it were with water.
