column1: āpaḥ na sindhum abhi yat samakṣaran somāsaḥ indram kulyāḥ iva hradam / vardhanti viprāḥ mahaḥ asya sādane yavam na vṛṣṭiḥ divyena dānunā /
column2: As waters flow together to the river, thus Somas to Indra flow, as rivulets to the lake. In place of sacrifice sages exalt his might, as the rain swells the corn by moisture sent from heaven.

column1: vṛṣā na kruddhaḥ patayat rajaḥsu ā yaḥ arya patnīḥ akṛṇot imāḥ apaḥ / sa sunvate maghavā jīra dānave avindat jyotiḥ manave haviṣmate / ud jāyatām paraśu jyotiṣā saha bhūyāḥ ṛtasya su dughā purāṇavat / vi rocatām aruṣaḥ bhānunā śuciḥ svar na śukram śuśucīta satpatiḥ /
column2: He rushes through the region like a furious bull, he who hath made these floods the dames of worthy lords. This Maghavan hath found light for the man who brings oblation, sheds the juice, and promptly pours his gifts. Let the keen axe come forth together with the light: here be, as erst, the teeming cow of sacrifice. Let the Red God shine pure with his refulgent ray, and let the Lord of heroes glow like heaven's clear sheen.

column1: gobhiḥ tarema amatim durevām yavena kṣudham puruhūta viśvām / vayam rājabhiḥ prathamā dhanāni asmākena vṛjanena jayema /
column2: O much-invoked, may we subdue all famine and evil want with store of grain and cattle. May we allied, as first in rank, with princes, obtain possessions by our own exertion.

column1: bṛhaspatiḥ naḥ pari pātu paścāt uta uttarasmāt adharāt aghāyoḥ / indraḥ purastāt uta madhyataḥ naḥ sakhā sakhibhyaḥ varivaḥ kṛṇotu //
column2: Brihaspati protect us from the rearward, and from above, and from below, from sinners. May Indra from the front, and from the centre, as friend to friends, vouchsafe us room and freedom.

column1: bṛhaspate yuvam indraḥ ca vasvaḥ divyasya īśāthe uta pārthivasya / dhattam rayim stuvate kīraye cit yūyam pāta svastibhiḥ sadā naḥ /
column2: Ye twain are Lords of wealth in earth and heaven, thou, O Brihaspati, and thou, O Indra. Mean though he be, give wealth to him who lauds you. Preserve us evermore, ye Gods, with blessings.

column1: vayam u tvā taditarthāḥ indra tvāyantaḥ sakhāyaḥ / kaṇvāḥ ukthebhiḥ jarante /
column2: This, even this, O Indra, we implore: as thy devoted friends, The Kanvas praise thee with their hymns.

column1: na gha īm anyat ā papana vajrin apasaḥ naviṣṭau / tava id u stomam ciketa /
column2: Naught else, O Thunderer, have I praised in the skilled singer's eulogy: On thy laud only have I thought.

column1: ichanti devāḥ sunvantam na svapnāya spṛhayanti / yanti pramādam atandrāḥ /
column2: The Gods seek him who presses out the Soma; they desire not sleep: Incessantly they punish sloth.

column1: vayam indra tvāyavaḥ abhi pra nonumaḥ vṛṣan / viddhi tu asya naḥ vaso /
column2: Faithful to thee we loudly sing, heroic Indra, songs to thee. Mark, gracious Lord, this act of ours.

column1: mā naḥ nide ca vaktave aryaḥ randhīḥ arāvne / tve api kratuḥ mama /
column2: Give us not up to man's reproach, to foeman's hateful calumny: In thee alone is all my strength.

column1: tvam varmā asi saprathaḥ puroyodhaḥ ca vṛtrahan / tvayā prati bruve yujā /
column2: Thou art mine ample coat of mail, my champion, Vritra-slayes, thou. With thee for Friend I brave the foe.

column1: vārtrahatyāya śavase pṛtanāṣāhyāya ca / indra tvā vartayāmasi // arvācīnam su te manaḥ uta cakṣuḥ śatakrato / indra kṛṇvantu vāghataḥ / nāmāni te śatakrato viśvābhiḥ gīrbhiḥ īmahe / indra abhimātiṣāhye //
column2: O Indra, Lord of Hundred Powers, may those who praise thee hitherward. Direct thy spirit and thine eye. O Indra, Lord of Hundred Powers, with all our songs we invocate. Thy names for triumph over foes.

column1: puruṣṭutasya dhāmabhiḥ śatena mahayāmasi / indrasya carṣaṇī dhṛtaḥ / indram vṛtrāya hantave puruhūtam upa bruve / bhareṣu vājasātaye / vājeṣu sāsahiḥ bhava tvām īmahe śatakrato / indra vṛtrāya hantave /
column2: We strive for glory through the powers immense of him whom many praise, Of Indra who supports mankind. For the foe's slaughter I address Indra whom many invocate, To win us booty in the wars.

column1: dyumneṣu pṛtanājye pṛtsutūrṣu śravaḥsu ca / indra sākṣva abhimātiṣu /
column2: In splendid combats of the hosts, in glories where the fight is won, Indra, be victor over foes.

column1: śuṣmintamam naḥ ūtaye dyumninam pāhi jāgṛvim / indra somam śatakrato /
column2: Drink thou the Soma for our help, bright, vigilant, exceeding strong, O Indra, Lord of Hundred Powers.

column1: indriyāṇi śatakrato yā te janeṣu pañcasu / indra tāni te ā vṛṇe /
column2: O Satakratu, powers which thou mid the Five Races hast dis- played These, Indra, do I claim of thee.

column1: agan indra śravaḥ bṛhat dyumnam dadhiṣva duṣṭaram / ud te śuṣmam tirāmasi // arvāvataḥ naḥ ā gahi atha u śakra parāvataḥ / u lokaḥ yaḥ te adrivas indra iha tatas ā gahi //
column2: Indra, great glory hast thou gained. Win splendid fame which none may mar: We make thy might perpetual. Come to us either from anear, or, Sakra, come from far away. Indra, wherever be thy home, come to us thence, O Thunder- armed.

column1: indraḥ aṅgam mahat bhayam abhi sat apa cucyavat / sa hi sthiraḥ vicarṣaṇiḥ /
column2: Verily Indra, conquering all, driveth even mighty fear away; For firm is he and swift to act.

column1: indraḥ ca mṛlayāti naḥ na naḥ paścāt agham naśat / bhadram bhavāti naḥ puras /
column2: Indra be gracious unto us: sin shall not reach us afterward . And good shall be before us still,

column1: indraḥ āśābhyaḥ pari sarvābhyaḥ abhayam karat / jetā śatrūn vicarṣaṇiḥ //
column2: From all the regions of the world let Indra send security. The foe-subduer, swift to act.

column1: ni u su vācam pra mahe bharāmahe giraḥ indrāya sadane vivasvataḥ / nu cit hi ratnam sasatām iva avidat na duṣṭutiḥ draviṇaḥ deṣu śasyate / duraḥ aśvasya duraḥ indra goḥ asi duraḥ yavasya vasunaḥ inaḥ patiḥ / śikṣānaraḥ pradivaḥ akāma karśanaḥ sakhā sakhibhyaḥ tam idam gṛṇīmasi // śacīvas indra puru kṛt dyumattama tava id idam abhitas cekite vasu / atas saṃgṛbhya abhibhūtaḥ ā bhara mā tvāyataḥ jarituḥ kāmam ūnayīḥ /
column2: Giver of horses, Indra, giver, thou, of kine, giver of barley, thou art Lord and guard of wealth: Man's helper from of old, not disappointing hope, Friend of our friends, to thee as such we sing this praise. Indra, most splendid, powerful, rich in mighty deeds, this treasure spread around is known to be thine own. Gather therefrom. O Conqueror, and bring to us: fail not the hope of him who loves and sings to thee.

column1: ebhiḥ dyubhiḥ sumanāḥ ebhiḥ indubhiḥ nirundhānaḥ amatim gobhiḥ aśvinā / indreṇa dasyum darayantaḥ indubhiḥ yuta dveṣasaḥ sam iṣā rabhemahi //
column2: Well-pleased with these bright flames and with these Soma drops, take thou away our poverty with steeds and kine. With Indra scattering the Dasyu through these drops, freed from their hate may we obtain abundant food.

column1: sam indra rāyā sam iṣā rabhemahi sam vājebhiḥ puru ścandraiḥ abhidyubhiḥ / sam devyā pramatyā vīra śuṣmayā go agrayā aśvāvatyā rabhemahi //
column2: Let us obtain, O Indra, plenteous wealth and food, with strength exceeding glorious, shining to the sky. May we obtain the Goddess Providence, the strength of heroes, special source of cattle, rich in steeds.

column1: te tvā madāḥ amadan tāni vṛṣṇyā te somāsaḥ vṛtra hatyeṣu satpate / yat kārave daśa vṛtrāṇi aprati barhiṣmate ni sahasrāṇi barhayaḥ //
column2: These our libations, strength inspiring Soma draughts, gladdened thee in the fight with Vritra, Hero-Lord, What time thou slewest for the singer with trimmed grass ten thousand Vritras, thou resistless in thy might.

column1: yudhā yudham upa gha id eṣi dhṛṣṇuyā purā puram sam idam haṃsi ojasā / namyā yat indra sakhyā parāvati nibarhayaḥ namucim nāma māyinam /
column2: Thou goest on from fight to fight intrepidly, destroying castle after castle here with strength; Thou Indra, with thy friend who makes the foe bow down, slewest from far away the guileful Namuchi.

column1: tvam karañjam uta parṇayam vadhīḥ tejiṣṭhayā atithigvasya vartanī / tvam śatā vaṅgṛdasya abhinat puraḥ anānudaḥ pariṣūtāḥ ṛjiśvanā /
column2: Thou hast stuck down in death Karanja, Parnaya, in Atithigva's very glorious going forth: Unyielding, when Rijisvan compassed them with siege, thou hast destroyed the hundred towns of Vangrida.

column1: tvam etām jana rājñaḥ dvis daśā bandhunā suśravasā upajagmuṣaḥ / ṣaṣṭim sahasrā navatim nava śrutaḥ ni cakreṇa rathyā duṣpadā avṛṇak /
column2: With all-outstripping chariot wheel, O Indra, thou far-famed, hast overthrown the twice ten kings of men, With sixty thousand nine-and-ninety followers, who came in arms to fight with friendless Susravas.

column1: tvam āvitha suśravasam tava ūtibhiḥ tava trāmabhiḥ indra tūrvayāṇam / tva asmai kutsam atithigvam āyum mahe rājñe yūne arandhanāyaḥ //
column2: Thou hast protected Susravas with succour, and Tūrvayāna with thine aid, O Indra: Thou madest Kutsa, Atithigva, Ayu subject unto this king, the young, the mighty.

column1: yaḥ udṛci indra deva gopāḥ sakhāyaḥ te śivatamāḥ asāma / tvām stoṣāma tvayā su vīrāḥ drāghīyaḥ āyuḥ prataram dadhānāḥ /
column2: May we protected by the Gods hereafter remain thy very pro- sperous friends, O Indra. Thee we extol, enjoying through thy favour life-long and joyful and with store of heroes.

column1: abhi tvā vṛṣabhā sute sutam sṛjāmi pītaye / tṛmpā vi aśnuhi madam /
column2: Hero, the Soma being pressed I pour the juice for thee to drink Sate thee and finish thy carouse.

column1: mā tvā mūrāḥ aviṣyavaḥ mā upahasvānaḥ ā dabhan / mākīm brahma dviṣaḥ vanaḥ //
column2: Let not the fools, or those who mock, beguile thee when they seek thine aid: Love not the enemies of prayer.

column1: iha tvā goparīṇasā mahe mandantu rādhase / saraḥ gauraḥ yathā piba /
column2: Here let them with rich milky draught cheer thee to great munificence: Drink as the wild bull drinks the lake.

column1: abhi pra gopatim girā indram arca yathā vide / sūnum satyasya satpatim /
column2: Praise, even as he is known, with song Indra, the guardian of the kine, The Son of Truth, Lord of the brave.

column1: ā harayaḥ sasṛjrire aruṣīḥ adhi barhiṣi / yatra abhi saṃnavāmahe //
column2: Hither his bay steeds have been sent, red steeds are on the sacred grass. Where we in concert sing our songs.

column1: indrāya gāvaḥ āśiram duduhre vajriṇe madhu / yat sīm upahvare vidat /
column2: For Indra, Thunder-armed, the kine have yielded mingled milk and meath, What time he found them in the vault.

column1: ā tū naḥ indra madryak ghuvānaḥ soma pītaye / haribhyām yāhi adrivas /
column2: Invoked to drink the Soma juice come with thy bay steeds, Thunder-armed! Come, Indra, hitherward, to me.

column1: sattaḥ hotā naḥ ṛtviyaḥ tistire barhiḥ ānuṣak / ayujran prātar adrayaḥ /
column2: Our priest is seated true to time; the grass is regularly strewn; The pressing-stones were set at morn.

column1: imāḥ brahma brahma vāhaḥ kriyante ā barhiḥ sīda / vīhi śūra purolāśam / rārandhi savaneṣu naḥ eṣu stomeṣu vṛtrahan / uktheṣu indra girvaṇaḥ / matayaḥ soma pām urum rihanti śavasaḥ patim / indram vatsam na mātaraḥ /
column2: O Vritra-slayer, be thou pleased with these libations, with these hymns, Song-loving Indra, with our lauds. Our hymns caress the Lord of Strength, vast, drinker of the Soma's juice, Indra, as mother-cows their calf.

column1: sa mandasva hi andhasaḥ rādhase tanvā mahe / na stotāram nide karaḥ //
column2: Delight thee with the juice we pour for thine own great munificence: Yield not thy singer to reproach.

column1: vayam indra tvāyavaḥ haviṣmantaḥ jarāmahe / uta tvam asmayuḥ vaso /
column2: We, Indra, dearly loving thee, bearing oblation, sing thee hymns: Thou, Vasu, nearly lovest us.

column1: māre asmat vi mumucaḥ hari priya arvāṅ yāhi / indra svadhāvas matsva iha / arvāñcam tvā sukhe rathe vahatām indra keśinā / ghṛtasnū barhiḥ āsade /
column2: O thou to whom thy Bays are dear, loose not thy horses far from us: Here glad thee, Indra, Lord Divine. May long-maned courses, dropping oil, bring thee on swift car hitherward. Indra, to seat thee on the grass.

column1: upa naḥ sutam ā gahi somam indra gavāśiram / haribhyām yaḥ te asmayuḥ /
column2: Come to the juice that we have pressed, to Soma, Indra! blent with milk: Come, favouring us, thy bay-drawn car!

column1: tam indra madam ā gahi barhiṣṭhām grāvabhiḥ sutam / kuvid nu asya tṛpṇavaḥ /
column2: Come, Indra, to this gladdening drink, placed on the grass, pressed out with stones: Wilt thou not drink thy fill thereof?

column1: indram itthā giraḥ mama achāguḥ iṣitāḥ itas / āvṛte soma pītaye /
column2: To Indra have my songs of praise gone forth, thus rapidly sent hence, To turn him to the Soma-draught.

column1: indram somasya pītaye stomaiḥ iha havāmahe / ukthebhiḥ kuvid āgamat / indra somāḥ sutāḥ ime tān dadhiṣva śatakrato / jathare vājinīvaso /
column2: Indra, these Somas are expressed, Take them within thy belly, Lord Of Hundred Powers, thou Prince of wealth.

column1: vidma hi tvā dhanaṃjayam vājeṣu dadhṛṣam kave / adha te sumnam īmahe /
column2: We know thee winner of the spoil and resolute in battles, Sage! Therefore thy blessing we implore.

column1: imam indra gavāśiram yavāśiram ca naḥ piba / āgatyā vṛṣabhiḥ sutam /
column2: Borne hither by thy stallions, drink, Indra, this juice which we have pressed, Mingled with barley and with milk.

column1: tubhyaḥ id indra sve okye somam codāmi pītaye / eṣa rārantu te hṛdi //
column2: Indra, for thee in thine own place I urge the Soma for thy draught: Deep in thy heart let it remain.

column1: tvām sutasya pītaye pratnam indra havāmahe / kuśikāsaḥ avasyavaḥ / aśvāvati prathamaḥ goṣu gacchati suprāvīḥ indra martyaḥ tava ūtibhiḥ / tam id pṛṇakṣi vasunā bhavīyasā sindhum āpaḥ yathā abhitas vicetasaḥ /
column2: Indra, the mortal man well guarded by thine aid goes foremost in the wealth of horses and of kine. With amplest wealth thou fillest him, as round about the waters clearly seen afar fill Sindhu full.

column1: āpaḥ na devīḥ upa yanti hotriyam avaḥ paśyanti vitatam yathā rajaḥ / prācais devāsaḥ pra nayanti devayum brahma priyam joṣayante varāḥ iva /
column2: The heavenly waters come not nigh the priestly bowl: they but look down and see how far mid-air is spread: The Deities conduct the pious man to them: like suitors they delight in him who loveth prayer.

column1: adhi dvayoḥ adadhāḥ ukthyam vacaḥ yata srucā mithunā yā saparyataḥ / a saṃyattaḥ vrate te kṣeti puṣyati bhadrā śaktiḥ yajamānāya sunvate /
column2: Praiseworthy blessing hast thou laid upon the pair who with uplifted ladle serve thee, man and wife. Unchecked he dwells and prospers in thy law: thy power brings blessing to the sacrificer pouring gifts.

column1: āt aṅgirāḥ prathamam dadhire vayaḥ iddha agnayaḥ śamyāḥ ye su kṛtyayā / sarvam paṇeḥ sam avindanta bhojanam aśvāvantam gomantam ā paśum naraḥ /
column2: First the Angirases won themselves vital power, whose fires were kindled through good deeds and sacrifice. The men together found the Pani's hoarded wealth, the cattle, and the wealth in horses and in kine,

column1: yajñaiḥ atharvā prathamaḥ pathaḥ tate tatas sūryaḥ vrata pāḥ venaḥ ājani / ā gāḥ ājat uśanā kāvyaḥ sacā yamasya jātam amṛtam yajāmahe /
column2: Atharvan first by sacrifices laid the path; then, guardian of the Law, sprang up the loving Sun. Usanā Kāvya drove the kine hither with him: let us with offer- ings honour Yama's deathless birth.

column1: barhiḥ vā yat su apatyāya vṛjyate arkaḥ vā ślokam āghoṣate divi / grāvā yatra vadati karuḥ ukthyaḥ tasya id indraḥ abhipitveṣu raṇyati /
column2: When sacred grass is trimmed to aid the auspicious work, or the hymn makes its voice of praise sound to the sky, Where the stone rings as 'twere a singer skilled in laud,—Indra in truth delights when these come near to him.

column1: pra ugrām pītim vṛṣṇe iyarmi satyām prayai sutasya haryaśva tubhyam / indra dhenābhiḥ iha mādayasva dhībhiḥ viśvābhiḥ śacyā gṛṇānaḥ / yoge yoge tavastaram vājevāje havāmahe / sakhāyaḥ indram ūtaye /
column2: To make thee start, a strong true draught I offer to thee the Bull, O thou whom bay steeds carry. Here take delight. O Indra, in our voices while thou art hymned with power and all our spirit. In every need, in every fray we call, as friends, to succour us Indra the mightiest of all.

column1: ā gha gamat yadi śravat sahasriṇībhiḥ ūtibhiḥ / vājebhiḥ upa naḥ havam //
column2: If he will hear us let him come with succour of a thousand kinds, And all that strengthens, to our call.

column1: anu pratnasya okasaḥ huve tuvi pratim naram / yam te pūrvam pitā huve /
column2: I call him, mighty to resist, the Hero of our ancient home, Thee whom my sire invoked of old.

column1: yuñjanti bradhnam aruṣam carantam pari tasthuṣaḥ / rocante rocanā divi // yuñjanti asya kāmyā harī vipakṣasā rathe / śoṇā dhṛṣṇū nṛ vāhasā / ketum kṛṇvan aketave peśaḥ maryāḥ apeśase / sam uṣadbhiḥ ajāyathāḥ /
column2: They who stand round him as he moves harness the bright, the ruddy steed: The lights are shining in the sky. On both sides of the car they yoke the two bay coursers dear to him, Bold, tawny, bearers of the thief.

column1: yat indra aham yathā tvam īśīya vasvaḥ ekaḥ id / stotā me goṣakhā syāt /
column2: If I, O Indra, were, like thee, the single sovran of all wealth. My worshipper should be rich in kine.

column1: śikṣeyam asmai ditseyam śacīpate manīṣiṇe / yat aham gopatiḥ syām /
column2: I should be fain, O Lord of Might, to strengthen and enrich the sage, Were I the lord of herds of kine,

column1: dhenuḥ te indra sūnṛtā yajamānāya sunvate / gām aśvam pipyuṣī duhe /
column2: To worshippers who press the juice thy goodness, Indra, is a cow. Yielding in plenty kine and steeds.

column1: na te vartā asti rādhasaḥ indra devaḥ na martyaḥ / yat ditsasi stutaḥ magham //
column2: None is there, Indra, God or man, to hinder thy munificence, The wealth which, lauded, thou wilt give.

column1: yajñaḥ indram avardhayat yat bhūmim vi avartayat / cakrāṇaḥ opaśam divi //
column2: The sacrifice made Indra strong when he unrolled the earth and made Himself a diaden in heaven.

column1: vāvṛdhānasya te vayam viśvā dhanāni jigyuṣaḥ / ūtim indraḥ ā vṛṇīmahe / vi antarikṣam atirat made somasya rocanā / indraḥ yat abhinat valam // ud gāḥ ājat aṅgirobhyaḥ āvis krṇvan guhā satīḥ / arvāñcam nunude valam /
column2: Thine aid we claim, O Indra, thine who after thou hast waxen great. Hast won all treasures for thine own. Bay horses with their long manes bring Indra to drink the Soma juice, The Bountiful to our sacrifice.

column1: indreṇa rocanā divaḥ dṛlhāni dṛṃhitāni ca / sthirāṇi na parāṇude / apām ūrmiḥ madan iva stomaḥ indra ajirāyate / vi te madāḥ arājiṣuḥ / tvam hi stoma vardhanaḥ indra asi uktha vardhanaḥ / stotṝṇām uta bhadra kṛt //
column2: With waters' foam thou torest off, Indra, the head of Namuchi, Subduing all contending hosts. The Dasyus, when they fain would climb by magic arts and mount to heaven, Thou, Indra, castest down to earth.

column1: asunvām indra saṃsadam viṣūcīm vi anāśayaḥ / soma pāḥ uttaraḥ bhavan //
column2: As Soma-drinker conquering all, thou scatteredst to every side Their band who poured no gifts to thee.

column1: pra te mahe vidathe śaṃsiṣam harī pra te vanve vanuṣaḥ haryatam madam / ghṛtam na yaḥ haribhiḥ cāru secate ā tvā viśantu hari varpasam giraḥ /
column2: In the great synod will I laud thy two bay steeds: I prize the sweet strong drink of thee the Warrior-God, His who pours lovely oil as'twere with yellow drops. Let my songs enter thee whose form hath golden tints.

column1: harim hi yonim abhi ye samasvaran hinvantaḥ harī divyam yathā sadaḥ / ā yam pṛṇanti haribhiḥ na dhenavaḥ indrāya śūśam harivantam arcata /
column2: Ye who—in concert sing unto the gold-hued place, like bay steeds driving onward to the heavenly seat, For Indra laud ye strength allied with tawny steeds, laud him whom cows content as'twere with yellow drops.

column1: saḥ asya vajraḥ haritaḥ yaḥ āyasaḥ hariḥ nikāmaḥ hariḥ ā gabhastyoḥ / dyumnī su śipraḥ hari manyu sāyakaḥ indre ni rūpā haritā mimikṣire /
column2: His is that thunderbolt, of iron, golden-hued, gold-coloured, very dear, and yellow in his arms; Bright with strong teeth, destroying with its tawny rage. In Indra are set fast all forms of golden hue.

column1: divi na ketuḥ adhi dhāyi haryataḥ vivyacat vajraḥ haritaḥ na raṃhyā / tudat ahim hari śipraḥ yaḥ āyasaḥ sahasra śokāḥ abhavat harimbharaḥ /
column2: As if a lovely ray were laid upon the sky, the golden thunder- bolt spread out as in a race. That iron bolt with yellow jaw smote Ahi down. A thousand flames had he who bore the tawny-hued.

column1: tvaṃtvam aharyathāḥ upastutaḥ pūrvebhiḥ indra hari keśa yajvabhiḥ / tvam haryasi tava viśvam ukthyam asāmi rādhaḥ hari jāta haryatam //
column2: Thou, thou, when praised by men who sacrificed of old, hadst pleasure in their lauds, O Indra golden-haired. All that befits thy song of praise thou welcomest, the perfect: pleasant gift, O golden-hued from birth.

column1: tā vajriṇam mandinam stomyam made indram rathe vahataḥ haryatā harī / purūṇi asmai savanāni haryate indrāya somāḥ harayaḥ dadhanvire / aram kāmāya harayaḥ dadhamire sthirāya hinvan harayaḥ harī turā / arvadbhiḥ yaḥ haribhiḥ joṣam īyate saḥ asya kāmam harivantam ānaśe /
column2: These two dear Bays bring hither Indra on his car, thunder- armed, joyous, meet for laud, to drink his fill. Many libations flow for him who loveth them: to Indra have: the gold-hued Soma juices run.

column1: hari śmaśāruḥ hari keśaḥ āyasaḥ turaspeye yaḥ hari pāḥ avardhata / arvadbhiḥ yaḥ haribhiḥ vājinīvasuḥ ati viśvā duritā pāriṣat dharī / śruvā iva yasya hariṇī vipetatuḥ śipre vājāya hariṇī davidhvataḥ / pra yat kṛte camase marmṛjat dharī pītvā madasya haryatasya andhasaḥ /
column2: The gold-hued drops have flowed to gratify his wish: the yellow. drops have urged the swift Bays to the Strong. He who speeds on with bay steeds even as he lists hath satisfied his longing for the golden drops. At the swift draught the Soma-drinker waxed in might, the iron. One with yellow beard and golden hair, He, Lord of tawny coursers. Lord of fleet-foot mares, will bear his bay steeds safely over all distress.

column1: uta sma sadna haryatasya pastyoḥ atyaḥ na vājam harivān acikradat / mahī cit hi dhiṣaṇā aharyat ojasā bṛhat vayaḥ dadhiṣe haryataḥ cit ā / ā rodasī haryamāṇaḥ mahitvā navyam navyam haryasi manma nu priyam / pra pastyam asura haryatam goḥ āvis kṛdhi haraye sūryāya /
column2: Yea, to the dear one's seat in homes of heaven and earth the- bay steeds' Lord hath whinnied like a horse for food. Then the great wish hath seized upon him mightily, and the beloved One hath gained high power of life. Thou, comprehending with thy might the earth and heaven, acceptest the dear hymn for ever new and new. O Asura, disclose thou and make visible the Cow's beloved home to the bright golden Sun.

column1: ā tvā haryantam prayujaḥ janānām rathe vahantu hari śipram indra / pibā yathā pratibhṛtasya madhvaḥ haryan yajñam sadhamāde daśoṇim /
column2: O Indra, let the eager wishes of the folk bring thee the golden- jawed, delightful, on thy car. That, pleased with sacrifice wherein ten fingers toil, thou mayest at the feast drink of our offered mead.

column1: apāḥ pūrveṣām harivas sutānām atha u idam savanam kevalam te / mamaddhi somam madhumantam indra satrā vṛṣam jathare ā vṛṣasva /
column2: Juices aforetime, Lord of Bays, thou drankest, and thine, and only thine, is this libation. Gladden thee, Indra, with the mead-rich Soma: pour it down ever, Mighty One, within thee.

column1: apsu dhūtasya harivas piba iha nṛbhiḥ sutasya jaṭharam pṛṇasva / mimikṣuḥ yam adrayaḥ indra tubhyam tebhiḥ vardhasva madam uktha vāhaḥ //
column2: Drink of the juice which men have washed in waters and fill the- full, O Lord of tawny horses. O Indra, hearer of the laud, with Soma which stones have mix- ed for thee enhance thy rapture.

column1: pra ugrām pītim vṛṣṇe iyarmi satyām prayai sutasya haryaśva tubhyam / indra dhenābhiḥ iha mādayasva dhībhiḥ viśvābhiḥ śacyā gṛṇānaḥ / ūtī śacīvas tava vīryeṇa vayaḥ dadhānāḥ uśijaḥ ṛta jñāḥ / prajāvat indra maṃsaḥ duroṇe tasthuḥ gṛṇantaḥ sadhamādyāsaḥ /
column2: To make thee start, a strong true draught I offer to thee the Bull, O thou whom bay steeds carry. Here take delight, O Indra, in our voices while thou art hymned with power and all our spirit. O mighty Indra, through thine aid, thy prowess, obtaining life, zealous, and skilled in worship. Men in the house who share the sacred banquet stand singing praise that brings them store of children.

column1: yaḥ jātaḥ eva prathamaḥ manasvān devaḥ devān kratunā paryamūṣat / yasya śuṣmāt rodasī abhyasetām nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: He who just born, chief God of lofty spirit, by power and might became the God's protector, Before whose breath, through greatness of his valour, the two worlds trembled, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ pṛthivīm vyathamānām adṛṃhat yaḥ parvatān prakupitām aramṇāt / yaḥ antarikṣam vimame varīyaḥ yaḥ dyām astabhnāt sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: He who fixed fast and firm the earth that staggered, and set at rest the agitated mountains, Who measured out air's wider middle region and gave the heaven support, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ hatvā ahim ariṇāt sapta sindhūn yaḥ gāḥ udājat apadhā valasya / yaḥ aśmanoḥ antar agnim jajāna saṃvṛk samatsu sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: Who slew the Dragon, freed the Seven Rivers, and draye the kine forth from the cave of Vala, Begat the fire between both stones, the spoiler in warrior's battle, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yena imā viśvā cyavanā kṛtāni yaḥ dāsam varṇam adharam guhākaḥ / śvaghnī iva yaḥ jigīvām lakṣam ādat aryaḥ puṣṭāni sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: By whom this universe was made to tremble, who chased away the humbled brood of demon, Who, like a gambler gathering his winnings, seized the foe's riches, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yam sma pṛchanti kuha sa iti ghoram uta īm āhuḥ na eṣaḥ asti iti enam / saḥ aryaḥ puṣṭīḥ vijaḥ iva ā mināti śrath asmai dhatta sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: Of whom, the terrible, they ask, Where is He? or verily they say of him, He is not. He wastes the foeman's wealth like stakes of gamblers. Have faith in him for He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ radhrasya coditā yaḥ kṛśasya yaḥ brahmaṇaḥ nādhamānasya kīreḥ / yukta grāvṇaḥ yaḥ avitā su śipraḥ suta somasya sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: Stirrer to action of the poor and lowly, of priest, of suppliant who sings his praises Who, fair-faced, favours him who presseth Soma with stones adjusted, He, O men, is Indra.

column2: He under whose supreme control are horses, all chariots, and the hamlets, and the cattle: He who begat the Sun, begat the Morning, leader of waters. He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yam krandasī saṃyatī vihvayete pare avare ubhayāḥ amitrāḥ / samānam cit ratham ātasthivāṃsā nānā havete sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: To whom both armies cry in close encounter, foe against foe, the stronger and the weaker; Whom two invoke upon one chariot mounted, each for himself, He, O ye men, is Indra.

column1: yasmāt naḥ ṛte vijayante janāsaḥ yam yudhyamānāḥ avase havante / yaḥ viśvasya pratimānam babhūva yaḥ acyuta cyut sa janāsaḥ indraḥ /
column2: He, without whom men conquer not in battle, whom, warring, they invoke for help and succour; He, all this universe's type and image, who shakes what never shook, He, men, is Indra.

column2: He who hath smitten, ere they know their danger, with his hurl- ed weapon many grievous sinners: Who pardons not his boldness who provokes him, who slays the Dasyu, He, O men, is Indra.

column2: Now unto him of these things hath been given what he, who rules alone o'er much, electeth. Indra helped Etasa, the Soma presser, contending in the chariot- race with Sūrya.

column2: With these my hymns I glorify that Indra who is alone to be invoked by mortals. The Lord, the Mighty One, of manly vigour, victorious, Hero, true, and full of wisdom.

column2: Our ancient sires, Navagvas, sages seven, while urging him to show his might, extolled him, Dweller on heights, swift smiting down opponents, guileless in word, and in his thoughts most mighty.

column2: We seek that Indra to obtain his riches that yield much food, and men, and store of heroes. O Lord of Bay Steeds, bring to make us joyful, celestial wealth abundant, undecaying.

column2: Declare to us—if at thy hand aforetime the earlier singers have obtained good fortune What is thy share and portion, strong Subduer, Asura-slayer, rich, invoked of many?

column2: He who for car-borne, thunder-wielding Indra, hath a hymn, craving deeply-piercing, fluent, Who sends a song effectual, firmly-grasping, and strength- bestowing, he comes near the mighty.

column2: Strong of thyself! thou with this art hast shattered with thought- swift Parvata, him who waxed against thee; And, Mightiest! rager! boldly rent in pieces things that were firmly fixed and never shaken..

column2: Him will we fit for you with new devotion, the strongest, Ancient One, in ancient manner. So way that Indra, boundless, faithful leader, conduct us o'er all places hard to traverse.

column2: Of all the heavenly folk, of earthly creatures, thou art the King, O God of splendid aspect. In thy right hand, O Indra, grasp the thunder: Eternal! thou destroyest all enchantments.

column1: ete te indra jantavaḥ viśvam puṣyanti vāryam / antar hi khyaḥ janānām aryaḥ vedaḥ a dāśuṣām teṣām naḥ vedaḥ ā bhara //
column2: These people, Indra, keep for thee all that is worthy of thy choice. Discover thou, as Lord, the wealth of men who offer up no gifts: bring thou to us this wealth of theirs.

column1: surūpa kṛtnum ūtaye su dughām iva go duhe / juhūmasi dyavidyavi //
column2: As a good cow to him who milks, we call the doer of fair deeds. To our assistance day by day.

column1: upa naḥ savanā gahi somasya soma pāḥ piba / go dāḥ id revataḥ madaḥ /
column2: Come thou to our libations, drink of Soma, Soma-drinker thou! The rich One's rapture giveth kine.

column1: atha te antamānām vidyāma sumatīnām / mā naḥ ati khye ā gahi //
column2: So may we be acquainted with thine innermost benevolence: Neglect us not, come hitherward.

column1: śuṣmintamam naḥ ūtaye dyumninam pāhi jāgṛvim / indra somam śatakrato /
column2: Drink for our help the Soma bright, vigilant, and exceeding strong, O Indra, Lord of Hundred Powers.

column1: indriyāṇi śatakrato yā te janeṣu pañcasu / indra tāni te ā vṛṇe /
column2: O Satakratu, powers which thou mid the Five Races hast dis- played, These, Indra, do I claim of thee.

column1: agan indra śravaḥ bṛhat dyumnam dadhiṣva duṣṭaram / ud te śuṣmam tirāmasi // arvāvataḥ naḥ ā gahi atha u śakra parāvataḥ / u lokaḥ yaḥ te adrivas indra iha tatas ā gahi //
column2: Indra, great glory hast thou gained. Win splendid fame which none may mar. We make thy might perpetual. Come to us either from anear, or, Sakra, come from far away. Indra, wherever be thy home, come thence, O Caster of the Stone.

column1: indraḥ aṅga mahat bhayam abhi sat apa cucyavat / sa hi sthiraḥ vicarṣaniḥ /
column2: Verily Indra, conquering all, driveth even mighty fear away. For firm is he and swift to act.

column1: indraḥ ca mṛlayāti naḥ na naḥ paścāt agham naśat / bhadram bhavāti naḥ puras /
column2: Indra be gracious unto us: sin shall not reach us afterward, And good shall be before us still.

column1: indraḥ āśābhyaḥ pari sarvābhyaḥ abhayam karat / jetā śatrūn vicarṣaṇiḥ //
column2: From all the regions of the world let Indra send security. The foe-subduer, swift to act.

column1: yaḥ ugraḥ san a niṣṭṛta sthiraḥ raṇāya saṃskṛtaḥ / yadi stotuḥ maghavā śṛṇavat dhavam na indraḥ yoṣatī ā gamat / vayam gha tvā sutāvantaḥ āpaḥ na vṛkta barhiṣaḥ / pavitrasya prasravaṇeṣu vṛtrahan pari stotāraḥ āsate / svaranti tvā sute naraḥ vaso nireke ukthinaḥ / kadā sutam tṛṣāṇaḥ oke ā gamaḥ indra svabdī iva vaṃsagaḥ /
column2: We compass thee like waters, we whose grass in trimmed and Soma pressed. Here where the filter pours its stream thy worshippers round thee, O Vritra-slayer, sit. Men, Vasu, by the Soma with lauds call thee to the foremost place. When comest thou athirst unto the juice as home, O Indra, like a bellowing bull?

column1: kaṇvebhiḥ dhṛṣṇo ā dhṛṣat vājam darṣi sahasriṇam / piśaṅga rūpam maghavan vicarṣaṇe makṣū gomantam īmahe /
column2: Boldly, bold Hero, bring us spoil in thousands for the Kanvas' sake. O active Maghavan, with eager prayer we crave the yellow-hued with store of kine.

column1: śrāyante iva sūryam viśvā id indrasya bhakṣata / vasūni jāte janamāne ojasā prati bhāgam na dīdhima /
column2: Turning, as 'twere, to meet the Sun, enjoy from Indra all good things. When he who will be born is born with power we look to treasures as our heritage.

column1: anarśarātim vasudām upa stuhi bhadrāḥ indrasya rātayaḥ / saḥ asya kāmam vidhataḥ na roṣati manaḥ dānāya codayan //
column2: Praise him who sends us wealth, whose bounties injure none. Good are the gifts which Indra gives. He is not wroth with one who satisfies his wish: he turns his mind to granting boons.

column1: baṭ mahām asi sūrya baṭ āditya mahām asi / mahaḥ te sataḥ mahimā panasyate addhā deva mahām asi / baṭ sūrya śravasā mahām asi satrā deva mahāṃ asi / mahnā devānām asuryaḥ purohitaḥ vibhu jyotiḥ adābhyam // ud u tye madhu mattamāḥ giraḥ stomāsaḥ īrate / satrājitaḥ dhanasāḥ akṣita ūtayaḥ vājayantaḥ rathāḥ iva /
column2: Verily, Sūrya, thou art great; truly, Āditya, thou art great. As thou art great indeed thy greatness is admired: yea, verily, great art thou, O God. Yea, Sūrya, thou art great in fame: thou evermore, O God, art great. By greatness thou art President of Gods, divine, far-spread, inviolable light.

column1: ud id nu asya ricyate aṃśaḥ dhanam na jigyusaḥ / yaḥ indraḥ harivān na dabhanti tam ripaḥ dakṣam dadhāti somini //
column2: His portion is exceeding great, like a victorious soldier's spoil. Him who is Indra, Lord of Bays, no foes subdue. He gives the Soma-pourer strength.

column1: mantram akharvam sudhitam supeśasam dadhāta yajñiyeṣu ā / pūrvīḥ cana prasitayaḥ taranti tam ye indre karmaṇā bhuvat //
column2: Make for the holy Gods a hymn that is not mean, but well arranged and fair in form. Full many snares and bonds subdue not him who dwells with Indra through his sacrifice.

column1: eva hi asi vīrayuḥ eva śūraḥ uta sthiraḥ / eva te rādhyam manaḥ /
column2: For so thou art the hero's Friend, a Warrior too art thou, and strong: So may thy heart be won to us.

column1: eva rātiḥ tuvīmagha viśvebhiḥ dhāyi dhātṛbhiḥ / aghā cit indra me sacā /
column2: So hath the offering; wealthiest Lord, been paid by all the worshippers: So dwell thou, Indra, even with me.

column1: mā u su brahmā iva tandrayuḥ bhuvaḥ vājānām pate / matsva sutasya gomataḥ /
column2: Be not thou, like a slothful priest, O Lord of wealth and spoil: rejoice. In the pressed Soma blent with milk.

column1: eva hi asya sūnṛtā virapśī gomatī mahī / pakvā śākhā na dāśuṣe /
column2: So also is his excellence, great copious, rich in cattle, like A ripe branch to the worshipper.

column1: eva hi te vibhūtayaḥ ūtayaḥ indra māvate / sadyas cit santi dāśuṣe /
column2: For verily thy mighty powers, Indra, are saving helps at once Unto a worshipper like me.

column1: eva hi asya kāmyā stomaḥ uktham ca śaṃsyā / indrāya soma pītaye /
column2: So are his lovely gifts: let laud be said and praise to Indra sung. That he may drink the Soma juice.

column1: tam te madam gṛṇīmasi vṛṣaṇam pṛtsu sāsahim / u loka kṛtnum adrivas hari śriyam / yena jyotīmṣi āyave manave ca viveditha / mandānaḥ asya barhiṣaḥ vi rājasi // tat adya cit te ukthinaḥ anu stuvanti pūrvathā / vṛṣa patnīḥ apaḥ jaya divedive /
column2: Wherewith thou also foundest lights for Āyu and for Manu's sake: Now joying in!!this sacred grass thou beamest forth. This day to singers of the hymn praise, as of old, this, might of thine. Win thou the waters, day by day, thralls of the strong.

column2: Sing forth to him whom many men invoke, to him whom many laud: Invite the potent Indra with your songs of praise;

column2: Whose lofty might—for doubly strong is he—supports the heaven and earth. And hills and plains and floods and light with manly power.

column2: Such, praised by many! thou art King: alone thou smitest foe- men dead, To gain, O Indra, spoils of war and high renown.

column2: To Indra sing a Sāman, sing to the high Sage a lofty song, To him who keeps the Law, inspired and fain for praise.

column2: Thou, Indra, art preeminent: thou gavest splendour to the Sun. Maker of all things, thou art mighty and All-God.

column1: vibhrājam jyotiṣā svar agacchaḥ rocanam divaḥ / devāḥ te indra sakhyāya yemire /
column2: Radiant with light thou wentest to the sky, the luminous realms: of heaven. The Gods, O Indra, strove to win thee for their friend.

column2: Sing forth to him whom many men invoke, to him whom many laud: Invite the potent Indra with your songs of praise;

column1: yasya dvibarhasaḥ bṛhat sahaḥ dādhāra rodasī / girīn ajrān apaḥ svar vṛṣatvanā /
column2: Whose lofty might—for doubly strong is he—supports the heaven and earth, And hills and plains and floods and light with manly power.

column1: sa rājasi puruṣṭutam ekaḥ vṛtrāṇi jighnase / indra jaitra śravasya ca yantave /
column2: Such, praised by many! thou art King. Alone thou smitest foe- men dead, To gain, O Indra, spoils of war and high renown.

column1: imā nu kam bhuvanā sīṣadhāma indraḥ ca viśve ca devāḥ / yajñam ca naḥ tanvam ca prajām ca ādityaiḥ indraḥ saha cīkḷpāti //
column2: We will, with Indra, and all Gods to aid us, bring these existing. worlds into subjection. Our sacrifice, our bodies, and our offspring, let Indra form to- gether with the Ādityas.

column1: ādityaiḥ indraḥ sa gaṇaḥ marudbhiḥ asmākam bhūtu avitā tanūnām / hatvāya devāḥ asurān yat āyan devāḥ deva tvam abhirakṣamāṇāḥ /
column2: With the Ādityas with the band of Maruts, may Indra be pro- tector of our bodies; As when the Gods came, after they had slaughtered the Asuras,. keeping safe their godlike nature,

column2: When will he trample like a weed the man who hath no gift for him? When verily will Indra hear our songs of praise?

column2: He who with Soma juice prepared among the many harbours. thee, Verily Indra gains thereby tremendous might. Joy, mightiest Indra, known and marked, sprung most from Soma draughts, wherewith Thou smitest down the greedy fiend, for that we pray.

column1: yena daśagvam adhrigum vepayantam svarṇaram / yena samudram āvitha tam īmahe //
column2: Wherewith thou helpest Adhrigu, the great Dasagva, and the God Who stirs the sunlight, and Sea, for that we pray.

column1: yena sindhum mahīḥ apaḥ rathān iva pracodayaḥ / panthām ṛtasya yātave tam īmahe /
column2: Wherewith thou dravest forth like cars Sindhu and all the mighty floods. To go the way ordained by Law, for that we pray.

column2: Come unto us, O Indra, dear, still conquering, unconcealable, Vast as a mountain spread on all sides, Lord of heaven.

column2: O truthful Soma-drinker, thou art mightier than both the worlds. Thou strengthenest him who pours libation, Lord of heaven.

column1: tvam hi śaśvatīnām indra dartā purām asi / hantā dasyoḥ manoḥ vṛdhaḥ patiḥ divaḥ /
column2: For thou art, he, O Indra, who stormest all castles of the foe, Slayer of Dasyus, man's supporter, Lord of heaven.

column1: indra sthātar harīṇām nakir te pūrvya stutim / ud ānaṃśa śavasā na bhandanā /
column2: Indra whom tawny coursers bear, praise such a thine,. preeminent None by his power or by his goodness hath attained

column1: tam vaḥ vājānām patim ahūmahi śravasyavaḥ / aprāyubhiḥ yajñebhiḥ vāvṛdhenyam //
column2: We seeking glory, have invoked this Master of all power and' might. Who must be glorified by constant sacrifice.

column1: etaḥ nu indram stavāma sakhāyaḥ stomyam naram / kuṣṭīḥ yaḥ viśvāḥ abhi asti ekaḥ id /
column2: Come, sing we praise to Indra, friends! the Hero who deserves the laud, Him who with none to aid o'ercomes all tribes of men.

column1: agorudhāya gaviṣe dyukṣāya dasmyam vacaḥ / ghṛtāt svādīyaḥ madhunaḥ ca vocata /
column2: To him who wins the kine, who keeps no cattle back, celestial God, Speak wondrous speech more sweet than butter and than mead.

column1: yasya amitāni vīryā na rādhaḥ paryetave / jyotiḥ na viśvam abhi asti dakṣiṇā / stuhi indram vyaśvavat anūrmim vājinam yamam / aryaḥ gayam maṃhamānam vi dāśuṣe /
column2: Whose hero powers are measureless, whose bounty ne'er may be surpassed, Whose liberality, like light, is over all. As Vyasva did, praise Indra, praise the strong unfluctuating guide. Who gives the foe's possessions to the worshipper.

column1: eva nūnam upa stuhi vaiyaśva daśamam navam / suvidvāṃsam carkṛtyam caraṇīnām /
column2: Now, son of Vyasva, praise thou him who to the tenth time still is new. The very wise, whom living men must glorify.

column1: vettha hi nirṛtīnām vajrahasta parivṛjam / aharahar śundhyuḥ paripadām iva /
column2: Thou knowest, Indra, thunder-armed, how to avoid destructive Powers, As one secure from pitfalls each succeeding day.

column1: vanoti hi sunvan kṣayam parīṇasaḥ sunvānaḥ hi sma yajati ava dviṣaḥ devānām ava dviṣaḥ / sunvānaḥ id siṣāsati sahasrā vājī avṛtaḥ / sunvānāya indraḥ dadāti ābhuvam rayim dadāti ābhuvam /
column2: The pourer of oblations gains the home of wealth pouring his gift conciliates hostilities, yea, the hostilities of Gods. Pouring he strives, unchecked and strong, to win him riches thousandfold. Indra gives lasting wealth to him who pours forth gifts; yea, wealth he gives that long shall last.

column2: Ne'er may those manly deeds of yours for us grow old, never may your bright glories fall into decay, never before your time decay. What deed of yours, new every age, wondrous, surpassing man,. rings forth, Whatever, Maruts may be difficult to gain grant us whate'er is hard to win.

column1: agnim hotāram manye dāsvantam vasum sūnum sahasaḥ jātavedasam vipram na jātavedasam / yaḥ ūrdhvayā su adhvaraḥ devaḥ devācyā kṛpā / ghṛtasya vibhrāṣṭim anu vaṣṭi śociṣā ājuhvānasya sarpiṣaḥ /
column2: I think on Agni, Hotar, the munificent, the gracious Son of strength, who knoweth all that live, as holy Sage who knoweth all. Lord of fair rites, a God with form erected turning to the Gods. He, when the flame hath sprung forth from the holy oil, the offered fatness, longeth for it with his glow.

column1: yajñaiḥ saṃmiślāḥ pṛṣatībhiḥ ṛṣṭibhiḥ yāmam chubhrāsaḥ añjiṣu priyāḥ uta / āsadyāḥ barhiḥ bharatasya sūnavaḥ potrāt ā somam pibata divaḥ naraḥ /
column2: Busied with sacrifice, with spotted deer and spears, gleaming. upon your way with ornaments, yea, our friends, Sitting on sacred grass, ye sons of Bharata, drink Soma from the Potar's bowl, O Men of heaven.

column2: Bring the Gods hither, Sage, and offer sacrifice. At the three altars seat thee willingly .O Priest. Accept for thy delight the proffered Soma mead: drink from the Kindler's bowl and sate thee with thy share.

column1: eṣa sya te tanvaḥ nṛmṇa vardhanaḥ sahaḥ ojaḥ pradivi bāhvoḥ hitaḥ / tubhyam sutaḥ maghavan tubhyam ābhṛtaḥ tvam asya brāhmaṇāt ā tṛpat piba /
column2: This is the strengthener of thy body's manly might: strength,. victory for all time are laid within thine arms. Pressed for thee, Maghavan, it is offered unto thee: drink from the chalice of this Brāhman, drink thy fill.

column1: yam u pūrvam a huve tam idam huve sa id u havyaḥ dadiḥ yaḥ nāma patyate / adhvaryubhiḥ prasthitam somyam madhu potrāt somam draviṇaḥ daḥ piba ṛtubhiḥ // surūpa kṛtnum ūtaye su dughām iva go duhe / juhūmasi dyavidyavi // upa naḥ savanā gahi somasya soma pāḥ piba / go dāḥ id revataḥ madaḥ /
column2: Him whom of old I called on, him I call on now. He is to be invoked: his name is He who Gives. Here brought by priests in Soma mead. Granter of Wealth, drink Soma with the Seasons from the Hotar's Cup.

column2: Go to the wise unconquered One, ask thou of Indra, skilled in song, Him who is better than thy friends. Whether the men who mock us say, Depart unto another place, Ye who serve Indra and none else;

column1: uta naḥ subhagām ariḥ voceyuḥ dasma kṛṣṭayaḥ / syāma id indrasya śarmaṇi //
column2: Or whether, God of wondrous deeds, all our true people call us blest, Still may we dwell in Indra's care.

column1: ā īm āśum āśave bhara yajña śriyam nṛ mādanam / patayan mandayat sakham // asya pītvā śatakrato ghanaḥ vṛtrāṇām abhavaḥ / prāvaḥ vājeṣu vājinam /
column2: Unto the swift One bring the swift, man-cheering, grace of sacrifice. That to the Friend gives wings and joy. Thou, Satakratu, drankest this and wast the Vritras' slayer; thou. Helpest the warrior in the fray.

column1: tam tvā vājeṣu vājinam vājayāmaḥ śatakrato / dhanānām indra sātaye //

column2: To him the mighty stream of wealth, prompt Friend of him who pours the juice, Yea, to this Indra sing your song. O come ye hither, sit ye down: to Indra sing ye forth your song, Companions, bringing hymns of praise. To him the richest of the rich, the Lord of treasures excellent, Indra, with Soma juice outpoured.

column2: May he stand by us in our need and in abundance for our wealth: With riches may he come to us;

column2: Whose pair of tawny horses yoked in battles foemen challenge not: To him, to Indra, sing your song.

column2: 6. O Lord of Hundred Powers, our chants of praise and lauds have strengthened thee: So strengthen thee the songs we sing!

column2: Indra, whose succour never fails, accept this treasure thousand- fold, Wherein all manly powers abide.

column2: O Indra, thou who lovest song, let no man hurt our bodies, keep. Slaughter far from us, for thou canst.

column1: aṣālham ugram pṛtanāsu sāsahim yasmin mahīḥ uru jrayaḥ / sam dhenavaḥ jāyamāne anonavuḥ dyāvaḥ kṣāmaḥ anonavuḥ //
column2: The potent Conqueror, invincible in war, him at whose birth the mighty ones, The kine who spread afar, sent their loud voices out, heavens, earths sent their loud voices out.

column1: yat dyāvaḥ indra te śatam śatam bhūmīḥ uta syuḥ / na tvā vajrin sahasram sūryāḥ anu na jātam aṣṭa rodasī /
column2: O Indra, if a hundred heavens and if a hundred earths were thine No, not a thousand suns could match thee at thy birth, not both the worlds, O Thunderer.

column1: ā paprātha mahinā vṛṣṇyā vṛṣan viśvā śaviṣṭha śavasā / asmān ava maghavan gomati vraje vajrim citrābhiḥ ūtibhiḥ / ud tvā mandantu stomāḥ kṛṇuṣva rādhaḥ adrivas / ava brahma dviṣaḥ jahi //
column2: Thou, Hero, hast performed thy hero deeds with might, yea, all with strength, O Strongest One. Maghavan, help us to a stable full of kine, O Thunderer, with wondrous aids. May our hymns give thee great delight. Display thy bounty, Thunderer. Drive off the enemies of prayer.

column1: padā paṇīn arādhasaḥ ni bādhasva mahān asi / nahi tvā kaḥ cana prati /
column2: Crush with thy foot the niggard churls who bring no gifts. Might art thou: There is not one to equal thee.

column1: tvam īśiṣe sutānām indra tvam asutānām / tvam rājā janānām /
column2: Thou art the Lord of Soma pressed, Soma unpressed is also thine, Thou art the Sovran of the folk.

column1: īṅkhayantīḥ apasyuvaḥ indram jātam upāsate / bhejānāsaḥ su vīryam /
column2: Swaying about the active Ones came nigh to Indra at his birth, And shared his great heroic might.

column1: tvam indra balāt adhi sahasaḥ jātaḥ ojasaḥ / tvam vṛṣan vṛṣā id asi /
column2: Based upon strength and victory and power, O Indra is thy birth. Thou, Mighty One, art strong indeed.

column1: tvam indra asi vṛtrahā vi antarikṣam atiraḥ / ud dyām astabhnāḥ ojasā /
column2: Thou art the Vritra-slayer, thou, Indra, hast spread the firmament: Thou hast with might upheld the heavens.

column1: tvam indra sajoṣasam arkam bibharṣi bāhvoḥ / vajram śiśānaḥ ojasā /
column2: Thou, Indra, bearest in thine arms the lightning that accords with thee, Whetting thy thunderbolt with might.

column1: tvam indra abhibhuḥ asi viśvā jātāni ojasā / sa viśvā bhuvaḥ ābhavaḥ /
column2: Thou, Indra, art pre-eminent over all creatures in thy strength: Thou hast pervaded every place.

column1: ā yātu indraḥ sva patiḥ madāya yaḥ dharmaṇā tūtujānaḥ tuviṣmān / pratvakṣāṇaḥ ati viśvā sahāṃsi apāreṇa mahatā vṛṣṇyena /
column2: May Sovran Indra come to the carousal, he who by holy Law is strong and active. The overcomer of all conquering forces with his great bull-like power that hath no limit.

column1: suṣṭhāmā rathaḥ suyamā harī te mimyakṣa vajraḥ nṛpate gabhastau / śībham rājan su pathā yāhi arvāṅ vardhāma te papusaḥ vṛṣṇyāni //
column2: Firm-seated is thy car, thy steeds are docile: thy hand, O King, holds, firmly grasped, the thunder. On thy fair path, O Lord of men, come quickly: we will increase thy power when thou hast drunken.

column1: indra vāhaḥ nṛpatim vajra bāhum ugram ugrāsaḥ taviṣāsaḥ enam / pratvakṣasam vṛṣabham satya śuṣmam ā īm asmatrā sadhamādaḥ vahantu //
column2: Let strong and mighty steeds who bear this mighty Indra, the Lord of men, whose arm wields thunder, Bring unto us, as shares of our banquet, the Bull of conquering might, of real vigour.

column1: eva patim droṇasācam sacetasam ūrjaḥ skambham dharuṇaḥ ā vṛṣāyase / ojaḥ kṛṣva sam gṛbhāya tve api asaḥ yathā kenipānām inaḥ vṛdhe / gaman asme vasūni ā hi śaṃsiṣam su āśiṣam bharam ā yāhi sominaḥ / tvam īśiṣe sā asmin ā satsi barhiṣi anādhṛṣyā tava pātrāṇi dharmaṇā /
column2: So like a bull thou rushest to the Lord who loves the trough, the Sage, the prop of vigour, in the vat. Prepare thine energies, collect them in thyself: be for our profit as the Master of the wise. May precious treasures come to us,— so will I pray. Come to the votary's gift offered with beauteous laud. Thou art the Lord, as such sit on this holy grass: thy vessels are inviolate as Law commands.

column1: pṛthak prāyan prathamāḥ deva hūtayaḥ akṛṇvata śravasyāni duṣṭarā / na ye śekuḥ yajñiyām nāvam āruham irmā eva te ni aviśanta kepayaḥ /
column2: Far went our earliest invocations of the Gods, and won us glories that can never be surpassed. They who could not ascend the ship of sacrifice sink down in desolation, trembling with alarm.

column1: eva eva apāk apare santu dūdhyaḥ aśvāḥ yeṣām duryuge āyuyujre / itthā ye prāk upare santi dāvane purūṇi yatra vayunāni bhojanā /
column2: So be the others, evil-hearted, far away, whose horses difficult to harness have been yoked. Here in advance man stand anear to offer gifts, by whom full many a work that brings reward is done.

column1: girīn ajrān rejamānām adhārayat dyauḥ krandat antarikṣāṇi kopayat / samīcīne dhiṣaṇe vi skabhāyati vṛṣṇaḥ pītvā made ukthāni śaṃsati //
column2: He firmly fixed the plains and mountains as they shook. Dyaus thundered forth and made the air's mid-region quake. He stays apart the two confronting bowls; he sings lauds in the potent Soma's joy when he hath drunk.

column1: imam bibharmi su kṛtam te aṅkuśam yena ārujāsi maghavam chaphārujaḥ / asmin su te savane astu oktyam sutaḥ iṣṭau maghavan bodhi ābhagaḥ //
column2: I bear this deftly-fashioned goad of thine wherewith thou, Maghavan, shalt break the strikers with the hoof. At the libation mayst thou be well satisfied. Partake the juice, partake the banquet, Bounteous Lord.

column1: gobhiḥ tarema amatim durevām yavena kṣudham puruhūta viśvām / vayam rājabhiḥ prathamā dhanāni asmākena vṛjanena jayema /
column2: O Much-invoked, may we subdue all famine and evil want with store of grain and cattle. May we allied, as first in rank, with princes, obtain possessions by our own exertions.

column1: bṛhaspatiḥ naḥ pari pātu paścāt uta uttarasmāt adharāt aghayoḥ / indraḥ purastāt uta madhyataḥ naḥ sakhā sakhibhyaḥ varivaḥ kṛṇotu //
column2: Brihaspati protect us from the rearward, and from above, and from below, from sinners! May Indra from the front and from the centre, as friend to friends, vouchsafe us room and freedom.

column1: trikadrukeṣu mahiṣaḥ yava āśiram tuvi śuṣmaḥ tṛpat somam apibat viṣṇunā sutam yathā avaśat / saḥ īm mamāda mahi karma kartave mahām urum sā enam saścat devaḥ devam satyam indram satyaḥ induḥ /
column2: From the three jars the Great and Strong hath drunk drink blent with meal. With Vishnu hath he quaffed the flowing Soma juice, all that he would. That hath so heightened him the Great, the Vast, to do his mighty work. So may the God attend the God, true Indu Indra who is true.

column1: pra u su asmai puroratham indrāya śūṣam arcata / abhīke cit u loka kṛt saṃge samatsu vṛtrahā asmākam bodhi coditāḥ nabhantām anyakeṣām jyākāḥ adhi dhanvasu // tvam sindhūṃr avāsṛjaḥ adharācaḥ ahan ahim / a śatruḥ indra jajñiṣe viśvam puṣyasi vāryam tam tvā pari svajāmahe nabhantām anyakeṣām jyākāḥ adhi dhanvasu // vi su viśvāḥ arātayaḥ aryaḥ naśanta naḥ dhiyaḥ / astāsi śatrave vadham yaḥ naḥ indra jighāṃsati yā te rātiḥ dadiḥ vasu / nabhantām anyakeṣām jyakāḥ adhi dhanvasu //
column2: Thou didst destroy the Dragon: thou sentest the rivers down to earth. Foeless, O Indra, wast thou born. Thou tendest well each choicest thing. Therefore we draw us close to thee. Let the weak bowstrings break upon the bows of feeble enemies. Destroyed be all malignities and all our enemy's designs. Thy bolt thou castest at the foe, O Indra, who would smite us dead: thy liberal bounty gives us wealth. Let the weak bow- strings break upon the bows of feeble enemies.

column1: tīvrasya abhivayasaḥ asya pāhi sarva rathā vi harī iha muñca / indra mā tvā yajamānāsaḥ anye ni rīraman tubhyam ime sutāsaḥ /
column2: Taste this strong draught that gives thee vital vigour: with all thy chariot here unyoke thy coursers. Let not those other sacrificers stay thee, Indra: these juices shed for thee are ready.

column1: tubhyam sutāḥ tubhyam u sotvāsaḥ tvām giraḥ śvātryāḥ ā hvayanti / indra idam adya savanam juṣāṇaḥ viśvasya vidvāṃ iha pāhi somam /
column2: Thine is the juice effused, thine are the juices yet to be pressed: our resonant songs invite thee. O Indra, pleased to-day with this libation, come, thou who knowest all, and drink the Soma.

column1: yaḥ uśatā manasā somam asmai sarva hṛdā deva kāmaḥ sunoti / na gāḥ indraḥ tasya parā dadāti praśastam id cārum asmai kṛṇoti //
column2: Whoso, devoted to the God, effuses Soma for him with yearning heart and spirit, Never doth Indra give away his cattle: for him he makes the lovely Soma famous.

column1: anuspaṣṭaḥ bhavati eṣaḥ asya yaḥ asmai revān na sunoti somam / niḥ aratnau maghavā tam dadhāti brahma dviṣaḥ hanti anānudiṣṭaḥ /
column2: He looks with loving favour on the mortal who, like a rich man, pours for him the Soma. Maghavan in his bended arm supports him: he slays, unasked, the men who hate devotion.

column1: aśvāyantaḥ gavyantaḥ vājayantaḥ havāmahe tvā upagantavai u / ābhūṣantaḥ te sumatau navāyām vayam indra tvā śunam huvema /
column2: We call on thee to come to us, desirous of booty, and of cattle, and of horses. For thy new love and favour are we present: let us invoke thee, Indra, as our welfare.

column1: muñcāmi tvā haviṣā jīvanāya kam ajñāta yakṣmāt uta rāja yakṣmāt / grāhiḥ jagrāha yadi etat tasyāḥ indra agnī pra mumuktam enam /
column2: For life I set thee free by this oblation from the unknown decline and from consumption; Or, if the grasping demon have possessed him, free him from her, O Indra, thou and Agni.

column1: yadi kṣita āyuḥ yadi vā paretaḥ yadi mṛtyoḥ antikam nītaḥ eva / tam ā harāmi nirṛteḥ upasthāt a spārśam enam śata śāradāya /
column2: Be his days ended, be he how departed, be he brought very near to death already, Out of Destruction's lap again I bring him, save him for life to last a hundred autumns.

column1: sahasra akṣeṇa śata vīryeṇa śata āyuṣā haviṣā ahārṣam enam / indraḥ yathā enam śaradaḥ nayāti ati viśvasya duritasya pāram /
column2: With thousand-eyed oblation, hundred-autumned, bringing a hundred lives, have 1 restored him. That Indra for a hundred years may lead him safe to the farther shore of all misfortune.

column1: śatam jīva śaradaḥ vardhamānaḥ śatam hemantān śatam u vasantān / śatam te indraḥ agniḥ savitā bṛhaspatiḥ śata āyuṣā haviṣā ahārṣam enam /
column2: Live waxing in thy strength a hundred autumns, live through a hundred springs, a hundred winters. Through hundred-lived oblation Indra, Agni, Brihaspati, Savitar yield him for a hundred!

column1: āhārṣam avidam tvā punar āgāḥ punarṇavaḥ / sarva aṅga sarvam te cakṣuḥ sarvam āyuḥ ca te avidam /
column2: So have I found and rescued thee: thou hast returned with youth renewed. Whole in thy members! I have found whole sight and all thy life for thee.

column1: brahmaṇā agniḥ samvidānaḥ rakṣaḥ hā bādhatām itas / amīvā yaḥ te garbham durṇāmāḥ yonim āśaye /
column2: May Agni yielding to our prayer, the Rakshas-killer, drive away. The malady of evil name that hath beset thy labouring womb.

column1: yaḥ te garbham amīvā durṇāmā yonim āśaye / agniḥ tam brahmaṇā saha niḥ kravya adam anīnaśat /
column2: Agni, concurring in the prayer, drive off the eater of thy flesh, The malady of evil name that hath attacked thy babe and womb.

column1: yaḥ te hanti patayantam niṣatsnum yaḥ sarīsṛpam / jātam yaḥ te jighāṃsati tam itas nāśayāmasi // yaḥ te ūrū viharati antarā dampatī śaye / yonim yaḥ antar ārelhi tam itas nāśayāmasi // yaḥ tvā bhrātā patiḥ bhūtvā jāraḥ bhūtvā nipadyate / prajām yaḥ te jighāṃsati tam itas nāśayāmasi //
column2: That which destroys the sinking germ, the settled, moving embryo, That which would kill the babe at birth, even this will we drive far away. That which divides thy legs that it may lie between the married pair, That penetrates and licks thy side, even this will we exterminate.

column1: yaḥ tvā svapnena tamasā mohayitvā nipadyate / prajām yaḥ te jighāṃsati tam itas nāśayāmasi //
column2: That which through sleep or darkness hath deceived thee and lies down by thee, And will destroy thy progeny,—even this will we exterminate.

column1: akṣībhyām te nāsikābhyām karṇābhyām chubukāt adhi / yakṣmam śīrṣaṇyam mastiṣkāt jihvāyāḥ vi vṛhāmi te / grīvābhyaḥ te uṣṇihābhyaḥ kīkasābhyaḥ anūkyāt / yakṣmam doṣaṇyam aṃsābhyām bāhubhyām vi vṛhāmi te / hṛdayāt te pari klomnaḥ halīkṣṇāt pārśvābhyām / yakṣmam matasnābhyām plīhnaḥ yaknaḥ te vi vṛhāmasi //
column2: From both thy nostrils, from thine eyes, from both thine ears and from thy chin, Forth from thy head and brain and tongue I drive thy malady away. From the neck-tendons and the neck, from the breast-bones and from the spine, From shoulders, upper, lower arms, I drive thy malady away.

column1: mehanāt vanaṃkaraṇāt lomabhyaḥ te nakhebhyaḥ / yakṣmam sarvasmāt ātmanaḥ tam idam vi vṛhāmi te /
column2: From viscera and all within, forth from the rectum, from the heart, From kidneys, liver and from spleen, I drive thy malady away.

column1: asthibhyaḥ te majjabhyaḥ snāvabhyaḥ dhamanibhyaḥ / yakṣmam pāṇibhyām aṅgulibhyaḥ nakhebhyaḥ vi vṛhāmi te /
column2: From thighs, from knee-caps, and from heels, and from the forepart of the feet, From hips, from stomach, and from groin, I drive thy malady away.

column1: aṅge aṅge lomni lomni yaḥ te parvaṇi parvaṇi / yakṣam tvacasyam te vayam kaśyapasya vībarheṇa viṣvañcam vi vṛhāmasi //
column2: From every member, every hair, disease that comes in every joint, From all thyself, from top to toe, I drive thy malady away.

column1: apehi manasas pate apa kāma paras cara / paras nirṛtyāḥ ā cakṣva bahudhā jīvataḥ manaḥ /
column2: Avaunt, thou Master of the Mind, I Depart and vanish far away. Look on Destruction far from us. The live man's mind is manifold.

column1: vayam enam idā hyopīpema iha vajriṇam / tasmai u adya samanā sutam bhara nūnam bhūṣata śrute /
column2: Here verily yesterday we let the Thunder-wielder drink his fill. So in like manner, offer him the juice to day. Now range you. by the Glorious One.

column1: vṛkaḥ cit asya vāraṇaḥ urāmathiḥ ā vayuneṣu bhūṣati / sa imam naḥ stomam jujuṣāṇaḥ ā gahi indra pra citrayā dhiyā /
column2: Even the wolf, the savage beast that rends the sheep, follows the path of his decrees. So, India, graciously accepting this our praise, with wondrous. thought come forth to us.

column1: kad u nu asya akṛtam indrasya asti pauṃsyam / kena u nu kam śromatena na śuśruve januṣaḥ pari vṛtrahā /
column2: What manly deed of vigour now remains that Indra hath not done? Who hath not heard his glorious title and his fame, the Vritra- slayer from his birth?

column1: tvām id hi havāmahe sātā vājasya kāravaḥ / tvām vṛtreṣu indra satpatim naraḥ tvām kāṣṭhāsu arvataḥ /
column2: That we may win us wealth and spoil we poets verily call on thee. In war men call on thee, Indra, the hero's Lord, in the steed's, race-course call on thee.

column1: sa tvam naḥ citra vajrahasta dhṛṣṇuyāḥ mahaḥ stavānaḥ adrivas / gām aśvam rathyam indra sam kira satrā vājam na jigyuṣe /
column2: As such, O Wonderful whose hand holds thunder, praised as mighty, Caster of the Stone. Pour on us boldly, Indra, kie and chariot-steeds, ever to be the conqueror's strength.

column1: abhi tvā pūrva pītaye indra stomebhiḥ āyavaḥ / samīcīnāsaḥ ṛbhavaḥ sam asvaran rudrāḥ gṛṇanta pūrvyam /
column2: Men with their lauds are urging thee, Indra, to drink the Soma first. The Ribhus in accord have lifted up their voice and Rudras. sung thee as the First.

column1: asya id indraḥ vāvṛdhe vṛṣṇyam śavaḥ made sutasya viṣṇavi / adya tam asya mahimānam āyavaḥ anu stuvanti pūrvathā /
column2: Indra increased his manly strength at sacrifice, in the wild rapture of this juice; And living men to-day, even as of old, sing forth their praises to his majesty.

column1: adhā hi indra girvaṇaḥ upa tvā kāmān mahaḥ sasṛjmahe / udeva yantaḥ udabhiḥ /
column2: Now have we, Indra, Friend of Song, sent our great wishes forth to thee. Coming like floods that follow floods.

column1: vār na tvā yavyābhiḥ vardhanti śūra brahmāṇi / vār na tvā yavyābhiḥ vardhanti śūra brahmāṇi / vāvṛdhvāṃsam cit adrivas divedive /
column2: As rivers swell the ocean, so, Hero, our prayers increase thy might, Though of thyself, O Thunderer, waxing day by day.

column1: yuñjanti harī iṣirasya gāthayā urau rathe uru yuge / indra vāhā vacaḥ yujā /
column2: With holy song they bind to the broad wide-yoked car the bay steeds of the rapid God, Bearers of India, yoked by prayer.

column1: agnim dūtam vṛṇīmahe hotāram viśva vedasam / asya yajñasya sukratum / asya yajñasya sukratum /
column2: Agni we choose, the messenger, the herald, master of all wealth,. Well skilled in this our sacrifice.

column1: agnim agnim havīmabhiḥ sadā havanta viśpatim / havyavāham puru priyam /
column2: With calls they ever invocate Agni, Agni, Lord of the House, Oblation-bearer, much-beloved.

column1: agne devān iha ā vaha jajñānaḥ vṛkta barhiṣe / asi hotā naḥ īḍyaḥ /
column2: Bring the Gods hither, Agni, born for him who strews the sacred grass. Thou art our herald, meet for praise.

column1: īlenyaḥ namasyaḥ tiras tamāṃsi darśataḥ / sam agniḥ idhyate vṛṣā /
column2: Meet to be lauded and adored, showing in beauty through the= dark, Agni the Bull is kindled well,

column1: vṛṣaḥ agniḥ sam idhyate aśvaḥ na deva vāhanaḥ / tam haviṣmantaḥ īlate /
column2: Agni is kindled as a Bull, like a horse bearer of the Gods; Men with oblations worship him.

column1: vṛṣaṇam tvā vayam vṛṣan vṛṣaṇaḥ sam idhīmahi / agne dīdyatam bṛhat /
column2: Thee will we kindle as a Bull, we who are bulls ourselves, O Bull, Thee, Agni, shining mightily.

column1: agnim īliṣva avase gāthābhiḥ śīra śociṣam / agnim rāye purumīlha śrutam naraḥ agnim su dītaye chardiḥ /
column2: Solicit with your hymns, for aid, Agni the God with piercing flame, For riches famous Agni, Purmilha ‘and ye men, Agni to light our dwelling well.

column1: agne ā yāhi agnibhiḥ hotāram tvā vṛṇīmahe / ā tvām anaktu prayatā haviṣmatī yajiṣṭham barhiḥ āsade / acha hi tvā sahasaḥ sūno aṅgiraḥ srucaḥ caranti adhvare / ūrjaḥ napātam ghṛta keśam īmahe agnim yajñeṣu pūrvyam //
column2: Agni, come hither with thy fires: we choose thee as our Hotai- priest. Let the extended ladle full of oil balm thee, best priest, to sit on sacred grass. For unto thee, O Angiras, O Son of Strength, move ladles in the sacrifice, To Agni, Child of Force, whose locks drop oil, we seek, fore- most in sacrificial rites.

column1: imāḥ u tvā purūvaso giraḥ vardhantu yāḥ mama / pāvaka varṇāḥ śucayaḥ vipaścitaḥ abhi stomaiḥ anūṣata /
column2: May these my songs of praise exalt thee, Lord who hast abun- dant wealth. Men skilled in holy hymns, bright with the hues of fire, have sung them with their lauds to thee.

column1: ayam sahasram ṛṣibhiḥ sahaskṛtaḥ samudraḥ iva paprathe / satyaḥ saḥ asya mahimā gṛne śavaḥ yajñeṣu vipra rājye /
column2: He with his might enhanced by Rishis thousand-fold, hath like an ocean spread himself. His majesty is praised as true at solemn rites, his power where holy singers rule

column1: ā naḥ viśvāsu havyaḥ indraḥ samatsu bhūṣatu / upa brahmāṇi savanāni vṛtra hā parama jyāḥ ṛcīṣamaḥ /
column2: May Indra, who in every fight must be invoked, be near to us. May the most mighty Vritra-slayer, meet for praise, come to libations and to hymns.

column1: tvam dātā prathamaḥ rāghasām asi asi satyaḥ īśāna kṛt / tuvi dyumnasya yujyā vṛṇīmahe putrasya śavasaḥ mahaḥ /
column2: Thou art the best of all in sending bounteous gifts, true art thou,. lordly in thine act. We claim alliance with the very Glorious One, yea, with the- mighty Son of Strength.

column1: tvam indra pratūrtiṣu abhi viśvāḥ asi spṛdhaḥ / aśasti hā janitā viśvatūr asi tvam tūrya taruṣyataḥ / anu te śuṣmam turayantam īyatuḥ kṣoṇī śiśum na mātarā / viśvāḥ te spṛdhaḥ śnathayanta manyave vṛtram yat indra tūrvasi //
column2: The earth, and heaven cling close to thy victorious might, as sire and mother to their child. When thou attackest Vritra all the hostile bands shrink and faint, Indra at thy wrath.

column2: Bring to your aid the Eternal One, who shoots and none may shoot at him, Inciter, swift, victorious, best of charioteers, Tugrya's unvan- quished strengthener;

column2: That lofty energy of thine, thy strength and thine intelligence, Thy thunderbolt for which we long, our wish makes keen.

column2: O Indra, heaven and earth augment thy manly power and thy renown, The waters and the mountains stir and urge thee on.

column2: Vishnu, the lofty Ruling Power, Varuna, Mitra sing thy praise: In thee the Maruts' company hath great delight.

column2: Before his hot displeasure all the peoples, all the men bow down, As rivers bend them to the sea.

column1: ojaḥ tat asya titviṣaḥ ubhe yat samavartayat / indraḥ carmā iva rodasī /
column2: This power of his shone brightly forth when Indra brought to- gether like A skin the worlds of earth and heaven.

column2: The fiercely-moving Vritra's head he severed with his thunder- bolt, His hundred-knotted thunderbolt.

column1: tat id āsa bhuvaneṣu jyeṣṭham yatas jajñe ugraḥ tveṣa nṛmṇaḥ / sadyas jajñānaḥ ni riṇāti śatrūn anu yat enam madanti viśve ūmāḥ /
column2: In all the worlds That was the best and highest whence sprang the mighty God, of splendid valour. As soon as born he overcomes his foemen, he in whom all who lend him aid are joyful.

column2: Grown mighty in his strength, with ample vigour, he as a foe strikes fear into the Dāsa, Eager to win the breathing and the breathless. All sang thy praise at banquet and oblation.

column2: All concentrate on thee their mental vigour, what time these, twice or thrice, are thine assistants. Blend what is sweeter than the sweet with sweetness: win quickly with our meath that meath in battle.

column1: yadi cit nu tvā dhanā jayantam raṇeraṇe anumadanti viprāḥ / ojīyaḥ śuṣmin sthiram ā tanuṣva mā tvā dabhan durevāsaḥ kaśokāḥ /
column2: Therefore in thee too, thou who winnest riches, at every banquet are the sages joyful With mighter power, bold God, extend thy firmness: let not malignant Yātudhānas harm thee.

column1: tvayā vayam śāśadmahe raṇeṣu prapaśyantaḥ yudhenyāni bhūri / codayāmi te āyudhā vacobhiḥ sam te śiśāmi brahmaṇā vayāṃsi /
column2: Proudly we put our trust in thee in battles, when we behold great wealth the prize of combat. I with my words impel thy weapons onward, and sharpen with my prayer thy vital vigour.

column1: ni tat dadhiṣe avare pare ca yasmin āvitha avasā duroṇe / ā sthāpayata mātaram jigatnum atas invata karvarāṇi bhūri // stuṣva varṣman puru vartmānam sam ṛbhvāṇam inatamam āptam āptyānām / ā darśati śavasā bhūri ojāḥ pra sakṣati pratimānam pṛthivyāḥ /
column2: Worthy of praises many-shaped, most skilful, most energetic, Āptya of the Aptyas: He with his might destroys the seven Dānus, subduing many who were deemed his equals. Thou in that house which thy protection guardedh bestowest- wealth, the higher and the lower. Thou stablishest the two much-wandering Mothers, and bringest many deeds to their completion.

column1: imā brahma bṛhaddivaḥ kṛṇavat indrāya śūṣam agniyaḥ svarṣāḥ / mahaḥ gotrasya kṣayati svarājā turaḥ cit viśvam arṇavat tapasvān /
column2: Brihaddiva, the foremost of light-winners, repeasts these holy prayers, this strength to Indra. He rules the great self-luminous fold of cattle, and all the doors of light hath he thrown open.

column1: eva mahān bṛhaddivaḥ atharvā avocat svām tanvam indram eva / svasārau mātaribhvarī aripre hinvanti ca ene śavasā vardhayanti ca /
column2: Thou hath Brihaddiva the great Atharvan, spoken to Indra as himself in person. The Mātarisvarīs, the spotless sisters, with power exalt him and impel him onward.

column1: citram devānām ketuḥ anīkam jyotiṣmān pradiśaḥ sūryaḥ udyan / divākaraḥ ati dyumnaiḥ tamāṃsi viśvātārīt duritāni śukraḥ /
column2: Bright, Presence of the Gods, the luminous herald, Siirya hath mounted the celestial regions. Day's maker, he hath shone away the darkness, and radiant passed o'er places hard to traverse.

column1: citram devānām ud agāt anīkam cakṣuḥ mitrasya varuṇasya agneḥ / āprāt dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣam sūryaḥ ātmā jagataḥ tasthuṣaḥ ca /
column2: The brilliant Presence of the Gods hath risen, the eye of Mitra, Varuna, and Agni. The soul of all that moveth not or moveth, Sūrya hath filled the earth and air and heaven.

column1: sūryaḥ devīm uṣasam rocamānām maryaḥ na yoṣām abhī eti paścāt / yatra naraḥ devayantaḥ yugāni vitanvate prati bhadrāya bhadram /
column2: Even as a lover followeth a maiden, so doth the Sun the Dawn, refulgent Goddess: Where pious men extend their generations before the Gracious One for happy fortune.

column1: tvam naḥ indra ā bharam ojaḥ nṛmṇam śatakrato vicarṣaṇe / ā vīram pṛtanāṣaham /
column2: O Indra, bring great strength to us, bring valour, Satakratu, thou most active, bring. A hero conquering in war.

column1: tvam hi naḥ pitā vaso tvam mātā śatakrato babhūvitha / adhā te sumnam īmahe /
column2: For, gracious Satakratu, thou hast ever been a mother and a sire to us, So now for bliss we pray to thee.

column1: tvām śuṣmin puruhūta vājayantam upa bruve śatakrato / sa naḥ rāsva su vīryam /
column2: To thee, Strong, Much-invoked who showest forth thy strength, O Satakratu, do I speak: So grant thou us heroic might.

column1: svādoḥ itthā viṣuvataḥ madhvaḥ pibanti gauryaḥ / yāḥ indreṇa sa yāvarīḥ vṛṣṇā madanti śobhase vasvīḥ anu sva rājyam / tāḥ asya pṛśanāyuvaḥ somam śrīṇanti pṛśnayaḥ / priyāḥ indrasya dhenavaḥ vajram hinvanti sāyakam vasvīḥ anu sva rājyam //
column2: The juice of Soma thus diffused, sweet to the taste, the bright Cows drink Who for the sake of splendour close to mighty Indra's side rejoice, good in their own supremacy. Craving his touch the dappled Kine mingle the Soma with their milk. The milch-kine dear to Indra send forth his death-dealing thun- derbolt, good in their own supremacy.

column1: tāḥ asya namasā sahaḥ saparyanti pracetasaḥ / vratāni asya saścire purūṇi pūrvacittaye vasvīḥ anu sva rājyam //
column2: With veneration, passing wise, honouring his victorious might, They follow close his many laws to win them due preeminence, good in their own supremacy.

column1: indrāya madūne sutam pari stobhantu naḥ giraḥ / arkam arcantu kāravaḥ /
column2: For Indra, lover of carouse, loud be our songs about the juice: Let poets sing the hymn of praise.

column1: yasmin viśvāḥ adhi śriyaḥ raṇanti sapta saṃsadaḥ / indram sute havāmahe //
column2: We summon Indra to the draught, in whom all glories rest, in whom The seven communities rejoice.

column1: trikadrukeṣu cetanam devāsaḥ yajñam atnata / tam id vardhantu naḥ giraḥ /
column2: By the three Soma jars the Gods span sacrifice that stirs the mind: Let our songs aid and prosper it.

column1: yat somam indra viṣṇavi yat vā gha trita āptye / yat vā marutsu mandase sam indubhiḥ /
column2: If, Indra, thou drink Soma by Vishnu's or Trita Āptya's side, Or with the Maruts take delight in flowing drops;

column1: yat vā śakra parāvati samudre adhi mandase / asmākam id sute raṇā sam indubhiḥ /
column2: Or, Sakra, if thou gladden thee afar or in the sea of air, Rejoice thee in this juice of ours, in flowing drops.

column1: yat vā asi sunvataḥ vṛdhaḥ yajamānasya satpate / ukthe vā yasya raṇyasi sam indubhiḥ /

column2: Thou, Indra, goest unto all Soma libations shed for thee, Both far away and near at hand.

column1: ubhayam śṛṇavat ca naḥ indraḥ arvāk idam vacaḥ / satrācyā maghavā soma pītaye dhiyā śaviṣṭhaḥ ā gamat /

column2: Or, Indra, when with Ruma, Rusama, Syāvaka, and Kripa thou rejoicest thee, Still do the Kanvas bring praises, with their prayers, O Indra, draw thee hither: come.

column2: Over the three great distances, past the Five Peoples go thy way, O Indra, noticing our voice. Send forth thy ray like Sūrya: let my songs attract thee hither- ward. Like waters gathering to the vale.

column2: With Indra splendid feasts be ours enriched with ample spoil, wherewith, Wealthy in food, we may rejoice.

column2: Like thee, thyself, the singers' friend, thou movest as it were, besought, Bold One, the axle of the car.

column2: That, Satakratu, thou to grace and please thy praisers, as it were, Stirrest the axle with thy strength. This is the Godhead, this the might of Sūrya: he hath with- drawn what spread o'er work unfinished. When he hath loosed his horses from their station, straight over all night spreadeth out her garment.

column2: In the sky's lap the Sun this form assumeth for Mitra and for Vāruna to look on. His bay steeds well maintain his power eternal, at one time bright and darksome at another.

column2: With what help will he come to us, wonderful, ever-waxing Friend, With what most mighty company?

column2: What genuine and most liberal draught will spirit thee with juice to burst. Open e'en strongly-guarded wealth?

column2: Do thou who art protector us thy friends who praise thee With hundred aids approach us.

column2: We will, with Indra and all Gods to help us, bring these existing worlds into subjection. Our sacrifice, our bodies, and our offspring shall Indra form together with the Ādityas.

column2: With the Ādityas, with the band of Maruts, may Indra be pro- tector of our bodies. As when the Gods came after they had slaughtered the Asuras, keeping safe their Godlike nature,

column2: Brought the Sun hitherward with mighty powers, and looked about them on their vigorous Godhead. With this may we obtain strength God-appointed, and joy with brave sons through a hundred winters.

column2: Drive all our enemies away, O Indra, the western, mighty Con- queror, and the eastern, Hero, drive off our northern foes and southern, that we in thy wide shelter may be joyful.

column1: kuvid aṅga yavamantaḥ yavam cit yathā dānti anupūrvam viyūya / iha iha eṣām kṛṇuhi bhojanāni ye barhiṣaḥ namaḥ vṛktim na jagmuḥ /
column2: What then? As men whose fields are full of barley reap the ripe corn removing it in order, So bring the food of those men, bring it hither, who come not to prepare the grass for worship.

column2: Men come not with one horse at sacred seasons; thus they obtain no honour in assemblies. Sages desiring herds of kine and horses strengthen the mighty Indra for his friendship.

column2: Ye, Asvins, Lords of Splendour, drank full draughts of grateful Soma juice, And aided Indra in his work with Namuchi of Asura birth.

column1: putram iva pitarau aśvinā ubhā indra āvathuḥ kāvyaiḥ daṃsanābhiḥ / yat surāmam vi apibaḥ śacībhiḥ sarasvatī tvā maghavan abhiṣṇak /
column2: As parents aid a son, both Asvins, Indra, aided thee with their wondrous powers and wisdom When thou, with might, hadst drunk the draught that glad- dens, Sarasvati, O Maghavan refreshed thee.

column1: indraḥ sutrāmā svavām avobhiḥ su mṛḍīkaḥ bhavatu viśva vedāḥ / bādhatām dveṣaḥ abhayam naḥ kṛṇotu su vīryasya patayaḥ syāma / sa sutrāmā svavān indraḥ asmat ārāt cit dveṣaḥ sanutar yuyotu / tasya vayam sumatau yajñiyasya api bhadre saumanase syāma /
column2: Indra is strong to save, rich in assistance: may he, possessing all, be kind and gracious. May he disperse our foes and give us safety, and may we be the lords of hero vigour. May we enjoy his favour, his the holy: may we enjoy his blessed loving-kindness. May this rich Indra, as our good protector, drive off and keep afar all those who hate us.

column1: vi hi sotoḥ asṛkṣata na indram devam amaṃsata / yatra amadat vṛṣākapiḥ aryaḥ puṣṭeṣu mad sakhā viśvasmāt indraḥ uttaraḥ /
column2: Men have abstained from pouring juice; nor counted Indra as a God. Where at the votary's store my friend Vrishākapi hath drunk his fill. Supreme is Indra over all.
